Input:
age: 51. gender: M.  
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___

Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Sulfa(Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / Penicillins / Asacol
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
ESRD
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
living non-related renal transplant ___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ man with h/o crohns s/p total colectomy with 
ileoanal pullthrough ___ years ago at ___ who has been on 
hemodialysis since ___ for ESRD due to medication toxicity 
and chronic dehydration.  He has a living donor (cousin's 
___ appropriate crossmatches and serologies were performed 
and were suitable.  He presented for translant. 
 
Past Medical History:
PMHx PSHx: ESRD ___ interstitial nephritis ___ Asacol on HD via 
RIJ tunnel cath ___.  
- Crohn's disease s/p total colectomy with ileoanal pullthrough 
___ years ago at ___  
- Tonsilectomy  

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:45PM BLOOD WBC-8.5 RBC-3.44* Hgb-10.9* Hct-32.3* 
MCV-94 MCH-31.5 MCHC-33.6 RDW-13.0 Plt ___
___ 06:45PM BLOOD Glucose-126* UreaN-27* Creat-4.1* Na-143 
K-4.1 Cl-113* HCO3-19* AnGap-15
___ 01:10PM BLOOD Glucose-110* UreaN-36* Creat-3.7* Na-139 
K-5.1 Cl-109* HCO3-20* AnGap-15
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, he underwent living donor renal transplant with 6 
___ double J ureteral stent. Of note the venous anastomosis 
was redone intra op. The kidney was making urine. Surgeon was 
Dr. ___. Please refer to operative note further details. 
He received induction immunosuppression which consisted of ATG, 
Cellcept and Solu-Medrol. Prograf was started. 

Postop overnight, urine output decreased to 35 and SBP was in 
low ___. Normal saline boluses were given without much change. 
5% albumin was then given with gradual increase in urine output 
and SBP to low 100s. He received a 2nd dose of ATG. Prograf was 
held as this was suspected of decreasing urine output. Incision 
was intact with scant serosanguinous drainage. Abdomen was 
non-distended. He experienced a little bit of nausea and was 
given Zofran. Urine output gradually increased to 150ml/hr. He 
continued to receive ___ NS cc/cc urine output replacements. 

On postop day 2, urine output continued to average 210 to 100 
cc. IV fluid replacements were decreased to a maintenance rate D 
___ at 100cc. Vital signs were stable. A 3rd dose of ATG 
(125mg each dose) was administered and Prograf was started at 
2mg bid.  Diet was advanced to regular, however, the patient was 
reluctant to advance given h/o Crohn's and anticipation of 
multiple BMs with regular food. By postop day 5, he was taking 
solid food but c/o multiple loose stools. Imodium 2mg daily was 
started with decrease in stool output. On postop day 6, urine 
output was ~ 2 liter per day. Creatinine was down to 1.9. 
Incision was intact and without drainage. He was taking 
Oxycodone for pain with good relief and was ambulating 
independently. Medication teaching went well. Dapsone was 
started ___ PCP prophylaxis given sulfa allergy 
precluding Bactrim. G6PD was 11.8. 

Of note, Prograf level increased to a high of 18.4 on ___. ___ 
dose of Prograf was held and prograf 3mg was given in am ___. 
Trough level was 7.0 that day and dose was increased to 4mg bid. 
He was instructed to have trough level drawn at ___ Lab 
on ___ and ___. Cellcept was well tolerated. Steroids were 
tapered off. 

He was discharged to home in stable condition. 

 
Medications on Admission:
lisinopril 2.5mg', nephrocaps 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H Pain 
may change to every 8 hours as needed for pain 
2. Dapsone 100 mg PO DAILY 
RX *dapsone 100 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*30 
Tablet Refills:*6
3. Famotidine 20 mg PO DAILY 
4. Mycophenolate Mofetil 1000 mg PO BID 
5. Nystatin Oral Suspension 5 ml PO QID 
6. Amlodipine 5 mg PO DAILY 
RX *amlodipine 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*30 
Tablet Refills:*3
7. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*50 Tablet Refills:*0
8. Tacrolimus 4 mg PO Q12H 
9. Loperamide 2 mg PO Q 24H prevent diarrhea 
RX *loperamide [Anti-Diarrheal (loperamide)] 2 mg 1 by mouth 
once a day Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*3
10. ValGANCIclovir 450 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
esrd 
crohn's 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call the Transplant office ___ if you have any 
of the following: temperature of 101 or greater, chills, nausea, 
vomiting, inability take any of your medications, increased 
abdominal pain, incision redness/bleeding/drainage, decreased 
urine output, weight gain of 3 pounds in a day, edema or any 
concerns
-you will need to have labs drawn tomorrow, ___ then 
___ then twice weekly on ___ and ___
-you may shower with soap and water, rinse and pat incision dry. 
do not scrub incision. Do not apply powder/lotion or ointment to 
incision
-do not lift anything heavier than 10 pounds. no straining
-no driving while taking pain medication
 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 51-year-old male who underwent a living non-related renal transplant due to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) caused by medication toxicity and chronic dehydration. He has a history of Crohn's disease, which was treated with total colectomy and ileoanal pullthrough 20 years ago. He has been on hemodialysis since then. The patient has allergies to sulfa, penicillins, and Asacol. His past medical history includes ESRD, interstitial nephritis, and Asacol on HD via RIJ tunnel cath. 

During his hospital stay, the patient received induction immunosuppression and underwent a successful transplant with a living donor. He experienced some complications, including decreased urine output and low blood pressure, which were managed with fluid replacement and medication adjustments. The patient was discharged with a stable condition and was instructed to follow up with the transplant office and to have regular lab tests. His medications at discharge included acetaminophen, dapsone, famotidine, mycophenolate mofetil, nystatin, amlodipine, oxycodone, tacrolimus, and valganciclovir.

Findings consistent with small-bowel obstruction, with a

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ presented to the ___ for a recurrence of his 
ventral wall hernia. It was reduced in the ED x 2, but due to 
the fact that the patient had an incarceration on CT and had 
been obstipated x 24 hours he was admitted for planned 
correction of the hernia.

The patient was prepared for surgery and was taken to the OR on

the PACU before returning to the hospital floor. He had several

observation overnight.

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
abdominal incisional hernia

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the 
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or 

back.

*Avoid lifting objects > 5lbs until your follow-up appointment 
with the surgeon.

*Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
as ordered. 
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.

Incision Care:
-Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
-You may shower, and wash surgical incisions.
-Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
-Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 45-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of an incisional hernia. He had a history of prolactinoma, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He also had a past surgical history of incarcerated umbilical hernia repair and cornea surgery. The patient had an allergy to amoxicillin.

The patient was diagnosed with an abdominal incisional hernia with obstruction and underwent a laparoscopic incisional hernia repair with graft or prosthesis. He was prescribed Percocet for pain and Colace for constipation.

At discharge, the patient was stable and was instructed to follow up with his surgeon. He was advised to avoid lifting objects greater than 5 pounds, driving, and operating heavy machinery while taking pain medications. He was also instructed to resume his regular home medications and take any new medications as ordered.

Sepsis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
___ h/o remote MRSA abscess transferred here with sepsis after 
suffering complications of perforated appy. Initially presented 
to presented to ___ on ___ with 
perforated appendicitis where he underwent lap appendectomy 
complicated by abscess which was later drained by ___ on 
___ at ___. He was also treated with 
antibiotics.
.
Two weeks ago, he was rescanned with evidence of a 6 x 3.3 cm 
abscess in the RLQ. A residual collection was identified and 
drained again. He was admitted for sepsis and treated with 
another course of antibiotics, discharged on 2 weeks of 
augmentin. He had been feeling well, tolerating POs, and without 
nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain.
.
Yesterday at 1pm, he was scheduled for a repeat interval CT scan 
which was apparently reassuring but was not officially read. He 
returned home, however, and began having chills, mild transient 
chest pain, nausea and anxiety for which he returned to ___ 
___.
.
At the outside hospital, he was found to be hypotensive to SBP 
of ___
and tachycardic to 160s. He was started on a norepinephrine drip 
with improvement in SBP to 110s. Transported by helicopter to 
___ ED.
.
In the ED, vitals Tm/Tc 104/101 rectally, 115/68, 88, 12, 95% 
RA. Labs notable for WBC 24.7 with 23% bands, lactate 1.8, HCO3 
19, normal LFTs, INR 1.4, CK 133, CKMB 13 (index 9.8), TnT 0.29. 
U/A negative, blood and urine cultures sent. ECG with TWF II, 
TWI III. CT abd/pelvis with inflammation about appy site but no 
drainable fluid collection and no free air. Central venous line 
placed, continued on levophed. Given vanco, levoflox, 
ceftriaxone, flagyl. Surgery consulted and based on imaging and 
benign abdomen, recommended non-surgical management at present. 
Cardiology was called and thought this was demand ischemia. He 
was admitted to MICU for sepsis.
.
ROS: Denies pain. He denies fever, and has had diarrhea 
(___) which he relates to being on antibiotics. While he 
was off antibiotics, his diarrhea resolved. Denies dyspnea, 
orthopnea, PND. Able to walk independently.

___ 07:50AM BLOOD Neuts-44.6* Bands-0 Lymphs-17.1* 
Monos-2.1 Eos-36.0* Baso-0.2
.
Cultures:
___ blood cultures: no growth to date
___ urine cultures: final no growth
___ stool: C. Diff negative
___ stool: C. Diff negative
___ stool: C. Diff negative

CT Abdomen and Pelvis (IV Contrast):
There are small bilateral pleural effusions with associated 
atelectasis. Atelectasis within the lingula is additionally 
noted. 
An amorphous area low attenuation is identified within segment 
IVb of the 
liver. The liver is otherwise unremarkable. The gallbladder, 
spleen, 
pancreas, adrenal glands, and left kidney appear within normal 
limits. The 
kidneys enhance symmetrically and excrete contrast normally. A 
3-cm low- 
attenuation lesion at the lower pole of the right kidney is 
consistent with a simple cyst. Diffuse atherosclerotic disease 
of the infrarenal abdominal aorta is evident.   
There is thickening of the cecum and significant pericecal 
stranding of 
mesenteric fat. Surgical clips at the site of appendectomy are 
noted. No 
evidence of abscess or loculated fluid. A small amount of free 
fluid in this area, which also tracks down into the pelvis is 
seen. Although the distal ileum is not well distended with oral 
contrast, there is a suggestion of bowel wall thickening/edema 
and stranding of the surrounding mesenteric fat. No organized 
fluid collection is evident, however. There is no evidence of 
bowel obstruction as contrast has passed through to the rectum. 
There is no free air within the abdomen. Although the colon is 
not distended, there is a suggestion of diffuse colonic wall 
thickening. 
.
CT OF THE PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST: The rectum, sigmoid colon, 
intrapelvic 
loops of small bowel are unremarkable. A Foley balloon is 
present within a 
decompressed bladder. A small amount of free fluid is evident 
within the 
pelvis. Small, bilateral fat-containing inguinal hernias are 
evident. 
OSSEOUS STRUCTURES: There are no suspicious lytic or blastic 
lesions. 
IMPRESSION: 
1. Inflammatory process appears to be centered in the ileocecal 
area at the site of recent appendectomy. No organized or 
drainable intra-abdominal fluid collection. Assessment is 
somewhat limited by lack of distal ileal distention with oral 
contrast. A small amount of free fluid and scattered subjacent 
lymph nodes are additionally evident.  
2. Equivocal diffuse colonic wall thickening. This finding 
raises the 
possibility of colitis and and infectious process such as C. 
difficile should be considered.   
3. Small bilateral pleural effusions with associated 
atelectasis. 
.
ECHOCARDIOGRAM ___:
The left atrium and right atrium are normal in cavity size. No 
atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. The 
estimated right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. Left ventricular 
wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is mild 
regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with focal 
akinesis of the basal inferolateral wall and hypokinesis of the 
basal half of the inferior wall. There is minimal hypokinesis of 
the remaining segments (LVEF = 45 %). The estimated cardiac 
index is normal (>=2.5L/min/m2). Tissue Doppler imaging suggests 
a normal left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP<12mmHg). Right 
ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The 
aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good 
leaflet excursion and no aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve 
appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. 
The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. 
There is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion. 
IMPRESSION: Mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction 
c/w ischemia. Left pleural effusion. 
.
ECG ___: normal sinus rhythm with T-wave inversions in 
leads III, AVF
.
PENDING STUDIES AT TIME OF DISCHARGE:
final blood cultures from ___ (no growth to date)
stool cultures, O&P from ___. SEPSIS:
Mr. ___ was transferred from an outside hospital with 
hypotension, on Levophed with an elevated WBC count of 22.6 on 
admission.  The source of infection was not clear on admission 
and differential included infection from recurrent abscesses at 
appendectomy site or C. Diff colitis.  Other etiology considered 
was reaction to CT contrast.  Was started on Vanocmycin, Zosyn 
and Flagyl in the MICU.  He remained hemodynamically stable and 
afebrile and Levophed was stopped on the day of transfer for 
MAP>65, SvO2 72, CVP 6 and good urine output.  CT showed 
inflammation prior appendectomy site without fluid collection.  
Surgery was consulted and did not recommend surgery.  
Gastroenterology was consulted and recommended 48 hours of IV 
antibiotics for presumed GI infection, then 3 weeks of PO 
antibiotics.  Cultures were obtained on ___ from ___ 
___ and showed no growth to date of blood or urine 
cultures.  Blood and urine cultures collected at ___ 
showed no growth to date.  C. Diff X 3 were negative.  The 
patient continued to do well and was trasnferred to the general 
medical floor on ___.  He was continued on IV antibiotics 
and then changed to PO antibiotics on ___.  He was put on 
Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO BID and Metronidazole 500mg PO TID and 
was discharged with 16 more days of antibiotics.  He will 
___ with his PCP ___ 1 week.  Another possible etiology for 
his symptoms that was considered was anaphylaxis from PO 
contrast from the CT scan, although this was less likely given 
that he has had PO contrast in the past without problems.  We 
recommended that he see an allergist as an outpatient to assess 
the possibility of an allergic reaction to PO contrast.
.
2. NSTEMI
The patient was found to have elevated cardiac enzymes with a CK 
of 133, CKMB 19, Troponin T 0.29 and T-wave inversions in leads 
III and AVL.  Cardiology was called and thought this was likely 
rate-related demand ischemia in the setting of tachycardia due 
to sepsis physiology.  Cardiac enzymes trended down and 
___ ECGs showed no change.  The patient's tachycardia 
improved with IV fluids and antibiotics.  He was asymptomatic 
during his admission.  He was put on telemetry and had no events 
or arrythmias.  An echocardiogram showed global reduced 
function, EF 45% and focal akinesis of basal inferior wall.  
Aspirin 325mg PO qday and Metoprolol 12.5mg PO BID were started 
for NSTEMI.  Cardiology did not recommend heparin or 
anti-platelet agents.  Cardiology recommended a ___ echo 
and cardiologist appointment within 4 weeks after his acute 
illness had resolved. The patient will have this scheduled with 
his primary care doctor.  He remained asymptomatic with no chest 
pain or signs of clinical heart failure.
.
3. EOSINOPHILIA
The patient's WBCs trended down from admission from 22.6 to 
11.8.  He had 23% bands on admission which resolved by 
discharge.  His eosinophil count was 0 on admission, however on 
___ he had 32% eosinophils, on ___ had 38% eosinophils, and 
on ___ had 36% eosinophils.  This corresponds to an absolute 
eosinophil count of 3680 on ___, 4294 on ___, and 4248 on 
___.  He had no signs of drug reaction, no fevers, skin rashes 
or other symptoms.  His diarrhea had improved over the course of 
admission but was still having ___ bowel movements per day.  His 
stool was checked for C. Diff and was negative X 3.  Ova and 
parasites and fecal stool cultures were pending at the time of 
discharge.  It was recommended that he see an allergist for 
discussion and testing for reaction to PO contrast from the CT 
scan.
.
4. DIARRHEA
Most likely etiology is antibiotic-associated as the patient has 
been on antibiotics off and on for the past several weeks.  His 
diarrhea was at times watery, but improved through admission and 
was described as loose stool at the time of discharge.  
Clostridium Difficile was checked X 3 and was negative.  He was 
discharged with Cipro and Flagyl for his antibiotic regimen.  He 
will ___ with his PCP with any further problems.  His 
final stool cultures are still pending at the time of discharge.
.
5. ANXIETY
The patient was anxious during his hospitalization regarding his 
medical condition and etiology of his sepsis.  He was given 
Ativan 0.5mg PRN for anxiety symptoms.  He was given Trazodone 
25mg PO qHS to help with sleep.  
.
6. PROPHYLAXIS
Mr. ___ was given SC Heparin for DVT prophylaxis.  He was 
able to tolerate a regular diet on ___.  
.
His symptoms improved and he was discharged with close PCP 
___ and instructions to ___ with cardiology as 
arranged by his PCP.  He was also recommended to see an 
allergist on discharge for ___ of this episode as a 
potential reaction to PO contrast from the CT scan.
 
Medications on Admission:
Augmentin BID x 2 weeks (approx day 7)

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed.

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis:
1. Sepsis

Secondary Diagnosis:
2. Non-ST Elevation Mycardial Infarction
3. Eosinophilia

 
Discharge Condition:
afebrile, hemodynamically stable, good condition

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with low blood pressure and 
septic shock after having a perforated appendicitis several 
weeks ago.  All your blood cultures were negative.  You were 
admitted to the intensive care unit and improved dramatically on 
antibiotics.  You were initially put on intravenous antibiotics 
and these were changed to oral antibiotics after 72 hours.  You 
experienced some chest pain and blood tests showed that was some 
damange to your heart which was likely from the low blood 
pressure.  You had an echocardiogram which showed some reduced 
function of the heart.  You should see a cardiologist as an 
outpatient as arranged by your primary care doctor and have 
another echocardiogram in 1 month to reassess your heart.

You had a rise in your white blood cell count associated with 
the sepsis.  Your eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, was 
still elevated on discharge.  You should have your blood checked 
in 1 week to assess your white blood count and differential.  
This will be arranged by your primary care doctor.

You should continue to take the antibiotics Ciprofloxacin and 
Metronidazole as prescribed for the next ___ days, even if you 
are feeling well.  You were started on Metoprolol 12.5mg by 
mouth twice a day to help your heart.  You should continue to 
take aspirin.

You should ___ with your primary care doctor next week.  
Your primary care doctor ___ arrange for you to see a 
cardiologist and have a repeat echocardiogram within 1 month.

You should call your doctor or come to the emergency room for 
any fevers > 100, chills, night sweats, cough, shortness of 
breath, chest pain or pressure, numbness in the arm or jaw, 
abdominal pain or bloating, nausea or vomiting, swelling in the 
legs, skin rashes, or any other symptoms that concern you.
 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 45-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with sepsis. He initially presented to the emergency department with perforated appendicitis, which was complicated by an abscess that was drained twice. He was treated with antibiotics and discharged, but two weeks later, he returned to the hospital with sepsis and was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). 

The patient has a history of MRSA abscess on his arm and a previous appendectomy complicated by an abscess. He has no known allergies to drugs. 

On admission, the patient's physical examination revealed an ill-appearing individual with a temperature of 98.4Â°F, blood pressure of 129/67 mmHg, and a heart rate of 88 beats per minute. His abdomen was soft, nontender, and nondistended, with well-healed laparoscopic scars. 

Laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 24.7, lactate level of 1.8, and troponin level of 0.29. He was treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin, levofloxacin, and ceftriaxone, and was started on a norepinephrine drip. 

The patient's diagnosis was sepsis, and he was managed non-surgically. He was discharged with a plan for continued antibiotic therapy and follow-up.

Output:
discharge_summary: The patient is a 91-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of cough and fever. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation, and congestive heart failure. She was previously admitted to the hospital with a similar condition and was discharged with a course of antibiotics, which she completed. However, her symptoms persisted, and she presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath. On admission, she was febrile with possible early pneumonia on chest X-ray, and she received a dose of ceftriaxone. Her white blood cell count was normal, and her cough was non-productive, so she was not initially treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia. She was started on azithromycin, prednisone, and nebulizers, and her symptoms improved.

___ yo M w/ AIDS off HAART for 15 months presents w/ malaise,

.
#HIV: Pt. has had poor reactions to ARV Tx in the past (stopped 
taking because of nausea w/ ritonavir), pt. restarted on ARV w/ 
attention to this. Pt. did well w/ no N/V after taking ritonavir 
at HS. Blood cultures were drawn for bacteria, mycobacteria and 
fungi and were no growth to date on day of D/C. Continued 
dapsone ppx, but considered switching to atovaquone because of 
hemolytic anemia, Hct remained stable so we kept pt. on dapsone.

.
#Abdominal pain: Pt. has Hx of bowel wall ulcer, this seems 
probable as his tenderness is extremely localized, has not been 
progressive. Likely he does not have acute bacterial issue as he 
is non septic and this has been present for a long time. He has 
been scoped before w/ conflicting path results (negative CMV Cx 
but a few inclusions),consider CMV colitis, Consider HSV 
colitis, Consider parasitic ___. Dr. ___ 
performed the endoscopy felt that the ulcer looked like it was 
from CMV and so pt. was empirically started on IV gancyclovir 
and then transitioned to PO valgancyclovir after 2 days. The 
abdominal pain seemed to improve slightly day to day. Pt. had 
elevated alk phos, GGT, Tbili so liver U/S was performed and wet 
read was consistent w/ HIV cholangiopathy.
.
#Anemia: Appears to be hemolytic as haptoglobin was decreased to 
<20 and retic count is elevated. Elevated retic count (not 
appropriately elevated given low Hbg) suggests that there is a 
lack of production. He recieved 2 units of PRBCs and his Hct 
increased to above 25 and remained stable after transfusion, on 
day of d/c was 24.9. Likely that he is no longer hemolyzing, but 
unknown whether his marrow is responding at time of d/c. There 
was significant concern that the lack of marrow response 
represented a marrow infiltrative process so a BMB was obtained. 
Results of BMB were pending at D/C.
.
#Fever: Likely OI as pt. has no other focal signs of infection. 
Could be drug fever as pt. recently started on gancyclovir and 
ARV's, the fevers did not appear until the night after the 
gancyclovir was started and continued to wax and wane and he had 
a temperature to 100.8 the night before d/c. CXR, UA, Ucx, Blood 
Cx X3 sets routine Negative so far. Pt. to f/u w/ Dr. ___ 
results of BMB and mycolytic blood cultures.
.
#Fatigue: likely ___ anemia, but may also be due to chronic OI 
and/or HIV wasting syndrome as pt. appeared quite cachectic. 
Nutrition was consulted and recommended ensure supplementation, 
but pt. did not like ensure and made this clear to nutrition, 
ensure was seen unopened on pt.s tray every morning.
.
#Diarrhea: Likely ___ OI, differential is quite wide: crypto, 
giardia, ___, CMV, C. diff. All previous wkup 
was negative in ___.  Likely etiology is an OI which will be 
treated by increasing his CD4 count. Repeat stool studies were 
negative for o/p, ___, crypto, giardia, cyclospora.
.
#Hyponatremia: Possibly secondary to diarrhea with free water 
replacement or SIADH from chronic pain. Most likelly from 
diarrhea. Urine lytes, Cr, Osm inconclusive for SIADH vs. volume 
depletion. FeNa was 1.6. Pt. remained asymptomatic and recieved 
no specific treatment.
.
#Elevated alk phos: Likely bile duct source as GGT also 
elevated. Pt. also complaining of RUQ pain and tenderness, has 
previous history of U/S which showed cholelithiasis. Liver U/S 
did not show stones in duct, wet read was consistent with HIV 
cholangiopathy.

Output:
discharge_summary: The patient is a 55-year-old male with a chief complaint of fatigue. He has a history of AIDS, diagnosed 15 months prior, and has been off antiretroviral therapy (ARV) for 15 months. He presents with anemia, diarrhea, and abdominal pain, which has been present for a year. He has a history of depression, situational depression, and has experienced weight loss. His physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor, hard white plaques on the sides of his tongue, and multiple umbilicated papules on his face. His laboratory results show anemia, elevated liver enzymes, and hyponatremia. He was started on IV gancyclovir and then transitioned to PO valgancyclovir for suspected CMV colitis. He received 2 units of PRBCs and his Hct increased to above 25. He was also started on dapsone prophylaxis. His discharge medications include dapsone 100mg QD and valgancyclovir.

were able to remain stable on a trach mask at 40% O2. 

There was a discussion held with you about the risk of eating. 
You stated that your quality of life was significantly impaired 
by not being able to eat and you accepted the risk of eating, 
including aspiration, infection, worsening respiratory status. 
You were able to tolerate a thin liquid and dysphagia diet 
during your hospitalization. You were on tube feeds but this was 
stopped when you were able to tolerate oral intake. You should 
continue bolus feeds with cans of Jevity 1.2 at 5 cans/day. You 
can decrease this as you tolerate more oral intake.

Please follow up with your physicians as below. 

Wishing you well,

Your ___ Care Team 
 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
discharge_summary: The patient is a 65-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with hypoxic respiratory failure. She has a past medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), orthostatic hypotension, and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). She has allergies to penicillins and oxybutynin. The patient's chief complaint was hypoxia, dyspnea, productive cough, and congestion, which she experienced for the past two days. She was previously intubated and had a tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement. She was referred to the emergency department for stoma closure and was found to have tachypnea, rhonchorous lungs, and a stoma site. The patient was given various medications, including albuterol, ipratropium bromide, and cefepime. She was also given oxygen therapy and had a flutter valve inserted. The patient's physical examination revealed clear lungs, regular heart rate and rhythm, and normal abdominal examination. The patient's laboratory results showed anemia, leukocytosis, and elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP). Imaging studies revealed extensive atelectasis in the lower lungs, which could not exclude a superimposed pneumonia. The patient was discharged with a tracheostomy mask and speaking valve, and was advised to use a flutter valve and oxygen therapy.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman who initially presented 
with severe abdominal pain. At that time, no obvious findings on 
CT scan and no obvious leak was appreciated. Given her pain and 
significant CT findings, it was decided that she would benefit 
from a diagnostic laparoscopy. At that time, I was concerned 
that she may actually have a gastric perforation and may have a 
gallbladder issue that could potentially be addressed 
laparoscopically. Thus, we decided to start the case 
laparoscopically with potential conversion to an open procedure 
if a significant
lesion in the stomach was appreciated. The risks and benefits of 
the procedure were described in detail to the patient. Despite 
these risks, she chose to proceed with surgery. She was found to 
have a gastric perforation and therefore converted to 
exploratory laparotomy with ___ patch and placement of a 
Pravena vac. 

Neuro: The patient was alert and oriented throughout 
hospitalization; pain was initially managed with a IV dialudid 
PCA and then transitioned to oral acetaminophen and oxycodone 
once tolerating a diet. 
CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization. 
GI/GU/FEN: The patient was initially kept NPO with a 
___ tube in place for decompression and nasojejunal 
tube in place for feeding.  On POD2 tube feeding were started 
through the doboff. On POD3 the NGT was accidently  removed by 
the patient when sneezing. She was kept NPO (except tube feeds). 
On POD5 she underwent upper GI leak test that was unclear and 
therefore was repeated on POD7 and negative for leak. Doboff was 
removed and she was given a regular diet with good tolerability. 
H.Pylori result was positive and therefore she was started on 
quadruple therapy once tolerating a diet. 
ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none. H.Pylori quadrupal therapy 
started and prescribed 2 week course. 
HEME: The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs 
of bleeding, of which there were none.
Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and ___ 
dyne boots were used during this stay and was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Gastric perforation 
H. Pylori infction

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the hospital because you had abdominal 
pain. You had a CT scan which showed that you had a perforation 
in your stomach where it connects to your small intestine. It 
was found to be caused by an infection (H.pylori), for which you 
have been started on medication and will finish after discharge. 
You underwent surgery to get your perforation fixed. You have 
tolerated a regular diet, had a return of bowel function, and 
your pain has been well-controlled. Thus, you are now ready to 
be discharged home to continue your recovery. Please follow the 
discharge instructions below: 

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old female who presented with abdominal pain. She reported a 2-week history of general malaise, upper respiratory tract infection, and decreased appetite. She also experienced severe abdominal pain, which began while she was sitting on the couch, and had not had a bowel movement or flatus in 2 days. She vomited non-bloody, non-bilious emesis shortly after eating.

The patient has no known allergies or adverse reactions. She has no past medical history, past surgical history, or family history of note.

The patient's physical examination revealed a soft, tender abdomen with focal rebound and guarding. Laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, blood urea nitrogen, and creatinine levels, as well as abnormal liver function tests.

The patient underwent a diagnostic laparoscopy, which revealed a gastric perforation. She was converted to an exploratory laparotomy and underwent repair of the perforation with a patch and placement of a Pravena vac.

The patient was prescribed medications at discharge, but the specific medications are not mentioned in the report.

is no mitral valve prolapse. No mass or vegetation is seen on 
the mitral valve. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The 
tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is mild 
pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial 
effusion.   
A patent foramen ovale is present with right to left shunting of 
agitated saline contrast during Valsalva.  
.
___ Lower Extremity doppler ultrasound
No evidence of deep venous thrombosis in right or left lower 
extremity.
.
___ Cardiac Catheterisation
Change for 6 ___ XB3 guide.  The initial plan was to pass the
wire as the primary reperfusion device.  A Pilot 50 Wire was
passed in a prolapsed fashion but this did not restore flow. 
Given that the patient was pain free and the small territory at
risk, it was decided to avoid further attempts at recanalization
(with balloon angioplasty) given risk of dissection, 
perforation.
The patient had intermittent chest pain at the end of the
procedure and was started on IV TNG and administered opiates 
with
resolution of chest pain.  He left the laboratory in stable
condition.
.
___ Foot XRay
Three views show the bony structures and joint spaces to be
essentially within normal limits. No dorsal swelling or evidence 
of erosion
is appreciated. No calcaneal spurs.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o M w/ PMH of prostate CA, HTN, presenting with distal 
apical NSTEMI.
.
# APICAL LAD STEMI:  Distal LAD thrombosis with distal apical 
infarct, s/p unsuccessful recanalisation during cardiac 
catheterisation.  No other evidence of coronoary atherosclerosis 
was found. Echocardiogram whowed preserved EF and no ventricular 
wall motion abnormalities. However, he was noted to have a 
patent formane ovale.  Given absence of atherosclerotic disease, 
PFO and known CA prostate, thromboembolic event from a possible 
proximal DVT remains a possible etiology for his STEMI.  Cardiac 
enzymes peaked ___ and trended down prior to discharge. He 
was treated with a heparin drip for 2 days after the procedure, 
as well as aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol.  He was started on 
lisinopril and atorvastatin, but these were held in the setting 
of acute kidney injury.  He will need to continue aspirin 
lifelong and clopidogrel for at least one year given his 
prothrombotic state.  Atorvastation was restarted at the time of 
discharge.
.  
# s/p CATH: unsuccessful attempt at wire recanalisation of 
distal LAD.
.
# THROMBOEMBOLISM: Cardiac cath shows no evidence of coronary 
atherosclerosis.  MI site is unusual and patient has PFO, 
history of prostate cancer, prothrombotic state. LENIs were 
negative, but did not include an evaluation of the iliac 
arteries.  He will continue aspirin and plavix for 
anticoagulation following discharge.  
.
# Fever: Etiology unclear. UA, CXR clear.  Urine cultures and 
blood cultures pending.  However, timing of fever suggests 
possible link with gout flare.  Other etiologies include: 
infection, post-MI, thromboembolism/PE, B-symptoms from cancer. 
His fever curve trended down spontaneously prior to discharge.
.
# Thigh pain - bilateral. Could be from strenous workout pt 
reports. CKs coming down but CK so out of proportion elevated 
compared to MB. We just started statin which can cause myopathy 
but states thigh pain since presentation. Pt without significant 
CAD that we know of.  We held his statin, but restarted it at 
the time of discharge.
.
# ___: Cr of 1.4 on ___ up from baseline of 1.0.  Could be 
secondary to high 
CK. Uric acid was 6.6, urinalysis was clear.  We gave him a 
small fluid bolus. 
.
# Right ankle pain - Most likely gout flair. pt with history of 
gout. A foot Xray was performed which showed no pathology.  His 
pain was controlled with percocet and colchicine.   
.  
# HTN: BP was high on presentation and he was initially on a 
nitro drip, but this was rapidly weaned and he was treated with 
metoprolol instead.  He was also started on lisinopril, but this 
was held given ___. He will need reevaluation
.

Lipid panel was unremarkable.  HbA1C was pending at the time of

.

Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___.  You were admitted with a heart 
attack. We performed a cardiac catheterization which showed a

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male who presented with chest pain and was diagnosed with a ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). He has a history of prostate cancer, treated with radiation therapy, and no other significant past medical history. He is allergic to Gadolinium-containing agents. 

The patient underwent cardiac catheterization, which showed a total occlusion of the distal left anterior descending (LAD) artery. An attempt was made to open the lesion, but it was not successful, and the patient was treated medically to avoid a potential procedural complication. 

At discharge, the patient's vital signs were stable, and he was prescribed medications, including aspirin, clopidogrel, and heparin. His physical examination was normal, with no signs of cardiac failure or respiratory distress. 

Laboratory results showed elevated troponin levels, indicating cardiac damage, but his kidney and liver function tests were normal. His electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, V4-6, consistent with a STEMI. 

The patient's chest X-ray and echocardiogram showed normal heart and lung structures, with no evidence of pneumonia or congestive heart failure.

# L Pleural Effusion - Etiology was considered in setting of 
pneumonia (leukocytosis with left shift, cough, though afebrile) 
vs. malignancy vs. CHF exacerbation. Pleural fluid studies were 
consistent with exudative effusion (elevated LDH, fluid/serum 
protein .46), making infectious etiology most likely. Patient 
initially received CTX/Azithro at OSH. Given GI symptoms in 
setting of slight hyponatremia, we sent Legionella antigen, 
which were negative. In the MICU we continued CTX and 
Azithromycin. CT chest showed loculated non hemorrhagic 
effusions. No evidence of occult malignancy. Pleural fluid was 
sent for cytology which was negative. 

# Shock - Patient was initially hypotensive to SBPs ___. 
Distributive is most likely in setting of pulmonary infection. 
Lactate was normal. Pressures become stable with SBPs ___ 
s/p Albumin 25g IV in the ED. Cardiogenic etiology is less 
likely given normal TTE in ___. We continued to treat infection 
as described above.   
 
# Congestive Heart Failure - EF 55-60% on TTE in ___. Patient 
has been taking Lasix 40mg PO TID at home. BNP 28329 (patient 
does have CKD, 797 in ___. She was volume overloaded on exam 
(marked JVD and acute onset ___. Possibly exacerbated in the 
setting of paroxysmal afib. Diuresis was held due to hypotension 
in the MICU; however, on the floor she was digressed with 40 mg 
IV lasix for a total of 9L net negative for LOS. Her lasix was

absorption.

___ it was 1.03, though elevated to 3.3 in ___. Likely 
cardiorenal physiology in setting of CHF and RAS (BUN/Cr 30).

was diuresed and her Cr improved to normal with discharge of 
0.9. She did have persistently low bicarb that improved with 
supplementation. 

# Atrial fibrillation - CHA2DS2-VASc 5 - Patient managed on 
nadolol at home. She had been started on Eliquis ___, but 
discontinued due to GIB. Patient reports increased palpitations 
over the past several days, no dizziness/lightheadedness.

Dear Ms. ___,

likely had a pneumonia and a loculated pleural effusion. Our 
Thoracic surgeons drained the fluid and added a chest tube which 
drained the remaining fluid. A repeat CT shows no pneumonia or 
signs of malignancy. We had endocrine see you who recommended 
seeing an ophthalmologist for your hyperthyroidism. We removed

exacerbation. We are changing your Lasix to Toresemide which is

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with shortness of breath and chest pain. She has a history of myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, hyperthyroidism, gastrointestinal bleeding, and chronic kidney disease. She is allergic to non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). 

The patient's presenting symptoms included worsening left-sided pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea, as well as increasing bilateral leg edema. She also experienced nausea, vomiting, and decreased oral intake. 

The patient underwent a chest tube and thoracentesis, which resulted in significant improvement in her dyspnea and oxygen saturation. She was diagnosed with pneumonia and pleural effusion, and was treated with antibiotics and other medications. 

At discharge, the patient's vital signs were stable, and she was able to breathe comfortably. She was advised to continue taking her medications as prescribed and to follow up with her primary care physician for further evaluation and treatment.

The patient is a 68-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital after falling from a ladder and being found down. He was transferred from an outside hospital and was found to have bifrontal contusions and a 2.5mm subdural hematoma in the middle cranial fossa. The patient has a history of COPD, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, hiatal hernia, lower esophageal ring, BPH, prostate nodule, and colonic polyps. He has no known allergies to drugs.

The patient underwent PEG placement and IVC filter placement during his hospital stay. He was intubated and sedated initially, but was eventually extubated and transferred to the floor. He was found to have decreased movement in his lower extremities and was incontinent of bladder and bowels.

The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including docusate sodium, lansoprazole, phenytoin, warfarin, magnesium hydroxide, senna, insulin sliding scale, bisacodyl, and fluticasone-salmeterol. He was discharged to an extended care facility in a stable condition with a diagnosis of multiple hemorrhagic contusions and subdural hematoma.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with genotype 1 hepatitis C virus infection and cirrhosis with portal hypertension, abdominal ascites, and recurrent hepatic hydrothorax. He presented with shortness of breath, coughing, and decreased urine output. He had a history of chronic bronchitis, diabetes mellitus type 2, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He had undergone a banding procedure for a GI bleed and an appendectomy. The patient had no known allergies or adverse reactions.

The patient was admitted for a TIPS procedure due to worsening symptoms and decreased effectiveness of diuretics. During his hospital stay, he underwent a thoracentesis, which removed 1.8 liters of yellow fluid from his right lung. He was prescribed lactulose and his diuretics were decreased. His liver function tests (LFTs) were normal.

The patient's diagnosis was successful transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt placement with a decrease in portosystemic pressure gradient from 14 to 3 mmHg. He was discharged with medications including lasix 20mg daily and spironolactone 50mg daily.

___ PCI
Coronary Anatomy
Left main coronary artery: Normal.
Left anterior descending coronary artery: The proximal and mid

small caliber but patent. There was a total occlusion of the 
drug eluting stent in
the LAD that appeared to have marked intimal hyperplasia within 
the stent after recanalization.
There is a 16 mm long, 100% stenosis in the Mid LAD. The 
restenotic lesion has a TIMI flow of 0, has no thrombus present, 
has mild calcification noted, and was previously treated with a 
stent procedure. This
lesion is further described as tubular. An intervention was 
performed on the Mid LAD with a final stenosis of 0%. There were 
no lesion complications. The final TIMI flow was 3.
Left circumflex coronary artery: The left circumflex was a large 
vessel that provided OMB and left posterolateral branches.
Right coronary artery: The RCA has up to 30% irregularites in 
the proximal and mid RCA. There appeared be stents in the mid 
RCA. The distal RCA had minimal irregularities and terminated in 
a PDA and posterolateral branches without disease. There were 
collaterals from right to left to the mid and distal LAD.
Interventional Details
Unfractionated heparin and tirofiban were used for 
anticoagulation to an ACT > 300 seconds.
A 6 ___ XB-LAD 3.5 provided good support for the procedure. A 
300 cm 0.014 BMW wire crossed the lesion with minimal dificulty 
over a OTW 2.5 x 8mm Apex balloon as backup. We first "dottered" 
the lesion
and flow was restored. The 2.5 mm balloon was inflated to 20 
atms. A 2.5 x 16 mm Promus Premier Rx was deployed at 16 ATM for 
30 secs. The stent was posted dilated with a 2.5 x 15 mm balloon 
at 24 atms for 20 secs.
Final angiogram revealed no residual stenosis, TIMI 3 flow and 
no evidence of dissection or rupture.
The patient left the cath lab pain free and with stable vistal 
signs.

Intra-procedural Complications: None.
Impressions:
1. Anterior STEMI due to single vessel coronary artery disease 
in the LAD with in stent restenosis and thrombus
2. Successful drug eluting stent for in-stent restenosis and 
thrombosis of the LAD 
Recommendations
1. Aspirin - clopigogrel - tirofiban x 4 hours
2. Medical therapy

2D or color Doppler. There is mild symmetric left ventricular 
hypertrophy with normal cavity size and global systolic function 
(LVEF>55%). There is mild regional left ventricular systolic 
dysfunction with hypokinesis to akinesis of the distal left 
ventricle, and dyskinesis of the true apex. The remaining 
segments contract normally (biplane LVEF = 58 %). No masses or 
thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. Tissue Doppler imaging 
suggests an increased left ventricular filling pressure 
(PCWP>18mmHg). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall 
motion are normal. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. Mild 
(1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are 
mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) 
mitral regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are 
mildly thickened. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic 
pressure is normal. There is an anterior space which most likely 
represents a prominent fat pad. 

IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
regional dysfunction c/w CAD and MI. Suggestion of impaired LV 
relaxation. Mild aortic and mitral regurgitation. Mildly dilated 
thoracic aorta.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital because you had a heart 
attack.

While you were here, you received a procedure called a left 
heart catheterization, which looked at your heart's blood 
vessels. There, we found that one of your previous stents was 
blocked with a clot, which was causing the heart attack. To open 
up this vessel, a second stent was placed within the first 
stent. After the procedure, you were placed on an IV medication 
called nitroglycerin overnight to relieve your chest pain, but 
you were able to get weaned off that medication the next day and 
stay chest pain free, which was very reassuring for a successful 
procedure. 

Moving forward, please note the following:
- New medications: Clopidogrel 75mg daily, atorvastatin 80mg 
daily
- Changed medications: Aspirin 81mg (decreased dose)
- Stopped medications: Simvastatin
- Please weigh yourself every morning, and call your 
cardiologist if your weight goes up more than 3 lbs in a day, or 
more than 5lbs in a week.
- We would recommend cardiac rehabilitation post-discharge.

We wish you the best,
Your ___ care team

___
 

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 78-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with chest pain. He has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). He was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) related to in-stent restenosis in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. The patient underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and was prescribed medications including Plavix, heparin, and nitroglycerin.

The patient has a history of multiple stents placed in the RCA and LAD arteries, as well as balloon angioplasty of a totally occluded RCA. He has also had a cardiac catheterization procedure in the past, which showed multi-vessel disease and multiple everolimus-eluting stents were placed.

The patient's allergies include shellfish, and he has a history of anginal symptoms, which are usually relieved with rest. He has used sublingual nitroglycerin several times in the past 9 months.

The patient's physical examination was normal, with no signs of distress or discomfort. His laboratory results showed elevated troponin levels, indicating myocardial infarction. He was discharged with medications and instructions to follow up with his cardiologist.

The patient is a 47-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for a robotic-assisted total laparoscopic hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy due to complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. She has a history of sleep apnea, hypercholesterolemia, hypokalemia, vitamin D deficiency, and a left rotator cuff tear. She also has a family history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia.

The patient's presenting symptoms included menometrorrhagia, and she underwent endometrial biopsy in the office, which revealed secretory endometrium and a likely polyp. She subsequently underwent hysteroscopy and D&C, which revealed multiple polyps and EIN arising in one of the polyps.

The patient's diagnosis is endometrial intra-epithelial neoplasia, with final pathology pending. She underwent a major surgical procedure, including robotic-assisted laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and lysis of adhesions.

At discharge, the patient was prescribed several medications, including ibuprofen, oxycodone-acetaminophen, docusate sodium, and losartan potassium. She was also advised to follow certain instructions, including taking her medications as prescribed, not driving while taking narcotics, and not combining narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.

The patient's discharge condition was good, with a clear and coherent mental status, alert and interactive level of consciousness, and ambulatory status.

started on a bowel regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake

are recovering well and are now ready for discharge. Please 
follow the instructions below to continue your recovery:

General Surgery:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.

or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.

bowel movement.

urine, or experience a discharge.

within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.

Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

medications.

discharge_summary:
The patient is an 89-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with severe lower abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, chronic diastolic heart failure, diabetes type II, asbestosis, essential tremor, knee osteoarthrosis, esophagus, colonic adenoma, obesity, vit B12 deficiency, and BPH with nocturia. He has allergies to morphine and penicillins. 

The patient underwent laparoscopic converted to open cholecystectomy for chronic cholecystitis. His physical examination on admission showed normal vital signs, and his physical examination on discharge showed him to be well appearing, afebrile, and with stable vital signs. 

The patient was prescribed the following medications at discharge: acetaminophen, cyanocobalamin, diltiazem, doxazosin, fluorouracil, furosemide, metformin, metoprolol, omeprazole, rivaroxaban, and triamcinolone. He was discharged home with services and instructed to follow up with his doctor or nurse practitioner if he experiences any new symptoms.

laboratory monitoring required

Personal Care:
1. Remove dressings and discard. Dressings may be replaced as 
needed. Use tape sparingly.
2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the 
skin, with hydrogen peroxide.
3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___ 
times per day.
4. A written record of the daily output from each drain should 
be brought to every follow-up appointment. your drains will be 
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to 
an acceptable amount.
5. You may shower daily, cover the wound and drain with seran 
wrap. shower with assistance as needed.

days.
9. No pressure on your chest or abdomen
10. Okay to shower, but no baths until after directed by your 
surgeon
.
Activity:
1. You may resume your regular diet.  Avoid caffeine and 
chocolate.
2. DO NOT drive for 3 weeks.
3. Sternal precautions
4. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity for 6 weeks following surgery.
5. Please perform the occupational/physical therapy exercises as 
instructed.
.
Medications:
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered .
2. No NSAIDs for one week. You may resume your baby aspirin 
seven days after discharge from the hospital.
3. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain.  You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength 
Tylenol for mild pain as directed on the packaging.  Please note 
that Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient 
so do not take these meds with additional Tylenol.
4. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol.
5. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.
6. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softerner if you wish.
7. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.
.
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
welling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s).
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s).
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.
.
Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness,swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you.
.
DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain and strip the drain at the same 
time each day. Pull the stopper out of the drainage bottle and 
empty the drainage fluid into the measuring cup. Record the 
amount of drainage fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain 
suction.
 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
discharge_summary:
Mrs. [Name], a 72-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital for a sternal wound infection. She had a history of CABGx3 and was previously treated for sternal wound infection with debridement and antibiotics. She was readmitted for upper pole incisional cellulitis and IV antibiotics. A CT scan showed significant inflammation in the manubrial area and poor healing suggestive of early osteomyelitis. She underwent sternal debridement and bilateral upper pectoralis clavicular head muscle advancement flap with removal of 3 sternal wires. She was started on IV nafcillin and ciprofloxacin, and her wound culture came back positive for MSSA. She was discharged on IV nafcillin and close follow-up with Dr. [Attending].

The patient's past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic renal insufficiency, anemia, obesity, COPD, hypothyroidism, and osteoporosis. She has a history of abdominal surgery for perforated ulcer, right knee surgery, and hysterectomy with bladder resuspension.

The patient's medications at discharge include ezetimibe, levothyroxine, ranitidine, rosuvastatin, aspirin, docusate sodium, magnesium oxide, acetaminophen, lisinopril, amlodipine, clonidine, ipratropium-albuterol, oxycodone, metoprolol tartrate, furosemide, and nafcillin. She is also scheduled for weekly lab work, including Cr, BUN, T bili, Alt, Ast, Alk ph, wbc, Hct/Hgb.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old female who was admitted for a known large hepatic cyst with progressive shortness of breath over the past year. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, urinary incontinence, spinal fusion, ovarian cysts, and osteoporosis. She is allergic to Cipro and Macrodantin.

The patient underwent a laparoscopic converted to open hepatic cyst unroofing, cholecystectomy, and repair of diaphragm with Gore-Tex patch, as well as ERCP. The cyst was benign and contained approximately 3 liters of clear fluid. The patient developed a bile leak and pancreatitis post-operatively, which was managed with a biliary stent and conservative treatment.

The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including acetaminophen, oxycodone, atenolol, simvastatin, fluticasone-salmeterol, docusate sodium, solifenacin, alendronate, calcium, and multivitamin. She was also advised to follow up with her doctor and to monitor her incision for redness, drainage, or bleeding.

The patient was discharged home with a JP drain still in place and was advised to follow up with her doctor for further treatment and management of her condition.

Discharge Diagnosis:
A polyp of the ascending colon

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after a Laparoscopic Right 
Colectomy for surgical management of your polyp. You have 
recovered from this procedure well and you are now ready to 
return home. Samples of tissue were taken and this tissue has 
been sent to the pathology department for analysis. You will 
receive these pathology results at your follow-up appointment. 
If there is an urgent need for the surgeon to contact you 
regarding these results they will contact you before this time. 
You have tolerated a regular diet, are passing gas and your pain 
is controlled with pain medications by mouth. You may return 
home to finish your recovery.  
 
Please monitor your bowel function closely. You may or may not 
have had a bowel movement prior to your discharge which is 
acceptable, however it is important that you have a bowel 
movement in the next ___ days. After anesthesia it is not 
uncommon for patientÂs to have some decrease in bowel function 
but you should not have prolonged constipation. Some loose stool 
and passing of small amounts of dark, old appearing blood are 
expected. However, if you notice that you are passing bright red 
blood with bowel movements or having loose stool without 
improvement please call the office or go to the emergency room 
if the symptoms are severe. If you are taking narcotic pain 
medications there is a risk that you will have some 
constipation. Please take an over the counter stool softener 
such as Colace, and if the symptoms do not improve call the 
office.

If you have any of the following symptoms please call the office 
for advice ___: 
fever greater than 101.5
increasing abdominal distension
increasing abdominal pain 
nausea/vomiting
inability to tolerate food or liquids
prolonged loose stool
extended constipation  
inability to urinate

Incisions:
You have ___ laparoscopic surgical incisions on your abdomen 
which are closed with internal sutures. These are healing well 
however it is important that you monitor these areas for signs 
and symptoms of infection including: increasing redness of the 
incision lines, white/green/yellow/malodorous drainage, 
increased pain at the incision, increased warmth of the skin at 
the incision, or swelling of the area.

You may shower; pat the incisions dry with a towel, do not rub. 
The small incisions may be left open to the air. If closed with 
steri-strips (little white adhesive strips), these will fall off 
over time, please do not remove them. Please no baths or 
swimming until cleared by the surgical team. 

Pain
It is expected that you will have pain after surgery and this 
pain will gradually improved over the first week or so you are 
home. You will especially have pain when changing positions and 
with movement. You should continue to take 2 Extra Strength 
Tylenol (___) for pain every 8 hours around the clock and you 
may also take Advil (Ibuprofen) 600mg every hours for 7 days. 
Please do not take more than 3000mg of Tylenol in 24 hours or 
any other medications that contain Tylenol such as cold 
medication. Do not drink alcohol while or Tylenol. Please take 
Advil with food. If these medications are not controlling your 
pain to a point where you can ambulate and preform minor tasks, 
you should take a dose of the narcotic pain medication 
Oxycodone. Please take this only if needed for pain. Do not take 
with any other sedating medications or alcohol. Do not drive a 
car if taking narcotic pain medications. 

Activity
You may feel weak or "washed out" for up to 6 weeks after 
surgery. No heavy lifting greater than a gallon of milk for 3 
weeks. You may climb stairs. You may go outside and walk, but 
avoid traveling long distances until you speak with your 
surgical team at your first follow-up visit. Your surgical team 
will clear you for heavier exercise and activity as the observe 
your progress at your follow-up appointment. You should only 
drive a car on your own if you are off narcotic pain medications 
and feel as if your reaction time is back to normal so you can 
react appropriately while driving. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

The patient is a 60-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for a laparoscopic right colectomy due to a right cecal polyp. She has a history of anxiety, benign hematuria, hypertension, normal pap smear, obesity, stress incontinence, tubal ligation, right knee mass, cystocele, stage III CKD, right renal cyst, and ? type colon polyp, ? gastritis, dysplastic colon polyp, and colonic polyps. She has no known allergies or adverse drug reactions.

The patient's diagnosis is a polyp of the ascending colon. She underwent a laparoscopic right colectomy and was discharged home with instructions to monitor her bowel function closely and to report any symptoms such as fever, increasing abdominal distension, increasing abdominal pain, nausea/vomiting, inability to tolerate food or liquids, prolonged loose stool, or extended constipation.

The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including oxycodone for pain, acetaminophen for pain, amlodipine for hypertension, atenolol for hypertension, clonazepam for anxiety, lisinopril for hypertension, ranitidine for gastritis, and zolpidem tartrate for sleep.

The patient was advised to take an over-the-counter stool softener such as Colace if she experiences constipation while taking narcotic pain medications. She was also advised to monitor her incisions for signs of infection and to avoid heavy lifting, baths, or swimming until cleared by the surgical team.

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female who was admitted for exertional angina and progressive dyspnea on exertion. She has a history of multiple medical problems, including diet-controlled type II diabetes, hypertension, chronic joint pain, and recent visual problems. She has had recent complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath, which have been worsening over time. She underwent right and left cardiac catheterization, which showed mild LVH with preserved ejection fraction. She was diagnosed with coronary artery disease and underwent cardiac catheterization to evaluate for left main disease prior to surgery. At discharge, she was prescribed medications and advised to follow up with her cardiologist.

Relevant past medical history includes spinal stenosis, fibromyalgia/polymyalgia rheumatica, hypertension, osteoarthritis, depression, and s/p bilateral oopherectomy. She has allergies to Aspirin, Ultram, Vioxx, Percocet, Vicodin, and Cephalexin.

The patient's physical examination revealed a slightly distant S1, S2 with no appreciable M/R/G, and no chest wall deformities, scoliosis, or kyphosis. Her abdomen was soft, non-tender, and non-distended, and her extremities showed non-pitting 1+ lower extremity edema, symmetric, and no calf tenderness.

Pertinent lab results include a glucose level of 153* on admission and 133* at discharge, with a normal white blood cell count and platelet count. Her chest X-ray showed lower lung volumes and fullness of indistinct pulmonary vessels consistent with elevated pulmonary venous pressure.

discharge_summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male who was admitted for aortic stenosis and coronary artery disease. He had been experiencing symptoms of dizziness and exertional dyspnea over the past few months. His past medical history includes aortic stenosis, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic bronchitis, polymyalgia rheumatica, prostate cancer, gout, and osteoarthritis.

The patient underwent a left heart catheterization, coronary angiogram, and left ventriculogram, which showed severe aortic valve stenosis and mild aortic regurgitation. He also had complex atheroma in the descending thoracic aorta. The patient underwent aortic valve replacement and coronary artery bypass grafting, and his post-operative course was uneventful.

The patient was discharged on day 5 with medications including alendronate, Symbicort, colchicine, ipratropium-albuterol, metoprolol succinate, prednisone, simvastatin, tiotropium bromide, sulfacetamide sodium, aspirin, and cyanocobalamin. He was advised to shower daily, avoid baths or swimming, and not to apply lotions or creams to his incisions. He was also instructed to weigh himself daily and take his temperature in the evening.

History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ right-handed man with a history of
prostate CA s/p radiation, hyperlipidemia, cervical spine
disease, and longstanding tobacco use who presents with left
sided weakness and incoordination over the last 10 days. He
reports that he had "the flu" about 6 weeks ago with URI 
symptoms
and muscle aches. This resolved, but then about 2 weeks ago he
began to have muscle aches again that felt very similar. These
started in his left quadriceps and then spread over the next
several days to involve his bilateral quadriceps, calves, and
triceps as well. He saw his PCP ___ ___ for his annual physical
and then again on ___ due to the persistent myalgias. At that
point he had also begun to experience intermittent vertigo as
well. This was only present with movement such as turning his
head or standing up to walk and resolved completely at rest. He
describes it as a brief sensation of spinning or movement 
lasting
seconds. CK and ESR were checked due to the myalgias and were
negative. His vertigo was felt to be most likely peripheral.
Basic labs were all normal and he was advised to monitor his
symptoms. 

However over the next week his vertigo persisted, still only
brought on by movement, and he also began to notice weakness in
his left arm and leg. He initially attributed this to the muscle
aches, which ultimately resolved on the right but have still
persisted a little in his left quad and triceps. However over 
the
last week he has also noticed that it is more difficult to
control his left arm and leg. He says they feel weak but also
clumsy, and his arm "flops around" when he tries to use it. His
wife says he also veers toward the left when he walks, and his
left leg has "given out" on him a couple of times. He has fallen
twice in the last week, once when getting out of the car and 
then
again yesterday when he was trying to help his wife make up the
bed. Both times his left leg just seemed to buckle and he fell 
to
the ground, sustaining some scrapes but no significant injuries.
Last night he was playing cards with his friends, which he has
done for ___ years, and realized that he couldn't hold the cards
or shuffle with his left hand. At this point he became 
concerned,
as he says one of his other friends in the group had a stroke a
few years ago with very similar symptoms. He therefore went back
to Dr. ___ this morning, and on exam he was found to
have left sided weakness and ataxia and was sent to the ED for
further evaluation.

In addition he also reports one episode of headache last week on
___, around the time that he first noticed the left sided
weakness. He describes the headache as bifrontal pressure with 
no
other associated symptoms. This was a bit unusual for him as he
does not typically get headaches but it resolved on its own and
has not recurred. He also noticed brief blurring of vision in 
his
left eye around the same time which also lasted for about a day
and then resolved. He denies any diplopia or loss of vision. He
reports that he has chronic tingling in his left arm and hand 
due
to an ulnar nerve injury many years ago, but this has seemed a
bit more prominent lately than usual. He denies any numbness or
tingling in his face or leg. He denies any problems with his
speech.

dysarthria,

difficulties producing or comprehending speech. No bowel or
bladder incontinence or retention.

chills (since his flu-like illness 6 weeks ago).  No night 
sweats
or recent weight loss or gain. Denies cough, shortness of 
breath.
Denies chest pain or tightness, palpitations.  Denies nausea,
vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain.  No recent
change in bowel or bladder habits.  No dysuria.  Denies
arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rash.
