- NON-CONTRAST HEAD CT (___): Findings concerning for multiple 
intracranial lesions which raises suspicion for metastatic 
disease.  Correlate with history of malignancy. MRI would be 
helpful for further evaluation. 

- CTA HEAD/NECK (___):  
1. Three distinct heterogeneously-enhancing parenchymal lesions, 
with cystic necrosis, within the superior cerebellar vermis, and 
the left frontal and parietal lobe, worrisome for metastatic 
disease. No intraparenchymal hemorrhage. 
2. Mild effacement of the left ambient cistern. 
3. 2.7 cm soft tissue mass within the azygos lobe with an 
associated 3.2 cm necrotic precarinal lymph node which may 
represent primary bronchogenic neoplasm with metastatic 
lymphadenopathy. 
4. Patent vasculature. No aneurysm, dissection, or stenosis. 

- MRI BRAIN W/WO GAD (___): 
1. Hemorrhagic metastases in the left superior frontal and left 
medial 
occipital regions, which may be leptomeningeal or superficial 
cortical, 
without significant mass effect. Punctate left superior frontal 
cortical 
metastasis adjacent to the larger left frontal metastasis. 
2. Hemorrhagic metastases in the left superior cerebellar vermis 
and left 
cerebellar hemisphere. The dominant metastasis in the left 
cerebellar vermis effaces the left ambient cistern with 
deformation of the left inferior colliculus. It also partially 
effaces the fourth ventricle without obstructive hydrocephalus. 
3. 4 mm enhancing lesion in the superior right aspect of the 
occipital bone, corresponding to a lytic lesion with erosion of 
the outer table on the prior CT, indicating an osseous 
metastasis. 
  
COMMENT: The appearance of the intracranial and calvarial 
lesions is more suggestive of metastatic disease from the right 
apical pulmonary mass seen on the preceding CTA, than from 
prostate cancer, but tissue diagnosis is needed. 

CT ___ W CONTRAST (___):  
1. Multiple enlarged low-attenuation mediastinal lymph nodes and 
right hilar lymph node. A 1.4 cm subpleural nodule in the right 
upper lobe. Adjacent to/contiguous with the necrotic right upper 
paratracheal lymph node. Multiple pulmonary nodules identified 
measuring up to 5 mm. Findings are suspicious of pulmonary and 
nodal metastases. The mediastinal lymph nodes are amenable for 
biopsy via bronchoscopy. 
2. A 1.5 cm and 1.6 cm hypodense lesions in segment 2 and 4B 
nonspecific but suspicious for hepatic metastasis, especially 
segment 4B lesion. 
3. 3.5 cm solid lesion identified posterior to the left psoas 
muscle, 
suspicious for metastasis. This lesion is amenable for biopsy 
under CT 
guidance, if necessary. 
4. Enlarged necrotic lymph nodes at the left external iliac and 
left common iliac chain, suspicious for nodal metastases. 
5. Cholelithiasis. Small hiatal hernia. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo RH M with a history of prostate CA s/p radiation, 
hyperlipidemia, cervical spine disease, and tobacco use who 
presents with left sided weakness and incoordination over the 
last 10 days. In the ED, head CT showed 3 lesions with central 
hemorrhage/necrosis and vasogenic edema in the left frontal 
lobe, left parietal lobe, and most notably in the left 
cerebellar vermis coming close to impinging on the ___ 
ventricle, with no hydrocephalus. CTA head/neck incidentally 
revealed a mass in the right upper lung with adjacent necrotic 
lymph nodes. The findings were highly concerning for metastatic 
cancer. 

# HOSPITAL COURSE: He was admitted to the Neurology service for 
further workup. MRI brain confirmed presence of hemorrhagic 
metastases in the left frontal and parietal lobes and left 
cerebellar hemisphere with small amount of vasogenic edema. CT 
torso revealed multiple lesions concerning for metastatic cancer 
-- enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes, 1.4cm RUL nodule and 
multiple other pulmonary nodules, 2 liver lesions, solid lesion 
posterior to the left psoas, and enlarged necrotic left iliac 
lymph nodes. Given his smoking history and distribution of the 
lesions, findings were highly suspicious for metastatic lung 
cancer. 

The next day an endobronchial biopsy of the right lung and LNs 
was obtained by Interventional Pulmonology (results pending on 
discharge). Hematology-Oncology, Neuro-Oncology, Neurosurgery 
and Radiation Oncology services consulted for workup and 
planning. Given the size of the cerebellar mass and its close 
proximity to the ___ ventricle, it was felt that patient would 
need whole brain radiation (fractionated radiotherapy to the 
area would cause too much swelling and thus hydrocephalus, and 
surgical resection would be unsafe given his age and 
comorbidities). After much debate, it was decided that he needed 
EVD placed before beginning whole brain XRT since risk for 
subsequent edema and hydrocephalus was still high. This will be 
performed one week after discharge, on ___ -- 
patient will be called beforehand with time and name of 
neurosurgeon doing the procedure. Following EVD placement, he 
will see Radiation Oncology (Dr. ___ in clinic to begin 
planning for whole-brain radiation. They anticipate beginning 
XRT one week after surgery in order to allow superficial wound 
healing. 

Patient was started on Dexamethasone 4mg qAM (with GI 
prophylaxis) in the hospital for additional for additional 
protection against vasogenic edema. He was also given oxycodone 
on discharge for left hip pain caused by metastases to the area, 
which cause him significant discomfort. 

At the time of discharge, results of the lung biopsy are still 
pending. Once they return, Heme-Onc will coordinate follow up 
and planning for systemic therapy in the appropriate clinic 
(most likely Thoracic Oncology, given high suspicion that this 
is lung cancer). 

Patient was seen by Social Work in the hospital to address 
coping with his new diagnosis and for assistance obtaining 
long-term disability and transportation to future appointments 
at ___. 

====================
TRANSITIONS OF CARE:
- Studies pending = lung biopsy from ___ (to be followed up by 
Heme Onc)
- Needs to be called by Neurosurgery and Rad Onc departments to 
schedule EVD placement and XRT planning in next week

Dear Mr. ___, 

You were admitted to the hospital for new clumsiness and 
weakness on the left side of your body. An MRI of your brain 
showed 3 masses concerning for metastatic cancer, one of which 
was in an area called the CEREBELLUM and carries a high risk for 
causing brain cancer (HYDROCEPHALUS). A subsequent CT scan of 
your torso showed masses in your lymph nodes, lungs and liver 
also concerning for cancer. A lung biopsy was performed, results 
pending. 

The next step in your care will be to start whole brain 
radiation. Before this, you will need a ventriculo-peritoneal 
(VP) shunt. This will be done on ___. You will 
be called by the Neurosurgery apartment with the name of the 
surgeon who will perform the operation and the time of surgery. 

Approximately 3 days after shunt placement, you should attend 
your follow-up appointment with Radiation Oncology. They will 
coordination your radiation plan, as well as your follow-up 
appointments with Neuro-Oncology (___). You will be 
called by them to schedule this appointment in the next few 
days.

You are scheduled for an outpatient with Medical Oncology (Dr. 
___ on ___ to discuss the results of your lung 
biopsy, which should have returned by them. See below for more 
info. They will plan your systemic therapy (chemotherapy and/or 
radiation) once the lung biopsy results have returned. 

We made the following changes to your medications: 
1. STARTED Dexamethasone (Decadron) 4mg by mouth in AM -- this 
is to treat swelling of the brain due to cancer. 
2. STARTED Famotidine 20mg twice daily -- this is to prevent 
acid reflux caused by Decadron. 
3. STARTED Oxycodone 2.5-5mg every 6 hrs as needed for pain -- 
side effects include nausea and constipation. Can take over the 
counter laxative as needed.
4. STARTED Ondansetron (Zofran) 4mg every 8 hrs as needed for 
nausea -- if experienced as side effect of oxycodone.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male who presented with left-sided weakness and incoordination over the last 10 days. He has a history of prostate cancer, hyperlipidemia, cervical spine disease, and longstanding tobacco use. He reports having had "the flu" six weeks ago, which resolved, but then began to experience muscle aches again, which spread to his bilateral quadriceps, calves, and triceps. He also noticed intermittent vertigo, which was felt to be most likely peripheral. His weakness and incoordination progressed, and he began to experience difficulty controlling his left arm and leg, which felt weak and clumsy. He has fallen twice in the last week and has noticed that his left leg has "given out" on him. 

The patient was found to have left-sided weakness and ataxia on examination and was sent to the emergency department for further evaluation. He also reports one episode of headache last week, which resolved on its own, and brief blurring of vision in his left eye, which also resolved. 

The patient's past medical history includes hyperlipidemia, prostate cancer, cervical disc herniation, and longstanding tobacco use. He has a family history of brain cancer and stroke. 

On physical examination, the patient was found to have normal vital signs, and his neurological examination revealed normal mental status, cranial nerves, and sensation, but decreased sensation in the left ulnar distribution. He had significant dysmetria on left finger-nose-finger and heel-knee-shin testing, and his gait was mildly wide-based. 

The patient was diagnosed with [insert diagnosis], and he was prescribed [insert medications] at discharge.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with h/o HTN, diabetes, and asthma presents with cough, sore

# Airway swelling: Patient given decadron, diphenhydramine and 
famotidine at OSH for concern of angioedema and upper airway 
swelling, transferred here for ENT and anesthesia evaluation 
should intubation be required. Receieved nebulized racemic 
epinephrine in the ED here. Upon arrival to the MICU the patient 
was subjectively improved. The etiology of his angioedema was 
unclear, but there was concern for contribution of symptoms from 
ACEi. As a result, his ACEi was discontinued while in the MICU, 
and was not restarted upon discharge. He was treated with 
steroids, benadryl, and famotidine. ENT evaulation on the 
morning of discharge revealed resolution of edema and he was 
discharged home from the MICU. 

# Cough/Rhinorrhea: Patient's complaints of cough and rhinorrhea 
recently were most likely due to URI. CXR was without evidence 
of PNA. He was treated with saline nasal spray while in the 
MICU. 

# Tachycardia: Likely in the acute setting of receiving IV 
steroids and epinephrine. Appears to be sinus tachycardia on 
monitor. Troponin from the ED was negative.

# Asthma: Upon arrival to the MICU he was noted to have diffuse 
wheezes on exam. He was given Albuterol nebulizers as needed.

# Diabetes: No active issues. He was discharged on his home dose 
of metformin. 

# HTN: Lisinopril was discontinued upon arrival to the MICU. His 
blood pressure remained within the normal range. He was not 
restarted on any additional anti-hypertensive medications prior 
to discharge.

- Patient will likely need treatment with alternative 
antihypertensive medication, given discontinuation of 
lisinopril. MICU team elected to defer to PCP on this decision.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

 It was a pleasure taking care of you during your 
hospitalization.  You were admitted because of swelling in your 
throat (angioedema) that was causing difficulty breathing.  You 
were admitted to the Medical Intensive Care Unit so we could 
closely monitor your breathing.  You did very well overnight and 
were treated with steroids, benadryl, and famotidine 
(anti-histamines) which helped to reduce the swelling.  We think 
this swelling was a side effect of your lisinopril.  You should 
not take lisinopril or other medicines in this class (ACE 
inhibitors) ever again as the swelling could happen again 
causing difficulty breathing.  You will need to talk to your PCP 
about starting ___ different blood pressure medicine.  You should 
also talk to your PCP about seeing an Allergy specialist to 
determine if there is another reason for the swelling you had.
  You were also wheezing when you were admitted.  This was 
because of your asthma.  You improved after a treatment with 
albuterol.  Your asthma can be better controlled if you take 
your Flovent inhaler every day - this helps control asthma 
symptoms.  We will give you a prescription for an albuterol 
inhaler that you should only use when you are having symptoms 
from your asthma.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

discharge_summary: The patient is a 49-year-old male who presented to the hospital with a chief complaint of throat swelling. He has a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension. He was taking lisinopril for hypertension, but it was discontinued during his hospital stay due to concerns about its potential contribution to his angioedema. The patient's symptoms included a sensation of throat swelling, rhinorrhea, and a cough productive of whitish sputum. He was treated with steroids, benadryl, and famotidine, and his angioedema resolved. He was also diagnosed with asthma and treated with albuterol nebulizers as needed. The patient was discharged home with a diagnosis of angioedema and asthma, and was prescribed medications including diphenhydramine, famotidine, prednisone, albuterol inhaler, fluticasone propionate, and metformin.

Patient is a ___ F with history of schistosomiasis cirrhosis

Hepatologist for acute renal failure. Patient was recently

HEENT: Sclera slightly icteric. PERRL, EOMI.

LUNGS: Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use, moving air 
well and symmetrically. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi.  
ABDOMEN: Distended but Soft, non-tender to palpation. Dullness 
to percussion over dependent areas but tympanic anteriorly.

Moderate to severe pulmonary edema.  Retrocardiac opacity may 
represent atelectasis and/or consolidation. 

ECG: NSR, normal axis, no ST changes, nl QRS and PR intervals.

TTE ___
The left atrium is mildly dilated. Left ventricular wall 
thickness, cavity size and regional/global systolic function are 
normal (LVEF >55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall 
motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, 
ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets 
(3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No 
aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are 
mildly thickened. Mild to moderate (___) mitral regurgitation 
is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. 
There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There 
is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion. 

 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a ___ F with history of schistosomiasis cirrhosis 
c/b diuretic refractory ascites, portal hypertension and 
encephalopathy currently on transplant list, IDDM, HTN and HLD 
who was directly admitted from home for acute renal failure.
  
# Acute Renal Failure: Baseline Cr < 1.5. Admitted with 
creatinine of 2.0, FeNa on admission 0.28% indicating pre-renal 
state. No evidence of infection on admission without fevers, 
chills, nausea, vomiting, suprapubic tenderness or dysuria, UA 
with epis and does not indicate UTI. Patient received albumin 
1g/kg (62.5grams) on HD 1 and morning after creatinine improved 
to 1.7. On HD 2 H/H was low so instead of albumin patient was 
volume challenged with 1 unit PRBCs and 25grams of albumin (1 
unit PRBCs=25 grams albumin). Diagnostic paracentesis ruled out 
SBP. Creatinine worsened after initial volume challenge and did 
not respond to second round of 1g/kg albumin. After failed 
improvement diagnosis of hepatorenal synrome was made and 
midodrine/octreotide were started and uptitrated without 
improvement in creatinine.  Cr steadily continued to rise, 
patient became oliguric and was volume overloaded.  The renal 
team was consulted.  Initially, plan was for pt to have HD line 
placed in ___ and start dialysis.  However, given active bleeding 
(see below), she was trasferred to SICU and started on CVVH.
       
# Cirrhosis: Chronic, related to schistosomiasis complicated by 
diuretic refractory ascites, chronic renal failure, portal 
hypertension, thrombocytopenia, prior SBP and encephalopathy. 
MELD 20 on admission with Childs Class C. Without evidence of 
encephalopathy, hepatic decompensation or asterixis on 
admission. Continued Rifaximin 550mg PO BID and Lactulose TID 
for HE prophylaxis. Continued Ciprofloxacin for SBP prophylaxis. 
Diagnostic paracentesis was performed and ruled out SBP. No GI 
endoscopy in our system but patient being evaluated for 
transplant, cannot be on transplant list without endoscopy so 
presumably completed somewhere. MELD rose to >30 in setting of 
hepatorenal syndrome and patient was listed for ABO incompatible 
liver. As HRS progressed, MELD score was at 40 on transfer to 
the SICU.

# Pulmonary edema: Pt w/ pulm edema on CXR on ___ and mildly 
symptomatic. Initially, pt subjectively some SOB, but O2 low to 
mid ___ on RA.  After 2 days, developed O2 requirement.  
Overload most likely in the setting of rapidly deteriorating 
renal function.  Less likely cirrhosis induced cardiomyopathy.  
Last TTE ___ with normal EF.  Repeat TTE with still normal EF 
but new moderate PA systolic HTN. Attempted to diurese with 
Lasix 20 iv then 80, put out very small amt of urine, 
incontinent.   In setting of rapidly progressive HRS, pt became 
oliguric and was unable to mobilize fluid.  Plan was made for 
dialysis as above.

# Hard palate bleed:  On ___ at ~6am, pt developed bleed right 
hard palate.  This was likely ___ mild oral trauma in the 
setting of coagulopathy--INR 3.6, platelets 75.  Initially, 
attempted to stop by applying pressure, unsuccessful.  Per 
discussion with ENT and OMFS, attempted to stop the bleed with 
afrin soaked gauze, topical thrombin, silver nitrate, 
aminocaproic acid.  Also transfused with platelets, FFP, and 
RBCs (as hct was 22 down from 25 at last check). Held continuous 
pressure for ~3 hours.  As soon as pressure was released, active 
bleeding was visualized.  Tamponaded bleed for ~10 minutes, but 
again continued to have uncontrollable bleed and was transferred 
to SICU on the transplant surgery service for elective 
intubation and packing.  The lesion was cauterized and the 
bleeding was controlled.  She was initially successfully 
extubated at transferred to the floor. 

# Hyponatremia: Hypervolumic hyponatremia from cirrhosis. Did 
not diurese patient given ___. Albumin and PRBCs given for 
intravascular volume and patient kept on 1.5L fluid restricted 
diet. She remained hyponatremic so fluid restricted further to 
1.2L with improvement in Na.
    
# Acute anemia: Patient with chronic anemia related to cirrhosis 
though with acute drop on HD 2. Unclear etiology without GIB 
during admission. Unknown if patient has varices without 
endoscopy in our system and is not on beta-blocker so presumably 
none on prior endoscopy. Possible hct drop was in setting of 
volume challenge overnight and dilutional effect though WBC and 
platelets unchanged. She was transfused 1 unit PRBCs both for 
anemia and volume challenge. Hct remained stable following 
transfusion.
     
# DM: Insulin Dependent, Type II. Hyperglycemic during admissin. 
Continued Glargine 12 units qHS and HISS
    
# HLD: Chronic, stable, continue zetia 
   
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
- Continue holding diuretics
- Recommend tracking down endoscopy report, unknown where 
completed

ICU Course ___ to ___, date of death)
Ms ___ was transferred to the surgical ICU the morning of 
___ after developing worsening melena. She had an EGD the day 
prior for the purpose of Dobhoff feeding tube placement, and 
during that EGD a duodenal polyp was noted and biopsied. Of 
note, she had an INR of 2.5 and fibrinogen of 59 prior to the 
procedure so snare removal of the polyp was deferred. The 
evening following the EGD, she had several episodes of melena 
thus prompting transfer to the ICU to facilitate repeat emergent 
EGD. The EGD ___ showed a lot of old blood around the polyp, but 
no active bleed from the stalk. 
The first few days in the SICU she remained HD stable, but 
continued to have melena with an unstable hematocrit. We 
transfused RBC, FFP, platelets and cryo to goal Hct of 30 and 
correct her coagulopathy. We were unable to completely correct 
her, and she began having significant oral bleeding. By ___, 
she was coughing blood, had an increased oxygen requirement. She 
remained encephalopathic and was not protecting her airway 
sufficiently so she was intubated. After intubation she had a 
pressor requirement which remained until time of death. She was 
started on broad spectrum antibiotics (vanc/zosyn/mica) and a CT 
torso showed severe pneumonia with very little residual aerated 
lung volume. 
On ___ she was begun on CVVH for acidosis and had increased 
pressor requirement with the addition of vasopressin. We 
continued to transfuse RBC/FFP/cryo to maintain blood levels.
On ___ she had increased pressor requirement and markedly 
increased oral bleeding. It was estimated she bleed 600cc 
periorally this day. Transfusions continued and she remained on 
high dose levo/vaso, though her pressor requirement was slightly 
less than the day prior. A family meeting was held. It was 
decided she would not want to be on full life support for more 
than 5 days. As it had been 3 days to this point, we decided to 
make a final decision ___ unless she acutely worsened.
On ___, the day of her death, she acutely worsened during the 
day. She became hypotensive despite increasing her pressor 
doses. Melena and oral bleeding increased and she grew 
increasingly tachycardic. She was not responding hemodynamically 
to significant product transfusion, and her ventilator settings 
were increased with more oxygen needed. Another family meeting 
was held and we discussed that she was decompensating rapidly 
and likely had an unsurvivable condition. The family present was 
receptive and understanding. She was transitioned to comfort 
care at 7pm, though the endotracheal tube was left in to prevent 
aspirating blood which we felt would cause her too much 
discomfort. She was started on a morphine drip. Her heart rate 
and blood pressure gradually declined and asystole occured at 
9:28pm. She was declared at 9:30pm. The family declined an 
autopsy. 
 
Medications on Admission:
- Ciprofloxacin 250 mg daily.  
- Ezetimibe 10 mg Tablet PO DAILY  
- Insulin glargine Twelve (12) units SC QHS
- Humalog 100 unit/mL sliding scale
- Lactulose 10 gram/15 mL 30 ML PO TID 
- Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet PO Q12H 
- Rifaximin 550 mg Tablet PO BID 
- Calcium 500 + D (D3) Oral  
- Omega 3 Fish Oil Oral 
 
Discharge Medications:
Expired
 
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Expired
 
Discharge Condition:
Expired
 
Discharge Instructions:
N/A
 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 69-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for acute renal failure. She has a history of schistosomiasis cirrhosis, portal hypertension, and encephalopathy, and is currently on the transplant list. She was recently discharged from another hospital where she was admitted for abdominal distension, and was directly admitted to this hospital for acute renal failure. The patient's past medical history includes schistosomiasis complicated by cirrhosis and ascites, hypertension, IDDM, dyslipidemia, and nephrolithiasis.

The patient's allergies include aspirin. She has a history of bleeding, including a recent episode of hematochezia and melena, and has been diagnosed with hepatorenal syndrome. She has also been diagnosed with pulmonary edema and has required oxygen therapy.

The patient's medications at discharge include midodrine and octreotide for hepatorenal syndrome, and rifaximin and lactulose for prophylaxis against hepatic encephalopathy and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.

The patient underwent several procedures during her hospital stay, including a diagnostic paracentesis, which ruled out spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, and an EGD with feeding tube placement and duodenal polyp biopsy. She also underwent a TTE, which showed mild to moderate mitral regurgitation and moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated liver enzymes, including ALT, AST, and LDH, as well as elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase. Her creatinine level was elevated at 2.0 mg/dL, and her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level was elevated at 28 mg/dL. Her albumin level was low at 3.7 g/dL, and her calcium level was elevated at 9.8 mg/dL.

Overall, the patient's hospital course was complicated by her underlying liver disease and acute renal failure, and she required multiple interventions to manage her symptoms and stabilize her condition.

The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:

1. Urinary retention - POD1 foley removed and patient unable to 
void, straight cath x 1, failed voiding trial again, foley 
replaced POD1 eve and removed again on POD3, voising trial 
pending.

a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The patient 
received lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of 
POD#1.  The surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the 
surgical incision was found to be clean and intact without 
erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient was seen daily by 
physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital 
course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the 
patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well.  The 
patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The patient's 
hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on 
an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly 
intact and the wound was benign.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.

2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 

3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.

4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.

5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.

6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower starting five 
(5) days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at 
least four (4) weeks. No dressing is needed if wound continues 
to be non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need to be 
removed will be taken out at your follow-up visit in three (3) 
weeks after your surgery.

7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in three (3) weeks.

8. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, 
motrin, etc).

9. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your lovenox for four (4) 
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If 
you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to 
continue at your previous dose while taking this medication.  
___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS.

10. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up 
visit in three (3) weeks.

11. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, and wound checks.

12. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize. CPM/ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise 
or heavy lifting until follow up appointment.

Mobilize

Wound checks
Ice and elevation
TEDs

___

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female who was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service for a left total knee arthroplasty. She has a history of advancing osteoarthritis of the left knee, and has tried symptomatic treatment including injections and physical therapy without relief. Her past medical history includes hyperlipidemia, anxiety, depression, diabetes type II, colon cancer, benign thyroid nodule, and sciatica. She has no known allergies or adverse reactions.

The patient's diagnosis is left knee degenerative joint disease. She underwent an uncomplicated surgery and tolerated the procedure well. Her postoperative course was marked by urinary retention, which was managed with a foley catheter. She was also treated with lovenox for DVT prophylaxis and received pain medication as needed.

At discharge, the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well. Her vital signs were stable, and her hematocrit was acceptable. She was discharged to rehab with instructions to follow up with her primary physician and to resume her home medications unless otherwise instructed.

Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery

Lower Extremity Angiogram Discharge Instructions

Medications:
ÂIf instructed, take Aspirin once daily 
ÂIf instructed, take Plavix daily
ÂContinue all other medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
ÂYou make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any 
post procedure pain or discomfort

What to expect when you go home:
It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs:
ÂElevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night
ÂAvoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated
ÂIt is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your 
appetite will return with time 
ÂDrink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals
ÂIt is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
ÂTo avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

What activities you can and cannot do:
ÂWhen you go home, you may walk and go up and down stairs
ÂYou may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, 
rinse and pat dry)
ÂYour incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
band aid over the area that is draining, as needed
ÂNo heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 
1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal)
ÂAfter 1 week, you may resume sexual activity
ÂAfter 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance 
walked as you can tolerate
ÂNo driving until you are no longer taking pain medications
___ and schedule an appointment to be seen in ___ weeks for 
post procedure check and ultrasound 

What to report to office:
ÂNumbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities 
ÂTemperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
ÂNew or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or 
green drainage from incisions
ÂBleeding from groin puncture site

SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site)
ÂLie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm 
pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, ___ 
vascular office ___. If bleeding does not stop, ___ 
___ for transfer to closest Emergency Room. 

Wet to dry dressing changes

What to Expect at Home

Your doctor or nurse may ask you to change your dressing at 
home. By placing a wet (or moist) gauze dressing in your wound 
and allowing it to dry, wound drainage and dead tissue can be 
removed when you take off the old dressing. 

As the wound heals, you should not need as much gauze (or 
packing gauze). 

Removing the Old Dressing

Follow these steps to remove your dressing: 

Wash your hands. 
Put on a pair of non-sterile gloves. 
Carefully remove the tape. 
Remove the old dressing. If it is sticking to your skin, wet it 
with warm water to loosen it. 
Remove the gauze pads or packing tape from inside your wound. 
Put the old dressing, packing material, and your gloves in a 
plastic bag. Set the bag aside. 
Wash your hands again
Cleaning Your Wound

Follow these steps to clean your wound: 

Put on a new pair of non-sterile gloves. 

Use a soft washcloth to gently clean your wound with warm water 
and soap. Your wound should not bleed much when you are cleaning 
it, but a small amount of blood is okay. Rinse your wound with 
water, and gently pat it dry with a clean towel. Do not rub it 
dry. 

Check the wound for 

Increased redness or swelling 
A bad odor 
Drainage that is darker or thicker
After cleaning your wound, remove your gloves and put them in 
the plastic bag with the old dressing and gloves. 
Wash your hands again.

Changing Your Dressing

Follow these steps to put a new dressing on: 

Put on a new pair of non-sterile gloves. 
Pour saline into a clean bowl. Place gauze pads and any packing 
tape you will use in the bowl. 
Squeeze the saline from the gauze pads or packing tape until it 
is no longer dripping. 
Place the gauze pads or packing tape in your wound. 
Carefully fill in the wound and any spaces under the skin. 
Do not let the wet gauze or packing tape touch any healed skin.
Cover the wet gauze or packing tape with a large dry dressing 
pad. Use tape or rolled gauze to hold this dressing in place. 
Put all used supplies in the plastic bag. Close it securely, 
then put it in a second plastic bag, and close that bag 
securely. Put it in the trash. 

Wash your hands again when you are finished.

When to ___ the Doctor

___ your doctor if you have any of these changes around your 
incision: 

More redness 
More pain 
Swelling 
Bleeding 
The wound is larger or deeper 
The wound looks dried out or dark
Also ___ your doctor if: 

Your temperature is above 100 Â°F for more than 4 hours 
Drainage is coming from or around the incision or wound and it: 
Is not decreasing after 3 to 5 days 
Is increasing 
Becomes thick, tan, or yellow, or smells bad

 
Followup Instructions:
___

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a chief complaint of a right foot heel ulcer. He has a history of diabetes type 1, coronary artery disease, peripheral neuropathy, osteoarthritis, and gait disturbance. He was admitted for an angiogram with possible angioplasty and stenting. The patient underwent ultrasound-guided puncture of the left common femoral artery, contralateral second-order catheterization of the right external iliac artery, abdominal aortogram, and serial arteriogram of the right lower extremity. The patient's wound culture showed mixed bacterial types, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Staphylococcus aureus, and beta strep.

The patient's medications on admission included atenolol, plavix, furosemide, gabapentin, Lantus, Lispro/Humalog SSI, lisinopril, and simvastatin. At discharge, the patient was prescribed oxycodone-acetaminophen for pain, simvastatin, atenolol, clopidogrel, Lasix, gabapentin, aspirin, Lantus, Humalog, and dicloxacillin.

The patient's discharge diagnosis was a right heel ulcer and diabetic foot infection, as well as diabetes mellitus type 1, angina, coronary artery disease, peripheral neuropathy, osteoarthritis, and gait disturbance. The patient was advised to follow a specific regimen for wound care, including wet to dry dressing changes, and to report any signs of infection or complications to the office.

cavity size and regional/global systolic function are normal 
(LVEF >55%). There is no ventricular septal defect. Right 
ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The 
diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are 
normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal 
with good leaflet excursion and no aortic regurgitation. The 
mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral 
regurgitation. There is no mitral valve prolapse. The pulmonary 
artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is no 
pericardial effusion. 

Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, no 
change.  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ yo male who presented to ___ for acute 
chest pain at rest, was transferred for code STEMI with mild ST 
elevations in inferior leads and T wave inversions in 
anterolateral leads, and was found to have positive cardiac 
biomarkers and mild luminal irregularities in the coronaries on 
catheterization.  

ACTIVE ISSUES
-------------
# Chest pain/elevated troponin: Unclear etiology of pain, but 
unlikely to be coronary artery disease given that patient denies 
angina symptoms, only cardiovascular risk factor is remote 
tobacco use, and there is no evidence of coronary artery disease 
on catheterization. It is possible that polycythemia ___ could 
have precipitated thrombosis in a distal branch not noted on 
catheterization.  Vasospasm is also a possibility, but there is 
no report of cocaine abuse.  Takotsubo's cardiomyopathy was 
considered unlikely given normal left ventriculogram, and 
unlikely to be myocarditis given patient does not have symptoms 
of congestive heart failure and URI symptoms only started 2 days 
ago with a normal echocardiogram.  Another possibility could be 
pulmonary embolus as patient did have hypoxia on presentation, 
however patient was not tachycardic, Wells score was 0 and 
D-dimer was normal.  Cardiac biomarkers were trended, showing 
elevations in troponin and CK-MB, which were trending down at 
the time of discharge.  Patient was started on aspirin 325 mg 
daily and metoprolol succinate 25 mg daily.  Cardiac MR was 
ordered for outpatient workup to further delineate a cause of 
the patient symptoms and laboratory abnormalities.  He was chest 
pain free at the time of discharge.  Close follow-up was 
arranged with a cardiologist, as well as the patient's PCP.

prior history of heart disease.  Echocardiogram revealed no 
abnormalities in heart function.  
.  
# Heart rhythm: Patient was in normal sinus rhythm with 8 beats 
of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia overnight that was 
asymptomatic.  

# Polycythemia ___: patient is currently getting phlebotomy 
every 2 weeks.  He was arranged for outpatient hematology 
follow-up upon discharge.
  
TRANSITION OF CARE
------------------

Follow-up: patient will require a cardiac MR upon discharge, and 
is scheduled up for follow-up with cardiology.  His cholesterol 
panel returned after discharge and should be followed up by the 
outpatient cardiologist.   He will require follow-up with his 
outpatient hematologist for his polycythemia ___.  He also has 
scheduled follow-up with his PCP.

Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___.  You came for

You will require a cardiac MRI as an outpatient to further

Output:
discharge_summary: The patient is a 41-year-old male who presented with acute chest pain at rest. He has a history of polycythemia diagnosed two years ago, with a hematocrit of 56, and has been undergoing phlebotomy every two weeks. He has no known allergies or adverse reactions. The patient's presenting symptoms included chest pain that radiated to his throat, making it difficult to take a deep breath. He was found to have mild ST elevations in II, III, and aVF and dynamic TWI in V3-V6, and was given medication to manage his pain. In the cath lab, he was found to have clean coronaries and normal left ventricular function. The patient's diagnosis was no angiographically apparent flow-limiting coronary artery disease, normal ventricular function, elevated left-sided filling pressure, and no aortic stenosis. He was prescribed medications at discharge, including plavix, ASA, and morphine.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service on 
___ and taken to the Operating Room for L3-S1 interbody 
fusion through an anterior approach. Please refer to the 
dictated operative note for further details. The surgery was 
without complication and the patient was transferred to the PACU 
in a stable condition. TEDs/pnemoboots were used for 
postoperative DVT prophylaxis. Intravenous antibiotics were 
given per standard protocol. Initial postop pain was controlled 
with a PCA. On HD#2 she returned to the operating room for a 
scheduled T12-L3 decompression with PSIF as part of a staged 
2-part procedure. Please refer to the dictated operative note 
for further details. The second surgery was also without 
complication and the patient was transferred to the PACU in a 
stable condition. Postoperative HCT was stable. On HD#3 she 
returned for a scheduled T10-S1 posterior fusion with 
instrumentation.  A bupivicaine epidural pain catheter placed at 
the time of the posterior surgery remained in place until postop 
day one. 
She developed a post-operative ileus and an NG tube was placed.  
The ileuse was slowly resolving and NG tube was removed with 
diet advanced.  
She developed acute distension and was transferred to the TICU 
for monitoring. There, an NG tube was placed and her abdomen was 
decompressed.  CT scan showed no sign of blockage.
She was subsequently transferred out of the TICU and monitored.
She was kept NPO until bowel function returned then diet was 
advanced as tolerated. The patient was transitioned to oral pain 
medication when tolerating PO diet. Foley remained in place due 
to post-op urinary incontenance.  This will be managed by her 
PCP. She was fitted with a TLSO brace for ambulation. Physical 
therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate. Hospital 
course was otherwise unremarkable. On the day of discharge the 
patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, comfortable on 
oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet.

Immediately after the operation:
 

 
-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around.
 

 
-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery. You can walk as much as you can tolerate. 

 
oLimit any kind of lifting.
 

 
-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some constipation 
after surgery. You have been given medication to help with this 
issue.
 

 
-Brace: You have been given a brace. This brace is to be worn 
when you are walking. You may take it off when sitting in a 
chair or while lying in bed.
 

 
-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days. If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing. If it is dry then 
you can leave the incision open to the air. Once the incision is 
completely dry (usually ___ days after the operation) you may 
take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool. If 
the incision starts draining at anytime after surgery, do not 
get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile dressing. Call the 
office. 
 

 
-You should resume taking your normal ___ medications. No 
NSAIDs.
 

 
-You have also been given Additional Medications to control your 
pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead. You can either have them 
mailed to your ___ or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___ 2. We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.
 

 
Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.

Activity:   Activity:  Ambulate with brace

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for surgical intervention due to a long history of scoliosis. She presented with back pain and had previously attempted conservative treatment without success. The patient has a history of HLD, GERD, esophagus, asthma, migraines, scoliosis, anxiety, and mitral valve prolapse. She is allergic to Percocdan and nylon sutures.

The patient underwent three surgeries: L3-S1 anterior fusion, anterior fusion and decompression of T12-L3, and posterior decompression and fusion T9-S1 with instrumentation and bone graft. She developed a post-operative ileus and was treated with an NG tube and diet advancement. She also experienced acute distension and was transferred to the TICU for monitoring.

The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including oxycodone for pain management. She was advised to follow a normal healthy diet, take medication for constipation, and wear a TLSO brace for ambulation. She was also instructed to limit lifting, follow wound care instructions, and attend physical therapy sessions.

The patient's discharge diagnosis includes scoliosis, urinary incontinence, post-op ileus, and acute post-op blood loss anemia. Her discharge condition is good, and she was discharged with service.

patent right axillary to femoral bypass graft, with minimal soft 
tissue density and small locules of air surrounding the distal 
portion of the bypass graft at its femoral artery anastomotic 
site." A TEE was performed showed "a well-seated bi-leaflet 
mechanical aortic valve prosthesis with normal leaflet motion 
and gradients. No discrete vegetations." 

The patient was treated with piperacillin-tazobactam for 
coverage of S. anginosus and MSSA BSI as well as a polymicrobial 
wound infection. 

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin during 
this stay, and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as 
possible. 

On day of discharge, pt's BUN/creat =65/2.6, thought to be 
likely due to dehydration. IVF bolus was given with maintenance 
IVF to continue at rehab until creatinine trends down. PO fluids 
also encouraged. Lasix was discontinued and ___ should not be 
restarted until creatinine at baseline. VAC was also 
discontinued and  should continue on wet to dry BID until follow 
up. Foley was reinserted for urinary retention of approx 600 cc 
urine. Please attempt voiding trial in a day or so. 

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, 
voiding with foley, and pain was well controlled.

Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery
Lower Extremity Surgery Discharge Instructions

What to expect when you go home:
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
ÂYou should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
Âyou may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
ÂIncrease your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!

2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on:
ÂAvoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated

3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
ÂYou will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
ÂEat small frequent meals
ÂIt is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
ÂTo avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

What activities you can and cannot do:
ÂNo driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications
ÂYou should get up every day, get dressed and walk
ÂYou should gradually increase your activity
ÂYou may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car
ÂIncrease your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
ÂNo heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
ÂTake all the medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
ÂTake one full strength (325mg) enteric coated aspirin daily, 
unless otherwise directed 
Â
What to report to office:
ÂRedness that extends away from your incision
ÂA sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication
ÂA sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg
ÂTemperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours
ÂBleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 69-year-old male who was admitted with a right groin infection. He has a history of multiple medical problems, including a previous stroke, ascending aortic aneurysm, and severe hypertension. He was treated with antibiotics and instructed to follow up with vascular surgery, but his wound continued to worsen and he was readmitted to the hospital. 

The patient underwent several surgical procedures, including exploration of the right groin, control of the external iliac artery, and excision of the distal portion of the axillary-femoral bypass. He also underwent abdominal washout, packing removal, and temporary abdominal closure. 

The patient's diagnosis was a right groin infection, and he was found to have a polymicrobial infection including Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus anginosus, and Escherichia coli. He was prescribed antibiotics, including ceftriaxone, clindamycin, and gentamicin. 

The patient's medications at discharge included ceftriaxone, clindamycin, and gentamicin. He also had an allergy to oxycodone.

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male who presented with ankle swelling and drainage. He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, colon cancer, cirrhosis, and atrial fibrillation. He was previously admitted to another hospital for the same condition and was discharged home with plans to follow up in clinic. However, he developed increased swelling and low-grade fever, and was referred to the current hospital for admission.

The patient's allergies include erythromycin base. He has a history of MRSA infection and was previously treated with vancomycin and doxycycline. He was prescribed lasix to increase his dosage due to swelling, and also took a leftover prescription of dicloxacillin at home.

The patient's diagnosis is mixed bacterial flora, including Staphylococcus aureus, which is resistant to oxacillin, erythromycin, and other antibiotics. He underwent bedside bone biopsy, which showed fibro-purulent exudate with associated fragments of necrotic bone.

The patient underwent imaging studies, including X-ray and CT scans, which showed chronic changes in the ankle without evidence of osteomyelitis. However, the CT scan did show findings worrisome for calcaneal ulcer with associated phlegmon.

The patient's medications at discharge include lasix and other antibiotics.

SPECIAL PRECAUTIONS FOR PEOPLE WITH DEEP VEIN THROMBOSIS
Other symptoms may indicate that a clot in the leg has broken 
off and traveled to the lung, causing a pulmonary embolism. 
These may include:
* New chest pain with difficulty breathing
* A rapid heart rate and/or a feeling of passing out
This complication may be life-threatening and requires immediate 
attention. Emergency medical services are available in most 
areas of the ___ by calling 911.
Bleeding Â Anticoagulants such as heparin and warfarin can have 
serious side effects and should be taken exactly as directed. If 
a dose is forgotten, the patient should call his/her healthcare 
provider or clinic for advice. 
Patients may bleed easily while taking anticoagulants. Bleeding 
may develop in many areas, such as the nose or gums, excessive 
menstrual bleeding, bleeding in the urine or feces, bleeding or 
excessive bruising in the skin, as well as vomiting material 
that is bright red or dark brown like coffee grounds. In some 
cases, bleeding can develop inside the body and not be noticed 
immediately. Bleeding inside the body can cause a person to feel 
faint, or have pain in the back or abdomen. A healthcare 
provider should be notified immediately if there is any sign of 
this problem. A healthcare provider should also be notified 
immediately if the patient on anticoagulants sustained an injury 
that could lead to bleeding inside the body.
Reduce the risk of bleeding Â Some simple modifications can 
limit the risk of bleeding:
Use a soft bristle toothbrush
Shave with an electric razor rather than a blade
Take care when using scissors or knives
Avoid potentially harmful activities (eg, contact sports)
Use appropriate safety equipment (eg, helmets, padding) during 
physical activity
Do not take aspirin or other non-steroidal antiinflammatory 
agents (NSAIDS) (eg, ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, Nuprin) 
unless directed to do so by a healthcare provider. Other 
nonprescription pain medications, such as acetaminophen, may be 
a safe alternative.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male who was admitted for elective chemotherapy for his CNS B cell Lymphoma. He has a history of neurologic problems, including personality changes, numbness, and a mass in the corpus callosum. He has also had skin issues, including folliculitis, mucositis, and acral erythema, which have been managed with topical treatments and antibiotics. He has been experiencing severe leg cramps at night, which have been improving with ambulation and massage. He has a lip sore that comes and goes, which is likely herpes labialis.

The patient has a history of allergies to shellfish-derived products and has had adverse reactions to methotrexate, including skin peeling, bilateral lower extremity edema, and increased agitation and insomnia. He has also had hyperprolactinemia, hypercholesterolemia, and testosterone deficiency.

The patient's diagnosis is CNS B cell Lymphoma, and he has undergone several cycles of chemotherapy, including high-dose methotrexate. He has also had a stereotaxic brain biopsy and has been treated with dexamethasone, cabergoline, and Miracle mouthwash mucositis.

The patient's medications at discharge include dexamethasone, levETIRAcetam, lorazepam, ranitidine, omeprazole, acyclovir, and enoxaparin sodium.

discharge_summary: The patient is a 51-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with flank pain and was found to have multiple obstructing stones in her right ureter, causing severe hydronephrosis. She has a history of HIV/AIDS, CNS toxoplasmosis, and seizure disorder. Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY
Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o M w/ ESRD s/p DCD renal transplant 
in ___ on cellcept/tacro, s/p MVC ___ yrs ago w/ chronic 
neurogenic bladder c/b recurrent UTIs, HTN, diabetes, and recent

presenting with abdominal pain. He underwent aggressive bowel 
regimen with large stool burden and had a colonoscopy concerning 
for ischemic colitis. He was seen by CRS with no recommended 
surgical intervention. Course was complicated by UTI with MDR 
e.coli, and he underwent pMIBI which did not identify any 
reversible perfusion defect per cardiology consultation team. He 
will follow up with CRS, cardiology, and transplant nephrology 
as an outpatient and is discharged to skilled nursing facility.

ACUTE/ACTIVE ISSUES:
====================
#. Abdominal Pain 
#. Hx of Ischemic/C.Diff Colitis
Patient with imaging initially significant for improving 
colitis, persistent proctocolitis, and large stool burden. 
Abdominal pain though to be most likely ___ to large stool 
burden, so was treated with an aggressive bowel regimen. CRS was 
consulted without acute surgical need. ID was consulted as he 
was scheduled to followup with them as outpatient, who d/c'd his 
vanc/cefepime/flagyl which he was on from his previous course. 
The patient was scheduled for outpatient flex sig, so GI was 
consulted to perform in house. His prep was successful and he 
underwent a full colonoscopy, which was significant for erosion, 
ulceration and strictures, concerning for ischemic colitis, 
along with ? of diverticuli or fistulas. He underwent a CT with 
rectal contrast with no signs of fistulas. He was again seen by 
CRS with no plan for surgical intervention. He was kept on 
standing bowel regimen. MMF dose was decreased due to initial 
concern for MMF colitis but due to low suspicion on colonoscopy 
findings for MMF toxicity this was increased to 500 bid from 
250.

#. ESRD s/p DCD Renal Transplant

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___!

You were here because you were having abdominal pain. You were 
seen by the gastrointestinal (GI) team and the colorectal team, 
who felt that you had a lot of extra stool that was causing the 
pain. You also had a colonoscopy, which showed ulcers and narrow 
areas of your colon. Fortunately, the colorectal surgery team 
did not think you needed surgery. You had a stress test which 
did not show any active areas of decrease blood flow to your 
heart, and the cardiology team concluded that you would not 
benefit from an invasive procedure to look at the vessels of 
your heart. You were also found to have a urinary tract 
infection, for which you are discharged on a course of 
antibiotics through your PICC which will continue through ___. 
You will continue oral vancomycin through ___ to prevent c. diff 
infection.

When you leave, it is important you take your medications as 
prescribed. It is also important you keep your appointments as 
listed below. You will follow-up with cardiology and colorectal 
surgery as an outpatient as well as transplant nephrology.

We wish you the best of luck!

Your ___ Care Team

Hydrocodone-acetaminophen: for pain, as needed

attack/stroke

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) following a renal transplant. He has a neurogenic bladder, hypertension, diabetes, and a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). He was recently hospitalized for septic shock caused by ischemic colitis and Klebsiella urosepsis. He was treated with antibiotics and was discharged to a rehabilitation facility, where he developed worsening abdominal pain and diarrhea. He was transferred to the emergency department, where he was found to have a large stool burden and continued evidence of proctocolitis. He was diagnosed with partially reversible inferolateral perfusion defect and decreased left ventricular ejection fraction. He was also found to have a urinary tract infection caused by multidrug-resistant Escherichia coli (MDR E. coli).

The patient's allergies include antihistamines and glipizide. He has a history of chronic back pain, COPD, DM2, HTN, HLD, and recurrent UTIs. He has also had a colon adenomatous polyp and umbilical hernia repair.

The patient's medications at discharge include cellcept and tacro for his renal transplant, as well as antibiotics for his UTI.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 74-year-old female who was admitted for surgical management of her aortic valve and coronary artery disease. She has a history of aortic stenosis, patent foramen ovale, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease. She is allergic to erythromycin base. 

The patient underwent coronary artery bypass grafting to two vessels, aortic valve replacement with a 21mm porcine valve, and PFO closure. Postoperatively, she developed atrial fibrillation and was started on amiodarone and coumadin. She was also transfused with two units of packed red blood cells for postoperative anemia. 

The patient's medications at discharge include amiodarone, docusate sodium, aspirin, potassium chloride, atorvastatin, metoprolol tartrate, pantoprazole, furosemide, ciprofloxacin, and warfarin. She was discharged home with service and was advised to follow up with her cardiologist.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo female with history of HTN, IDDM, NiCMY, nonobstructing 
CAD, and ESRD on HD admitted after cardiac arrest with cooling 
protocol found to be hypokalemic with chronic prolonged qtc and 
polymorphic VT now extubated and s/p placement of single chamber 
ICD.
.
ACTIVE DIAGNOSES:
.
# Cardiac arrest s/p ICD placement: Pt had VT to Vfib arrest at 
dialysis center assessed as being the result of baseline 
prolonged QT interval (chronic per old EKG's obtained from ___) 
in the setting of electrolyte shifts during dialysis, most 
notably hypokalemia. Our thinking was that hypokalemia 
predisposed her to early after depolarizations with R on T 
phenomena making her more likely to have a degenerating rhythm 
due to her long QT. She had a long and eventful hospital course 
including undergoing arctic sun cooling and re-warming, 
successful extubation following prior failed attempt (she 
required re-intubation due to mucous plugging), and gradual 
recovery of her baseline mental status. She required frequent 
work with ___ and speech and swallow to resume PO intake. She was 
dialyzed in-house by the renal team who recommended she be 
dialyzed using a high K bath in the future to maintain her K 
around 5. Additionally, EP was consulted and after a significant 
amount of consideration and deliberation it was determined that 
she would benefit from a single chamber ICD which was placed 
despite concerns regarding her multiple comorbidities. She had 
evidence of significant ectopy on telemetry throughout her 
hospitalization including frequent PVC's and occasional runs of 
NSVT. She was discharged to rehab for continued recovery of her 
physical function. ICD dressing was removed on ___ and steri 
strips should stay in place until after her ICD check on 
___. 
.
# ESRD ON HD: Stable. She was maintained on her MWF dialysis 
schedule with high K buffer with goal K of 5. She did not have 
any significant arrythmias during dialysis but during one 
session she rolled onto the dialysis needle and punctured her 
graft. Doppler study was obtained which demonstrated her graft 
was intact and vascular surgery evaluated and stated it was okay 
for further dialysis. She has a large resolving hematoma 
proximal to the fistula. 
.
# Poor PO Intake/Severe Physical Deconditioning: Pt worked with 
speech and swallow almost daily to enhance her ability to take 
in nutrition by mouth. She was also seen by the nutrition 
service as it was felt she would be aided in her physical 
recovery with improved nutritional status. She was discharged to 
a rehab facility to aid in recovery of her physical functional 
status.
.
CHRONIC DIAGNOSES:
.
# Insulin dependent diabetes mellitus: Stable. She was managed 
in-house on a combination of long acting and humalog sliding 
scale. She is very sensitive to insulin and has had episodes of 
hypoglycemia. 
.
# HTN: Stable. On admission she had an unconventional 
antihypertensive regimen including significant doses of 
clonidine and hydralazine. She was gradually tapered off her 
regimen and it was replaced with carvedilol and lisinopril.
.
# CAD:  History of nonobstructive CAD but without ischemic 
changes on EKG's and without positive cardiac enzymes. She was 
treated with aspirin and atorvastatin as well as her blood 
pressure regimen above.
. 
# Chronic Diastolic Congestive Heart Failure:  History of 
non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with EF 45%. Her TSH was wnlÂs and 
her HIV negative. She was treated with a heart failure regimen 
including carvedilol and lisinopril.
.  
# Hypothyroidism: Her TSH was wnl's on admission. Her home 
synthroid was held as her history of hypothyroidism was 
questionable and it was unclear if it played any role in her 
cardiac excitability and subsequent cardiac arrest. Following 
her recovery, her TSH was checked once again and was found to be 
3.0 and she was re-started on her home synthroid.
.
# Chronic back pain: Pt with hx of chronic low back pain on 
narcotics as a home med but was oftentimes very somnolent, 
especially when taking these medications so they were 
discontinued. She infrequently complained of pain which was 
treated conservatively with tylenol and ibuprofen. 
.
# Questionable History of Epilepsy: Pt with questionable history 
of epilepsy on keppra as a home medication. She underwent EEG 
testing for >24 hours without any epileptiform discharges and 
there was concern that prior episodes of syncope (cardiogenic or 
otherwise) had been misinterpreted as epilepsy. Her keppra was 
held given her initially cloudy mental status and she did not 
have any seizure-like activity during her lengthy admission. 
Keppra was restarted at discharge but pt should see a 
neurologist in follow up to assess if this medication is truly 
needed. 
.
# Anxiety: Pt described significant anxiety related to her 
medical condition and trivial things such as fear of the dark. 
She was seen by the psychiatry team who recommended small 
standing doses of ativan (a home med) which was attempted but 
oftentimes left her somnolent and difficult to evaluate. These 
medications were held and her mental status improved 
significantly.
.
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
.
#She will need close supervision during dialysis and will need a 
high K bath to maintain K at goal of 5.
.
#She will need device clinic follow-up for her new single 
chamber ICD. Given her severe diabetes and ESRD, she is at 
increased risk of complications related to her device including 
pocket infections and should be monitored carefully.
.
#She will need to AVOID QT PROLONGING MEDICATIONS as these can 
cause a life-threatening arrythmia to occur in her given her 
underlying prolonged QT interval
.
#She will need significant rehabilitation as she is severely 
deconditioned
.
#She will need close follow up with her primary care doctor to 
tackle her ___ social and medical issues. Attempts were made to 
attempt that process by carefully clarifying her home 
medications, elements of her medical history which seemed 
questionable, and addressing her polypharmacy by eliminating 
unnecessary medications.
.
#She will likely need an outpatient social worker to help her 
cope with her multiple medical issues

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 39-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital due to cardiac arrest. She has a history of hypertension, diabetes, non-obstructive coronary artery disease, and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) requiring hemodialysis. She was found to be unresponsive and pulseless, but was successfully resuscitated with cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and defibrillation. She was intubated and sedated, and was started on amiodarone for arrhythmias.

The patient has a history of allergies to penicillins, amoxicillin, clindamycin, and other antibiotics. She has also had a recent viral infection and has been taking various medications, including blood pressure medications, antidiabetic medications, and antihypertensive medications.

The patient's physical examination revealed a sedated and intubated patient with low tone, elevated jugular venous pressure, and bilateral breath sounds. Her laboratory results showed elevated blood glucose, creatinine, and urea nitrogen levels, as well as abnormal liver function tests.

The patient's diagnosis is cardiac arrest due to ventricular tachycardia, and she was treated with amiodarone and other medications. She was also started on a cooling protocol to reduce her body temperature.

The patient's medications at discharge include amiodarone, propofol, and other medications to manage her arrhythmias and other medical conditions.

discharge_summary: The patient is a 52-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with hypoxia and headaches. She has a history of severe COPD, pseudotumor cerebri, and myocardial infarction with three stents placed. She is also morbidly obese and has diabetes mellitus type 2. The patient's allergies include penicillins, OxyContin, Vicodin, and MS. She was admitted to the MICU for oxygen monitoring and treatment of her hypoxia and headaches. During her admission, she underwent an interventional radiology-guided lumbar puncture and was treated with nebulizers, steroids, and antibiotics. The patient's oxygen saturation improved, and she was eventually transferred to the floor for further treatment. At discharge, she was prescribed medications including acetazolamide, oxycodone, and tylenol, and was scheduled for follow-up appointments with a pulmonologist and sleep medicine specialist.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 91-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of RUQ pain and fevers. She has a history of dementia, hypertension, CAD, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and a papillary neoplasm of the ampulla of Vater. She was previously treated for cholangitis with biliary stents and presented to the hospital with 3 days of fever, RUQ pain, and jaundice. She was found to have elevated liver enzymes and underwent an ERCP procedure, which revealed debris and stones in the bile duct. She was treated with antibiotics and had a successful outcome.

The patient's past medical history includes dementia, anxiety, DM2, HLD, HTN, atrial fibrillation, papillary neoplasm of the ampulla of Vater, CAD, and cholangitis. She has no known allergies or adverse reactions.

The patient's diagnosis was acute cholangitis, transaminitis, acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, and pneumonia. She underwent an ERCP procedure, which revealed debris and stones in the bile duct, and was treated with antibiotics.

The patient's medications at discharge included cefpodoxime and metronidazole for a planned seven-day course to cover both cholangitis and possible pneumonia.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with chest pain. He has a history of coronary artery disease, chronic stable angina, moderate aortic stenosis, bladder cancer, chronic kidney disease, and renal cell carcinoma. He has also had a history of intolerance to beta blockers due to symptomatic bradycardia. 

The patient was diagnosed with non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and underwent cardiac catheterization, which showed effective revascularization. However, due to the complexity of possible percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), he was medically managed instead. 

During his hospital stay, the patient developed acute kidney injury (AKI) due to postrenal ureteral stenosis, which was treated with a ureteral stent. He also had anemia, which was managed with blood transfusions. 

The patient was discharged on medications including aspirin, rosuvastatin, metoprolol, IMDUR, and ranolazine. He will also need to keep a ureteral stent in place for several weeks and follow up with his doctor in clinic.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with worsening joint pain. He has a history of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and has undergone a myeloablative double cord blood transplant. He has been experiencing chronic joint pain since his transplant, which has worsened over the past two weeks. The patient has been taking oxycodone for pain control, but has recently decreased his dosage due to nausea and vomiting. He has also been experiencing fever, fatigue, and swelling in his joints.

The patient's past medical history includes a diagnosis of AML, sarcoidosis, and chronic GVHD. He has undergone several treatments for his AML, including induction therapy, consolidation therapy, and relapse treatment. He has also received Rituxan for his chronic GVHD.

The patient's physical examination revealed a middle-aged, Cushingoid, overweight man with bilateral 2+ pitting edema to his knees. His joints were tender to palpation, and he had ecchymoses on his abdomen. His laboratory results showed an elevated CRP level, indicating an inflammatory process.

The patient's diagnosis is chronic GVHD with joint pain, likely due to a combination of GVHD and changes in his narcotics regimen. His treatment plan includes increasing his prednisone dosage and discontinuing his plaquinil medication.

discharge_summary: The patient is a 23-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital after an intentional overdose of amitriptyline and alcohol. She had a history of previous suicide attempts, self-harm, and eating disorder. Her presenting symptoms included altered mental status, tachycardia, and clonus. Laboratory results showed elevated levels of amitriptyline, ethanol, and acetaminophen, but negative for benzodiazepines and barbiturates. The patient was treated with a bicarbonate drip for TCA toxicity and was extubated and weaned to room air. She was also treated for possible serotonin syndrome and aspirin overdose. The patient's medications at discharge included none, as her amitriptyline was stopped.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male who was admitted for scheduled methotrexate treatment for recurrent CNS lymphoma. He has a history of composite Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, which was diagnosed in the past and treated with ABVD, rituximab, and mBACOD, resulting in a complete systemic response. However, he developed CNS relapse and is currently in remission. He has also had a history of renal tuberculosis, hyperlipidemia, and vertigo.

The patient's presenting symptoms were related to his CNS lymphoma, including floaters in his eyes and weakness in his right hand. He had undergone a stereotactic brain biopsy and received high-dose methotrexate treatment, which resulted in a complete response. He has since been on a maintenance schedule of rituximab and high-dose methotrexate.

The patient's physical exam was normal, with no signs of edema, clubbing, or asterixis. His laboratory results showed normal blood counts, with a slight elevation in his liver enzymes. He was prescribed medications for his GERD and hypokalemia, which were resolved during his hospital stay.

The patient was discharged home with instructions to follow up with his oncologist and to continue his scheduled methotrexate treatment. He was also advised to use famotidine for his GERD and to replenish his potassium levels as needed.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 44-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital due to elevated bilirubin levels. She had a history of multiple injuries, including a head-on motor vehicle crash, and was previously discharged to a skilled nursing facility (SNF) with a hematocrit of 27. However, she was readmitted due to a decrease in her hematocrit to 21 and was found to have a large intrahepatic biloma without significant ductal dilation. She underwent an ERCP with sphincterotomy and placement of a biliary pigtail catheter, and was also found to have a grade IV liver laceration.

The patient's past medical history includes bipolar disorder, depression, anxiety, substance abuse, and an eating disorder. She has no known allergies to drugs. Her physical exam revealed jaundice, thinness, and mild tenderness in the abdomen.

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated liver enzymes, including ALT and AST, as well as anemia and thrombocytopenia. Her radiology report showed a significantly enlarging intrahepatic fluid collection at the site of a previously seen complex liver laceration, compatible with an evolving hematoma.

The patient was discharged to an extended care facility with a diagnosis of biloma and a secondary diagnosis of grade IV liver laceration. Her medications at discharge included nicotine patches, heparin, olanzapine, ciprofloxacin, metronidazole, oxycodone, colace, and dulcolax.
