1. CXR (___)
Lungs are well expanded, with linear opacities at the lung 
bases, most likely representing atelectasis. However, 
curvilinear opacity could also represent scarring. Heart is 
normal in size, 
and there is no hilar or mediastinal enlargement. Soft tissue 
and bony structures are unremarkable. IMPRESSIONS: Atelectasis 
versus scarring at the left lung base. No acute 
abnormalities. 
2. CT Head w/o Contrast (___)
There is no intra- or extra-axial hemorrhage, edema, mass 
effect, shift of normally midline structures, or acute major 
vascular territorial infarction. Ventricles and sulci are normal 
in caliber and configuration. Visualized paranasal sinuses and 
mastoid air cells are well aerated. Osseous structures are 
unremarkable. IMPRESSION: No acute intracranial process. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
1. Loss of Consciousness:
Most likely this was due to hypovolemia given pt's history of 
diarrhea, decreased PO intake and orthostatic symptoms. BP was 
also low on admission. Other concern on admission was for 
cardiogenic syncope.  EKG showed ST-T wave changes with T wave 
inversions in V1-V4 which were unchanged from prior ECGs.  
Troponins and CK were cycled and showed a Troponin of 0.08 which 
did not rise and was likely due to her kidney disease.  Pt had 
no signs of congestive heart failure and an echo was done which 
was normal.  She had no clinical signs of PE.  Has a history of 
seizures and migraines; however no seizure activity was 
observed. TIA/CVA is also unlikely with normal neuro exam. Pt 
also had a history of hypothyroidism and TSH was check and was 
>100.  Free T4 was low at 0.28. Pt has been non-compliant with 
meds in the past but stated that she had not missed any of her 
thyroid medication.  Pt's home pharmacy was called and stated 
that the prescription had last been filled in early ___ but 
had not been filled prior to this.  TSH was checked in the past 
___ and ___ and was elevated at this time as well.  Pt also 
had symptoms of hypothyroidism with weight gain, weakness, 
fatigue, headache and dry skin. Pt was also reported to be 
hypoglycemic on presentation and this could have been a 
contributing factor to syncope with poor oral intake. 
.
On admission, pt was due for dialysis and did undergo HD with 
2.3L removed. On arrival to the floor, BP was low at 80/40.  Pt 
required 2.5L of fluid resuscitation to bring BP to 100s.  She 
was asymptomatic during this time without chest pain, 
lightheadedness or dizziness.  Blood and urine cultures were 
sent and negative.  A urine tox was negative.  Orthostatic BPs 
were checked after fluid resuscitation and were normal.  An 
echocardiogram was done which was normal with an EF of 55%.  Pt 
did well clinically during admission and experienced no other 
symptoms of lightheadedness or loss of consciousness.  Her 
anti-hypertensive medications were held in light of her low 
blood pressure.  She was given Levothyroxine at 100mcg/day given 
her low levels of T4 (was previously supposed to be taking 
75mcg/day).
.
The patient experienced no further symptoms of syncope during 
admission.  Telemetry showed no arrhythmias and echocardiogram 
was normal.
.
2. Hypoglycemia:
Pt was hypoglycemic on admission with blood sugar reported to be 
45 at ___. Fingersticks were checked throughout admission and 
blood sugars with in the low-normal range of ___.  LFTs 
were checked for possible causes for hypoglycemia and were with 
AST 45 and ALT 27.
.  
3. Diarrhea: 
Pt stated that diarrhea symptoms had been present prior to 
admission and continued through hospital stay.  Stool cultures 
and ova and parasites were negative.  Likely cause was viral 
gastroenteritis vs. narcotic withdrawal.
.

withdrawal symptoms of anxiety and agitation.  She was given 
120mg of Methadone daily for her hx of narcotic abuse and 
withdrawal symptom prevention. She was given Trazadone 50 qhs as 
per home dose.
.

admission as well as on ___ as per home schedule (___). She 
was continued on Calcitriol and calcium carbonate. She tolerated 
dialysis well.
.

Pt experienced no seizures while admitted. She was continued on 
her home done of Keppra.  
.

Pt was continued on Fluoxetine.
.
8. Hypothyroidism
As described, pt was hypothyroid with a free T4 of 0.28 and 
unclear if she had been taking Levothyroxine as prescribed.  She 
was put on Levothyroxine 100mcg daily and discharged on this 
dose. She was discharged with ___ services to assist with 
medication compliance. 
.

Pt had no asthma symptoms.  Advair was continued.
.

Pt was put on SC heparin for DVT prophylaxis and omeprazole.
.

Output:
discharge_summary: The patient is a 53-year-old female who presented to the emergency department with a brief loss of consciousness and subsequent fall. She has a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) secondary to hypertensive nephropathy, and has undergone a renal transplant. She also has a history of substance abuse, depression, and hypothyroidism. On physical examination, her vital signs were stable, and she had no signs of acute distress. Laboratory results showed mild anemia, elevated creatinine, and hypocalcemia. The patient was diagnosed with a syncopal episode and was treated with IV fluids and dialysis. She was also prescribed medications for her hypertension and hypothyroidism.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ woman w/ ESRD on dialysis, HCV cirrhosis, HTN and chronic 
diarrhea presenting with abdominal pain, fevers, nausea/vomiting 
and ongoing diarrhea. Initially, Ms. ___ was found to have a 
mildly elevated Lipase (239) and CT findings consistent with 
acute pancreatitis and was admitted for treatment and further 
evaluation.

# abdominal pain: The location, quality and time course of Ms. 
___ pain were not classic for acute pancreatitis, however, 
her mildly elevated lipase, fat stranding and reactive LN seen 
of abdominal CT were consistent w/ pancreatitis. There was no 
evident CBD dilation or evidence of stones, and the portal veins 
were open with no evidence of thrombosis. Alcohol and 
gallstones, the most common etiologies for pancreatitis were 
unlikely in this case. Triglycerides were checked and found to 
be within normal limits. The patient was treated conservatively 
for acute pancreatitis, made NPO, given narcotic pain control 
and antiemetics. Over the course of her stay her pain localized 
primarily to the left lower quadrant for which there was no 
clear explanation. She had a bimanual pelvic exam and was found 
to have no adnexal tenderness or cervical motion tenderness. An 
adenexal cyst seen incidentally on CT was on the right and could 
not explain her discomfort. Over the course of her stay, Ms. 
___ pain improved. Her diet was advanced, and she was sent 
home only on her baseline Methadone with no further medications 
for pain control. She may benefit from an outpatient MRCP for 
further evaluation of the cause of her pancreatitis.

# diarrhea: Ms. ___ reports ongoing diarrhea for >6mo. Based 
on OMR records and patient report it appears that work-up to 
date has been negative. The bowel appears normal on CT. The 
patient's diarrhea is secretory based on labs and history of 
large volume diarrhea that occurs throughout the day and night. 
The patient's TSH was found to be suppressed to 0.15 which may 
be contributing. Based on an informal recommendation from 
endocrinology her levothyroxine dose was decreased.
Inpatient work-up including stool cultures and O&P were 
negative. A second O&P is pending at the time of discharge. 
Fecal fat is also pending. Outpatient follow up with the 
patient's gastroenterologist was scheduled for further work-up.

# fever: The patient reported intermittent fevers at home up to 
approximately ___. At the time of admission she was afebrile. 
On hospital day number 2 she developed a fever up to ___ 
accompanied shaking chills. Her dialysis was cut short due to 
concern for sepsis and possible exacerbation of her acute 
pancreatitis. The patient was treated with Tylenol and cooling 
packs and her fever resolved. She had no further febrile 
episodes during her stay. Her fever was most likely secondary to 
her pancreatitis although temperatures as high as ___ are 
unusual with uncomplicated pancreatitis. It may also have been 
attributable to a viral illness. Bacterial infection was ruled 
out by blood culture which was negative x 3 ___s CXR with 
no sign of infection. The patient had no respiratory symptoms. 
Urinalysis and urine culture could not be obtained as the 
patient is anuric. The patient was tested for HIV and was found 
to be negative. She reports recent TB testing (often part of 
work-up related to dialysis) which was also negative per her 
report. 
An adnexal cyst was seen on CT which did not appear consistent 
with an abscess. She had no focal adnexal tenderness on bimanual 
exam and no CMT (pt last sexually active ___ ago). Fever could 
also be explained by malignancy. As the patient was reporting 
malaise and an approximately ten pound weight loss over ___ 
months and lymphadenopathy was seen on CT and on exam ___ was 
checked to assess for lymphoma and came back within normal 
limits. No further work-up for malignancy was pursued.

# Leukopenia: Ms. ___ presented with a white blood cell count 
within the normal range. Over the course of her hospital stay 
she developed a leukopenia. This was most likely secondary to a 
viral illness. Her white blood cell count was monitored and 
stabilized prior to discharge. This will be followed up by her 
outpatient Nephrologist at hemodialysis and this abnormality was 
also discussed with her PCP. 

# ESRD: The patient is regularly on a MWF schedule for 
hemodialysis. Her last hemodialysis prior to admission was ___. 
She missed HD on ___, the day of admission. During her 
hospitalization, Ms. ___ was followed by the dialysis team 
and had daily labwork. She went for hemodialysis on ___ which 
was cut short due to worsening clinical status including 
fever/chills leading to concern for sepsis as well as the 
conflict between removing fluid through dialysis and the goal of 
maintaining fluid volume with acute pancreatitis. The patient 
did not receive HD on ___ as based on labs and clinical status 
it was not urgently indicated and the patient had worsened ___ 
w/ hemodialysis. The patient did receive HD ___ and ___.
The patient was hypocalcemic during her stay. Albumin was 3.9 
indicating a true hypocalcemia. She was continued on calcitriol 
and calcium carbonate.

#HTN - The patients blood pressures were mainly in the 150s 
systolic. She had been on Labetalol 400mg TID prior to a 
previous admission which was switched to Metoprolol XL 25mg 
daily, lisinopril 2.5mg daily @ last admission ___. 
Simvastatin 20mg daily and ASA 81mg were also added at that time 
for cardio-protection, however the patient states that she was 
not taking her Metoprolol, Lisinopril, ASA or Simvastatin. The 
patient's blood pressure was discussed with her nephrologist, 
Dr. ___. Dr. ___ restarting her 
beta-blocker, but waiting to restart Lisinopril. The patient was 
started on Metoprolol succinate 12.5mg daily which was titrated 
up to Metoprolol succinate 25mg daily prior to discharge. 

# seizure disorder - The patient had no seizure activity during 
her hospitalization and was continued on her home dose of 
Keppra.

# depression - The patient's home medications were continued 
during her stay. She was seen by social work at her request for 
coping/support. The patient reports seeing a therapist on a 
regular basis which she plans to continue.
 
# hypothyroidism - The patient has a history of hypothyroidism 
and her TSH was found to be suppressed @ 0.15. This may have a 
role in her diarrhea, although her free T4 and total T4 were 
only minimally elevated. The patient's levothyroxine dose was 
decreased from 200mcg to 188mcg daily. She will need outpt 
follow up including repeat TFTs in 1 month.

# Asthma - The patient has a history of asthma and uses Advair 
at home. She was stable from a respiratory standpoint during her 
admission. She was continued on Advair. 

# CT findings - a 5cm right adnexal mass and new renal lesions 
were seen on CT scan incidentally. The patient will need outpt 
follow up of these findings.

Discharge Instructions:
Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital with nausea, vomiting and 
abdominal pain. You had blood tests performed and a CT Scan that 
showed signs of pancreatitis. In the hospital you received 
intravenous fluids, pain control, and were asked not to eat or 
drink. While you were in the hospital you had an episode of high 
fevers that were likely due to your pancreatitis. No other 
source of infection or cause for your fevers was found. Your 
fevers resolved with tylenol and cooling packs. Your pain and 
nausea also improved and your diet was advanced slowly back to a 
regular diet.

While in the hospital you had dialysis for your kidney disease. 
You also had tests performed to evaluate possible causes of your

with your gastroenterologist, Dr. ___ as scheduled for further 
work-up.

to follow up with your primary care doctor. You will also see 
your nephrologist, Dr. ___, at dialysis and your

your diarrhea.

means that you are HYPER-thyroid. This may have played a role in

Output:
discharge_summary: The patient is a 53-year-old female with a chief complaint of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has a history of hypertension, HCV cirrhosis, and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis. She also has a history of chronic diarrhea, which has been ongoing for over six months. On admission, she was found to have mild tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant, but no rebound or guarding. Laboratory results showed mildly elevated lipase and CT findings consistent with acute pancreatitis. She was treated conservatively for acute pancreatitis and her pain improved over the course of her stay. She was also found to have a suppressed TSH, which may be contributing to her diarrhea. At discharge, she was afebrile and her abdominal pain had improved. She was prescribed no further medications for pain control and was scheduled for outpatient follow-up with her gastroenterologist for further work-up.

Brief Hospital Course:
Key Information for Outside Providers: 
___ is a ___ year old female with history of ESRD on HD, 
peripheral vascular disease status post RLE BKA, admitted 
___ with sepsis secondary to MRSA bacteremia, now status 
post removal and replacement of her tunneled HD line able to be 
discharged home with planned course of vancomycin to be 
continued at HD

# MRSA Sepsis secondary to
# Acute blood stream infection 
# Suspected Acute bacterial Endocarditis 
# L lateral heel ulcer 
Patient with history of MRSA line infection ___ who 
presented with MRSA bacteremia presumed ___ line infection. 
Patient's TTE was concerning for possible vegetation on 
tricuspid valve.  She was seen by ID consult service who 
initially recommended TEE, but patient declined this and was 
able to verbalize her understanding.  Source of bacteremia felt 
to be line-related, although ID also recommended MRI of L heel, 
where she had an unhealed ulcer that was debrided by podiatry.  
Given need for IV contrast, patient declined study due to 
chronic risks associated with MRI contrast in patients who are 
ESRD.  Patient had HD catheter removed on ___, then had a 
line replaced on ___.  Patient treated with IV vancomcyin 
with clinical improvement.  Last positive blood cultures were 
drawn on ___. Because endocarditis and/or osteomyelitis 
could not be definitively ruled out, ID consult service 
recommended completion of 6-week course of Vancomycin, dosed at 
HD.  

# Difficult access 
___ initially tried to place a new line on the left side, to 
preserve the right-sided vasculature for a future AV graft. 
Unfortunately, a L IJ and L subclavian line was unable to be 
placed due to sclerosis and or thrombosis of the L IJ and L 
subclavian, likely secondary to multiple access attempts. The 
patient refused femoral access and was able to verbalize 
understanding of clinical situation.  Per discussion with Renal 
and ___, the decision was made to place R IJ line as above. 

# Behavioral Issues 
Patient often refused medications during this admission. In 
speaking to the patient, she believes that many medications 
make her sick. In speaking to her HCP, her brother ___ 
___, he reports that she often refuses medications at home as 
well.  Inpatient psychiatry consult team saw patient for 
assessment regarding capacity to make medical decisions 
relating to medications and inpatient managemetn.  She was felt 
to not pose a danger to herself, and in discussions with team 
was able to demonstrate understanding of her decisions and 
their impact on her health.  She was recommended for outpatient 
follow up with psychiatry and counseling. Of note, per review 
of prior records, does have history of concussion as child. 
Evaluated by Cognitive Neurology in ___. Found to have 
significantly low IQ and learning deficits, although masked by 
verbal fluency. Her ability to handle new and complex info is 
impaired.  During this admission extra time was spent 
counseling patient to ensure she understood clinical situation, 
team recommendations and risk/benefit as it related to her 
clinical state.

# Gastroparesis
Initial presentation notable for nausea and vomiting. No 
evidence of acute abnormality on CT A/P and abdominal exam 
reassuring.  Felt to represent gastroparesis flare.  Treated 
with supportive care with resolution of symptoms.  She was able 
to tolerate a regular diet. 

# ESRD: On HD TThSa. Pt declined sevelamer/nephrocaps as she 
reported they worsen her chronic symptoms of nausea. 

# Hyperphosphatemia: Pt declined phosphate binders this 
admission. 

# Mild Intermittent Asthma
Continued home flovent. 

# DM type 2
Held glipizide while inpatient, restarted upon discharge.

Output:
discharge_summary: The patient is a 29-year-old female with a chief complaint of abdominal pain, vomiting, fever, and rigors. She has a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD) with gastroparesis, neuropathy, and peripheral vascular disease (PVD) following a right lower extremity (RLE) below-knee amputation (BKA). She has multiple allergies, including penicillins, cephalosporins, aztreonam, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and Reglan. She was admitted to the hospital with MRSA bacteremia and line infection, treated with vancomycin. During her hospital stay, she underwent tunneled HD catheter removal and temporary HD catheter placement. She was also treated for a cold and had a chronic foot ulcer on her left heel. At discharge, her vital signs were stable, and she was prescribed medications for her condition.

She underwent ERCP with sphincterotomy and stent placement, and also had EUS with aspiration of a duodenal mass/cyst. At discharge, she was prescribed medications including Zolpidem for insomnia, Ciprofloxacin for infection, and Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen for pain. She was advised to follow a bland diet and to return to the ER or call her PCP if she experiences increased epigastric pain, vomiting, or fever.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old female who was admitted for valve-sparing aortic root replacement surgery. She has a history of aortic insufficiency, aortic aneurysm, asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and hyperlipidemia. Her chief complaint was dyspnea on exertion. The patient underwent a successful surgery and was discharged on post-operative day 6.

The patient's past medical history includes aortic insufficiency, aortic aneurysm, asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, depression, gastroesophageal reflux disease, hyperlipidemia, insomnia, liver mass, psoriasis, and vitamin D deficiency.

The patient's medications at discharge include acetaminophen, amLODIPine, aspirin, docusate sodium, furosemide, metoprolol tartrate, ranitidine, senna, and trazodone.

The patient's physical examination revealed a warm, dry, and intact skin with multiple purpura and bruising on her arms and legs. Her vital signs were stable, and she was awake and alert. Her neurological examination was grossly intact, and her cardiovascular examination revealed a regular rhythm with a III/VI diastolic murmur at the aortic position.

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with chest pain. He has a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, pre-diabetes, hemorrhoids/anal fissure, and benign prostatic hypertrophy. He presented with substernal chest pain that started in the morning while he was lying in bed, which was associated with sweating, feeling hot and clammy, and diaphoresis. The pain lasted for about an hour and was described as severe. He denied radiation of pain, numbness/tingling in his arms, shortness of breath, and abdominal/back pain.

The patient has a past medical history of cardiac risk factors, including pre-diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia. He also has a history of dermatoheliosis, benign prostatic hypertrophy, inflammatory colon polyp, chronic sun-damaged skin, and seborrheic keratoses.

The patient's physical examination on admission showed a well-developed male in no acute distress, with a normal cardiovascular examination. His laboratory results showed elevated troponin levels, with a peak level of 0.16 ng/mL. He was started on heparin gtt and aspirin.

The patient underwent a left heart catheterization, which showed 90% occlusion in the mid and distal left anterior descending (LAD) artery, and two drug-eluting stents were placed with good revascularization.

The patient's diagnosis is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, consistent with coronary artery disease. He was prescribed medications at discharge, including aspirin, clopidogrel, and metoprolol.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is an ___ yo M with history of intellectual disability, 
HTN, HLD, who presented to the hospital with facial bruising and 
had first time seizure in the ED >15 minutes, and required 
Ativan, keppra, and intubation with propofol drip to resolve. He 
was found to have a UTI which likely contributed to the seizure, 
and had decreased brain volume and atrophy on MRI which lowers 
seizure threshold. He will continue on keppra for seizure 
treatment. 

#Seizure/encephalopathy
The patient was admitted to the NeuroICU on midazolam gtt and 
fentanyl. No further seizure like activity was noted. He was 
continued on Keppra 500 mg BID. He was initially continued on 
broad spectrum coverage for meningoencephalitis, though 
antibacterials were discontinued with an LP showing 1 WBC. He 
was continued on acyclovir until HSV PCR negative on ___. 
MRI showed global brain atrophy, without acute lesions or other 
structural problems. EEG showed generalized slowing in the ___ 
hz range with no seizures or epileptiform dischages. He was 
weaned to extubate on hospital day 3. Urine culture from 
admission turned positive, showed >100k CFU EColi, he was 
started on ceftriaxone, however sensitivities showed CTX 
resistance, and he was switched to IV Unasyn on ___. He was 
discharged on augmentin 875mg BID for a total 10 day course 
(ends on ___.

#Hypotension
Home BP medications were held as he had SBP90s while intubated 
on sedating medications. His SBP ran in the 100-110 range after 
extubation, so home medications continued to be held.

# Constipation
On ___ he vomited dinner, and again vomited breakfast on ___. He 
had benign abdominal exam with KUB that showed large amount of 
stool. He received Miralax, bisacodyl, lactulose, milk of 
magnesia, and fleet enema x 2 and had multiple bowel movements. 
He was able to tolerate PO prior to discharge back to nursing 
facility. He was discharged on new medications for constipation.

# Pectoralis tear: CT chest showed an incidental finding of a 
left pectoralis muscular injury/tear with evolving intramuscular 
hematoma. Patient denied pain at that site and had full range of 
motion of the shoulder. Orthopedics was consulted who 
recommended nonoperative management with rest, ice, and pain 
control.

Output:
discharge_summary: The patient is an 81-year-old male with a chief complaint of seizures. He has a history of intellectual disability, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He was admitted to the hospital after presenting with facial bruising and having a generalized seizure that lasted over 15 minutes. He was intubated and placed on propofol due to the severity of the seizure. Laboratory results showed lactate levels of 7.9 and prolactin levels of 93, indicating a possible encephalopathy. A CT scan of the head showed diffuse decreased brain volume consistent with his history of intellectual disability. He was started on ceftriaxone, vancomycin, and acyclovir for possible meningoencephalitis. He was also found to have a urinary tract infection, which likely contributed to the seizure. He was treated with keppra for seizure treatment and was continued on broad-spectrum antibiotics until a lumbar puncture showed only one white blood cell. He was eventually weaned off propofol and extubated.

He was found lying on the ground by his wife and friend, and he does not recall the events surrounding the fall. He was taken to the hospital and evaluated, and a CT scan revealed a left frontal punctate hemorrhage and resolving subarachnoid hemorrhage, as well as multiple facial fractures.

The patient's past medical history includes a meniscectomy in his right knee and high cholesterol. He has no allergies or adverse reactions listed. His diagnosis is a traumatic brain injury with facial fractures.

The patient underwent no surgical procedures during his hospital stay. The patient's physical examination was normal, with the exception of some ecchymosis and lacerations on his face and scalp. His neurological examination was also normal, with no signs of seizure activity or incontinence.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is an ___ y/o M with extensive vascular history who 
presented with chest pain and anemia. Transferred to MICU due to 
concern of demand ischemia in setting of LGIB.  

#Chest Pain - The patient has an extensive coronary history. His 
present episode of chest pain ocurred in the setting of 
tachycardia to the 160s (reported by EMS) and a hematocrit below 
his baseline. Given pt's EKG and clinical picture, the elevated 
troponin was most likely demand ischemia. He was given packed 
RBCs to increase oxygen supply for increased demand.   A CHF 
exacerbation despite an elevated BNP, but unclear likely given 
clear lungs and no fluid overload on CXR.  Other etiologies 
including PE was considered but his INR was supratherepeutic and 
pt was not hypoxic. Cardiology was consulted and did not believe 
that this was ACS and did not recommend coronary angiography.

# Anemia - The patient has a long history of anemia and has 
known history of gastric erosions, but no ulcers, and 
diverticuli. CT Abdomen this month has no evidence of 
malignancy. Pt is presently on iron supplementation. Guaiac (+) 
stool in ED and on the floor. Pt was transfused several units of 
RBCs (followed by lasix) to maintain a goal of hct>30 for demand 
ischemia. 
 
# A. Fib - CHADS2 score of 4. The patient presented in afib with 
a rate in the 110s, and hemodynamically stable. Pt may have had 
an episode of NSVT with EMS before arriving to ED since he had 
SVT during last admission. No SVT episodes during ICU course. Pt 
was continued on metoprolol with rates maintained below 100, 
until the patient developed the GI bleed.  Metoprolol was held 
given blood pressures in 90/50 and his heart rate was well 
controlled without it.  Given his GI bleed, his coumadin and 
metoprolol were held at the time of discharge.

and started on metronidazole on ___.  He will need to 
complete 14 days of metronidazole.
 
# PVD - Patient with PVD leading to ulcerations. Patient with 
stent placed recently and it was of high priority that he 
continued anti-platelet and AC with plavix and warfarin at 
present. With pt's GI bleed, vascular team was amenable to 
discontinuing Plavix. Wound care team followed pt throughout 
course.

# Acute on Chronic Kidney Disease - Cr elevated to 2.0 on 
admission. Also with BUN elevation to suggest pre-renal state. 
___ also be due to renal vein congestion in the setting of CHF. 
After receiving blood products, his Cr improved and was 1.4 at 
the time of discharge.

# sCHF/CAD - Worsening EF thought to be due to progressive CAD. 
It was imperative to give blood/fluid slowly and diurese as 
needed. CXR and lungs presently clear with absent JVD on my 
exam. Pt's home torsemide was held.  The statin and ACE 
inhibitor were restarted by the time of discharge.  The patient 
should follow up with his cardiology within ___ weeks after 
discharge to assess the need to restart his torsemide.

Seen by ___ consult and was started on zyprexa PRN agitation at 
night.

We also found that you had a bleed within your gastrointestional 
system.  You underwent endoscopy, in otherword we looked with a 
camera at your gastrointestion system, which did not find the 
source of your bleeding.  We have stopped your plavix and 
currently stopping your coumadin after discharge.  We have also 
stopped your torsemide and metoprolol given lower blood

determine if you should restart the torsemide, metoprolol, and

Finally, it is important that you rebuild your strength after

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 77-year-old male who presented with chest pain and anemia. He has a extensive past medical history, including coronary artery disease, ischemic cardiomyopathy, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and peripheral vascular disease. He was recently admitted with hypotension and was found to have a reduction in left ventricular ejection fraction to 20%. He was also diagnosed with gastritis and duodenal ulcer.

The patient's diagnosis on admission was demand ischemia, and he was given packed red blood cells to increase oxygen supply. He was also treated for possible gastrointestinal bleeding and sepsis. His medications at discharge included warfarin, metoprolol, and iron supplementation.

The patient underwent an endoscopy and was found to have moderate gastritis and duodenal ulcer. He also had a positive stool test for Clostridium difficile.

The patient's physical examination on admission showed an irregularly irregular heartbeat, normal S1 and S2 heart sounds, and a II/VI systolic murmur. His lungs were clear to auscultation, and his abdomen was soft and non-tender. His extremities showed poor pulses bilaterally with eschar over an ulcer on the right.

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated troponin levels, anemia, and abnormal liver function tests. His chest X-ray showed no acute cardiopulmonary process.

The patient's hospital course was complicated by demand ischemia, anemia, and possible gastrointestinal bleeding. He was treated with packed red blood cells, antibiotics, and iron supplementation. He was also continued on warfarin and metoprolol.

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:
- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- weight bearing as tolerated and range of motion as tolerated 
in left lower extremity 

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

PAIN MEDICATIONS INSTRUCTIONS:
1)  Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock.
2)  Add your prescribed narcotics as needed for increased pain. 
Start weaning the narcotic medication once you get home. 

This is an example on how to wean down:
Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, 
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.  
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.

3)  Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic 
medication.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please continue home Xarelto daily

WOUND CARE:
- Your incision is covered with a dry dressing. Please change 
the dressing daily. If there is no drainage, you may leave your 
incision open to the air. If you are continuing to have 
drainage, you may place a dry dressing over the incision as 
needed.
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.

THIS PATIENT IS EXPECTED TO REQUIRE <30 DAYS OF REHAB

Physical Therapy:
weight bearing as tolerated and range of motion as tolerated in 
left lower extremity 

Activity:  Out of bed w/ assist 
Ambulate twice daily if patient able
 Right lower extremity:  Full weight bearing
 Left lower extremity:  Full weight bearing
Encourage turning, deep breathing and coughing qhour when awake. 
 

Treatments Frequency:
Any staples or superficial sutures you have are to remain in 
place for at least 2 weeks postoperatively.  Incision may be 
left open to air unless actively draining.  If draining, you may 
apply a gauze dressing secured with paper tape.  You may shower 
and allow water to run over the wound, but please refrain from 
bathing for at least 4 weeks postoperatively.

Call your surgeon's office with any questions.  

 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
discharge_summary: The patient is an 89-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a left intertrochanteric fracture after falling from standing and landing on her left hip. She has a history of atrial fibrillation, mild COPD, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. She is allergic to sulfa, dicloxacillin, and Bactrim. The patient underwent left hip ORIF with TFN and was discharged with a diagnosis of left intertrochanteric hip fracture. She was prescribed medications including Lovenox for DVT prophylaxis, and was instructed to take Tylenol and narcotics as needed for pain. She was also advised to continue her home medications, except for those that were adjusted during her hospital stay. The patient was discharged in stable condition, with her incision well approximated and dressing clean and dry. She was instructed to follow up with her surgeon and to take her medications as prescribed.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of right toe pain. She has a history of IDDM2, pHTN, Sweet syndrome, and inflammatory arthritis, and was recently hospitalized for UTI, worsening Sweet syndrome, and inflammatory arthritis. She was treated with antibiotics and underwent an I&D procedure for a right toe abscess. The patient's past medical history includes CKD stage III, HLD, recurrent cystitis, urge incontinence, endometrial cancer, OSA, and COPD. She has allergies to Clindamycin and dapsone.

The patient's diagnosis is a right toe abscess/cellulitis, likely related to a flare of Sweet's syndrome and inflammatory arthritis. She was treated with Unasyn and Augmentin antibiotics, and her wound was treated with betadine dressings and a surgical boot.

At discharge, the patient's medications included Augmentin, and she was advised to follow up with her primary care physician for further management of her conditions.

the physical therapy service for assistance with strength and 
mobility. The sternal wound is noted to have some irritation by 
the superior pole- possibly reaction to dermabond or sutures- it 
does not appear infected.  She will return to clinic next week 
for a wound check.   By the time of discharge on POD 5 the 
patient was ambulating freely, the wound was healing and pain 
was controlled with oral analgesics.  The patient was discharged 
home with ___ in good condition with appropriate follow up 
instructions.  Labs will be checked by ___ 2 days following 
discharge to follow-up on post-op blood loss anemia and

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with complaints of chest pain. She has a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, hypothyroidism, and depression. She was referred for a stress test, which revealed anterior ischemia, and was subsequently found to have three-vessel disease. She underwent a cardiac catheterization and was referred to cardiac surgery for surgical revascularization.

The patient's past medical history includes coronary artery disease, hypertension, hypothyroidism, depression, and ulcerative colitis. She has allergies to statins and has had adverse reactions to blood pressure medications.

The patient's diagnosis was severe three-vessel coronary artery disease, and she underwent a coronary artery bypass graft x 2. She was also found to have mild mitral regurgitation and trivial aortic regurgitation.

The patient's medications at discharge include aspirin, levothyroxine, lisinopril, polyethylene glycol, clopidogrel, furosemide, metoprolol, potassium chloride, ranitidine, tramadol, and insulin pump therapy.

The patient's physical examination revealed a pulse of 53, blood pressure of 124/54 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100% on room air. Her abdomen was soft and non-distended, and her extremities were warm and well-perfused.

age: 37. gender: M.  
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___

Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Gabapentin / Trazodone / Codeine
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
ETOH Withdrawl
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
Past Medical History:
* Subdural hematoma (___) from ___  
* Alcohol and polysubstance abuse  
* Hepatitis C virus infection  
* Mood disorder with multiple suicide attempts  
* ?PTSD, bipolar/anti-social personality/impulse/rage disorders  

* Migraines  
* Chronic lower back pain  
* MVA s/p chest tube placement in ___  
* Seizure disorder since ___ yo, alcohol withdrawal seizures  
(Please see note from ___ ___ which calls into 
question the veracity of this history)  
* Aspiration pneumonia treated at ___ from ___  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father was an alcoholic.  
 
Physical Exam:
___ well known to ___ for multiple alcohol related admissions, 
BIBA for ___ unresponsive on a park bench. 

 

The patient states that today he got back together with his 
long-term girlfriend/wife who brought him a family sized bottle 
of Listerine in the mall and then layed on bench and became 
unresponsive.  He states that they began to fight and then she 
beat him about the head and chest with his own cane.  She left 
and at a time distant to the assault he passed out on a park 
bench.  He states that he drank more of the listerine, "being 
the bigger man."  

 

EMS arrived and finger stick was found to be in the 150's. In 
the ER he opened his eyes and was able to communicate 
appropriately despite slurred speech. He adamantly claimed that 
he only drank listerine, and no other drugs.  Initial vitals 
were 99.1 100 144/78 20 100%. 

.

Plan was for CIWA and observation until sober re-evaluation.  
However after several hours in observation he began to withdraw 
and score on CIWA for tremulousness and tachycardia.  Given his 
seizure history and requirement of 6mg Ativan over an hour he 
was transferred to the ___.

.

 

On arrival here, he is alert, interactive and asking for pain 
meds

.

Of note Mr ___ has had multiple recent admissions as 
follows:

- ___ ICU w/ d/c AMA on ___ for presumed isopropyl alcohol 
intoxication and admission from ___ to ___ for presumed 
aspiration pneumonia on cefpodoxime/azithromycin 

- ___ ___ for fevers, CP, and productive cough cough.  

.  

- ___ ICU from ___ to ___. Patient was visiting his wife 
___ in the ICU when he was noted to become unresponsive.

- Durring his hospitalization ___ he called his ___ PCP and 
complained of not getting enough pain meds, he then told his PCP 
___ "if he didnt give him more pain meds he would put him in as 
much pain as he (___) was already in."  This resulted in the 
patient being banned from ___ clinic, patient relations 
involvement and an agreement by which Mr. ___ is not 
allowed to get any outpatient prescriptions from ___.

 

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 09:21PM URINE  HOURS-RANDOM
___ 06:40PM   ASA-NEG ACETMNPHN-NEG bnzodzpn-NEG 
barbitrt-NEG tricyclic-NEG

___ 10:31PM BLOOD ASA-NEG Ethanol-82*
___ 10:31PM BLOOD Osmolal-314*
___ 06:15AM BLOOD Osmolal-___ with complicated social situation and multiple ___ 
admission for ingestions of alcohol and its related denatured 
counterparts.

.

Listerine Ingestion: 

Per the ingredient list Listerine is 40% etoh and also includes 
a salicylate.  Mr ___ ETOH level on admission to the ICU 
was 85 while his salicylate level was negative.  It is likely 
that ETOH was driving all of his assorted issues.  This likely 
explained his lowish anion gap metabolic acidosis on admission.  
Using the formula that ETOH is corrected for in the osmolar gap 
by dividing by 3.8, his osmolar gap is accounted for by his ETOH 
level, making coingestion with isopropanol or ethylene glycol 
much less likely.  He scored only once on CIWA, over 18 hours 
ago, and currently has normal vital signs.  We will plan for 
discharge. 

- Per prior agreement he will not be discharged with 
prescriptions for any medications
.
Hypoxia:
Suspect medication induced hypoventilion c/b splinting leading 
to increased CO2 and thus increased CO2 admixture via the 
alveolar gas equation, stably in the low 90's overnight while 
asleep. Resolved morning of discharge.
.
Pain control:
This patient is a terrible candidate for opiates, and refuses 
nsaids, we used low dose tylenol and would not give opiates in 
any situation if possible.  Despite sleeping easily, he 
continued to request fioricet/fioranol for his migraines when he 
awakened, but this medication was not in his medication discarge 
list.  He was given tylenol.
.
Rib Pain:
No hct drop to raise c/f splenic rupture, no fractured ribs, no 
ptx
.
Multiple Psychiatric diagnoses:
Patient was continued on his home regimen, he should continue 
with his home supply at home.
.
?Seizure d/o history:
.
Doctor ___ recent note calls into question his seizure 
history; however, the patient comes in with a positive 
barbiturate level.   Given his lack of seizure disorders and 
previous plans, we will discharge him without a prescription for 
phenobarb.

.

Dicharge planning:

Please refer to the below note from Chief Resident ___ 
regarding his rules for discharge.
.  
" After discussion with the patient and his consulting services, 
we will not provide prescriptions for any of his reported home 
medication including clonazepam, carbamazepine, amitriptyline, 
olanzapine or mirtazapine. At this time, the risk of significant 
toxicity including death, in the setting of his ongoing 
substance abuse is greater the risk of any potential withdrawal 
symptoms.
.
After discussion with neurology we will provide the patient with 
a short duration of phenobarbital with planned Neurology Access 
Clinic follow up." 

 
Medications on Admission:
Meds he should be on that are no longer prescribed by ___:
.
thiamine HCl 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) 1,000 unit DAILY (Daily).  
folic acid 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
multivitamin Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
ibuprofen 400 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8 
hours) as needed for Pain.  
amitriptyline 50 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO HS (at 
bedtime).  
olanzapine 10 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO HS (at 
bedtime).  
mirtazapine 30 mg Tablet Sig: 1.5 Tablets PO HS (at bedtime). 

 
Discharge Medications:
Meds he should be on that are no longer prescribed by ___:
.
thiamine HCl 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY

Home

ETOH withdrawl

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Mr ___ you were admitted to the BI with alcohol withdrawl 
from drinking listerine.  As you know your previous actions at 
___ have resulted in our inability to provide you with any 
outpatient medications.  You must establish follow-up with 
health care for the homeless as soon as possible.  You also 
should follow up with neuro as soon as possible.
.
Please call ___ for the Homeless at ___ 

to schedule an appointment for PCP ___.

If you are feeling concerned about your mental health, you can

___.

Please call neurology at ___ to schedule an appointment

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 37-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital due to ethanol withdrawal after ingesting Listerine, which contains 40% ethanol. He has a history of substance abuse, including alcohol and polysubstance abuse, as well as a mood disorder with multiple suicide attempts and a possible diagnosis of PTSD, bipolar disorder, and anti-social personality disorder. He has also had multiple admissions for ingestions of alcohol and its related denatured counterparts.

The patient's past medical history includes a subdural hematoma, hepatitis C virus infection, seizure disorder, and chronic lower back pain. He has also had multiple recent admissions, including one for presumed isopropyl alcohol intoxication and another for presumed aspiration pneumonia.

The patient's physical exam was notable for his ability to communicate appropriately despite slurred speech. He was alert and interactive, and his vital signs were stable. He was diagnosed with ethanol withdrawal and was treated with CIWA and observation until sober re-evaluation.

The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of ethanol withdrawal and was advised to continue his home regimen, including his home supply of medications. He was also advised to avoid using Listerine and other denatured alcohols.

CT ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE HEAD: 
The CT angiography of the head demonstrates normal flow in the 
distal cervical internal carotid arteries with marked narrowing 
of both supraclinoid internal carotid arteries with diminished 
flow in the both MCA trunks. Flow is visualized normally in the 
anterior cerebral arteries as well as somewhat diminished flow 
is seen in the posterior circulation. Vascular structures are 
attenuated and it is difficult to evaluate for an aneurysm. 
Extensive collateral vascular structures are seen in the region 
of basal ganglia bilaterally. The superior sagittal and 
transverse sinuses are patent. The vein ___ and ___ 
sinus are also patent. The anterior portions of both internal 
cerebral veins are not well visualized, which could be secondary 
to blood within the third ventricle and focal mass effect.  
IMPRESSION:
1. Head CT shows intraventricular hemorrhage with dilated 
lateral ventricles due to hydrocephalus.
2. CT angiography of the head demonstrates attenuated internal 
carotid
arteries and middle cerebral arteries with collateral 
lenticulostriate
arteries indicative of a moyamoya pattern which could be 
secondary to
vasculitis. The arterial structures are quite attenuated for 
evaluation of
aneurysm, although none is obviously present. Further evaluation 
with
cerebral angiography is recommended. Although no obvious 
aneurysm or
arteriovenous malformation is seen but the conventional 
angiography can
provide better information of the arterial structures.

CT Head ___:
NON-CONTRAST HEAD CT: There has been interval decrease in the 
amount of
hyperdense blood in the left lateral ventricle and third 
ventricle and fourth ventricle. There has been decrease in 
amount of hydrocephalus in the interval since ___. 
The suprasellar cistern is patent. The basal cisterns are 
slightly narrowed; however, visualized. This demonstrates 
improvement since ___, where the basal cisterns 
were obliterated. A focal area of hypodensity in the right basal 
ganglia (2:11) is noted. Linear hyperdensity in the sulci of the 
left frontoparietal region (2:17) may represent a component of 
subarachnoid hemorrhage. Bilateral ventricular shunts from a 
frontal approach are stable in place. There has been interval 
resolution of previously seen pneumocephalus. There is minimal 
subcutaneous gas (2:26). There is no sclerotic or lytic bony 
lesion to suggest malignancy. Minimal mucosal thickening in the 
posterior right ethmoid air cells are noted. 
IMPRESSION:
1. Interval decrease in intraventricular hyperdense hemorrhage 
and interval
decrease in hydrocephalus and mass effect with interval 
visualization of the basal cisterns, which were obliterated on 
prior exam.
2. Focal hypodensity in the right basal ganglia may represent a 
focal area of infarction. This was not seen on prior exam.

MRI ___
IMPRESSION: Right intraventricular hemorrhage as on the previous 
CT.  
Acute/subacute right periatrial white matter infarct as seen on 
the previous CT examination. Signal changes in the right basal 
ganglia could be due to subacute/chronic hemorrhage. Increased 
signal in the right side of the midbrain probably due to 
subacute or chronic infarct in this location. No other acute 
infarct seen. Other findings as above. 

MRA OF HEAD: ___
Head MRA demonstrates bilateral supraclinoid internal carotid 
artery flow 
signal narrowing indicative of occlusive disease. The middle 
cerebral 
arteries are not fully visualized. Similar findings were seen on 
the previous CTA examination. In the posterior circulation, 
basilar artery is well visualized but diminished flow signal is 
seen in both posterior cerebral arteries. 
IMPRESSION: The MRA appearance has not significantly changed 
since the 
previous CTA examination. Diminished flow is seen in both middle 
cerebral 
arteries secondary to supraclinoid occlusive disease. 

U/S abdomen:
___
IMPRESSION: Normal right upper quadrant ultrasound without 
evidence of 
cholecystitis or intra- or extra-hepatic biliary ductal 
dilatation. 
  
CT HEAD ___: s/p removal of EVDs
IMPRESSION: 
1. Stable appearance of right ventricular hemorrhage, with blood 
products 
layering dependently in the occipital horn of the right lateral 
ventricle. No new hemorrhage. 
2. Stable ventricular size.

fluctuations between theta frequency slowing and higher voltage

**The patient underwent emergent bilateral EVD placement in the

on the previous

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital because you were unresponsive. 
You were found to have a bleed in your brain. Imaging of your 
vessels in your brain showed a condition called ___ 
Syndrome. Subsequently, you suffered a stroke that is causing 
your left sided weakness. 

You will be discharged to rehab and have been started on a 
number of medications listed below.

Please attend all followup appointments as listed below. 

GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS
WOUND CARE
ÂYou or a family member should inspect your wound every day and 
report any of the following problems to your physician. 
ÂKeep your incision clean and dry.
ÂYou may wash your hair with a mild shampoo 24 hours after your 
sutures are removed.
ÂDo NOT apply any lotions, ointments or other products to your 
incision.   
ÂDO NOT DRIVE until you are seen at the first follow up 
appointment.
ÂDo not lift objects over 10 pounds until approved by your 
physician.

DIET
Usually no special diet is prescribed after this procedure. A 
normal well balanced diet is recommended for recovery, and you 
should resume any specially prescribed diet you were eating 
before your surgery. 

MEDICATIONS
ÂTake all of your medications as ordered.  You do not have to 
take pain medication unless it is needed.  It is important that 
you are able to cough, breathe deeply, and is comfortable enough 
to walk.   
ÂDo not use alcohol while taking pain medication. 
ÂMedications that may be prescribed include: 
oNarcotic pain medication such as Dilaudid (hydromorphone).  
oAn over the counter stool softener for constipation (Colace or 
Docusate). If you become constipated, try products such as 
Dulcolax, Milk of Magnesia, first, and then Magnesium Citrate or 
Fleets enema if needed). Often times, pain medication and 
anesthesia can cause constipation.
ÂUnless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc, as this can increase your chances of bleeding. 

ACTIVITY
The first few weeks after you are discharged you may feel tired 
or fatigued. This is normal. You should become a little stronger 
every day. Activity is the most important measure you can take 
to prevent complications and to begin to feel like yourself 
again. In general:
ÂFollow the activity instructions given to you by your doctor 
and therapist.
ÂIncrease your activity slowly; do not do too much because you 
are feeling good.
ÂYou may resume sexual activity as your tolerance allows.
ÂIf you feel light headed or fatigued after increasing 
activity, rest, decrease the amount of activity that you do, and 
begin building your tolerance to activity more slowly.
ÂDO NOT DRIVE until you speak with your physician.
ÂDo not lift objects over 10 pounds until approved by your 
physician.
ÂAvoid any activity that causes you to hold your breath and 
push, for example weight lifting, lifting or moving heavy 
objects, or straining at stool.
Â   Do your breathing exercises every two hours.  
Â   Use your incentive spirometer 10 times every hour, that you 
are awake.  

WHEN TO CALL YOUR SURGEON:
With any surgery there are risks of complications. Although your 
surgery is over, there is the possibility of some of these 
complications developing. These complications include: 
infection, blood clots, or neurological changes. Call your 
Physician ___ if you Experience:

ÂConfusion, fainting, blacking out, extreme fatigue, memory 
loss, or difficulty speaking.
ÂDouble, or blurred vision. Loss of vision, either partial or 
total.
ÂHallucinations
ÂNumbness, tingling, or weakness in your extremities or face.
ÂStiff neck, and/or a fever of 101.5F or more.
ÂSevere sensitivity to light. (Photophobia)
ÂSevere headache or change in headache.
ÂSeizure
ÂProblems controlling your bowels or bladder.
ÂProductive cough with yellow or green sputum.
ÂSwelling, redness, or tenderness in your calf or thigh.

Call ___ or go to the Nearest Emergency Room if you Experience:
ÂSudden difficulty in breathing.
ÂNew onset of seizure or change in seizure, or seizure from 
which you wake up confused.
ÂA seizure that lasts more than 5 minutes.

Important Instructions Regarding Emergencies and After-Hour 
Calls
ÂIf you have what you feel is a true emergency at any time, 
please present immediately to your local emergency room, where a 
doctor there will evaluate you and contact us if needed. Due to 
the complexity of neurosurgical procedures and treatment of 
neurosurgical problems, effective advice regarding emergency 
situations cannot be given over the telephone.
ÂShould you have a situation which is not life-threatening, but 
you feel needs addressing before normal office hours or on the 
weekend, please present to the local emergency room, where the 
physician there will evaluate you and contact us if needed.

 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
discharge_summary: The patient is a 38-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital after collapsing at home. She was found to have an intraventricular hemorrhage and was intubated. The patient has a history of diabetes and was found to have a moyamoya pattern on CT angiography, which could be secondary to vasculitis. She underwent a cerebral angiogram, bilateral EVD placement, and PEG placement. The patient's physical exam revealed an unresponsive patient with fixed bilateral pupils and no corneal reflex. Her laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, blood glucose, and creatinine levels. The patient was prescribed medications at discharge, including antibiotics and anticonvulsants.

Impression:
 "3.2 x 3.7 cm round, heterogeneously enhancing mass centered

postcontrast enhancement. 
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. Expected postsurgical changes, as described, with a small 
fluid collection 
at the right craniotomy bed likely representing a seroma.

Brief Hospital Course:

Right cerebellar mass. The patient was admitted to the

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions
Brain Tumor

Surgery
ÂYou underwent surgery to remove a brain lesion from your 
brain. 

ÂFrozen preliminary was: Medulloblastoma
ÂPlease keep your incision dry until your staples are removed. 
ÂYou may shower at this time but keep your incision dry.
ÂIt is best to keep your incision open to air but it is ok to 
cover it when outside. 
ÂCall your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
ÂWe recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
ÂYou make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
ÂNo driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
ÂIf you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
ÂNo contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications
Â***Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
ÂYou may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
ÂYou may experience headaches and incisional pain. 
ÂYou may also experience some post-operative swelling around 
your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the second and third day of surgery.  You apply 
ice or a cool or warm washcloth to your eyes to help with the 
swelling. The swelling will be its worse in the morning after 
laying flat from sleeping but decrease when up. 
ÂYou may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
ÂFeeling more tired or restlessness is also common.
ÂConstipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
ÂSevere pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
ÂFever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
ÂNausea and/or vomiting
ÂExtreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
ÂSevere headaches not relieved by pain relievers
ÂSeizures
ÂAny new problems with your vision or ability to speak
ÂWeakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
ÂSudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
ÂSudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
ÂSudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
ÂSudden severe headaches with no known reason

 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
discharge_summary: The patient is a 28-year-old male who was admitted to the Neurosurgery service with a chief complaint of headache, neck pain, and numbness in his left fingers. He had a history of knee surgery and wisdom teeth removal. He was allergic to amoxicillin. The patient presented with a progressively worsening headache, neck pain, and numbness in his left fingers over the last three weeks. He was transferred to the hospital from another emergency room and was found to have a right cerebellar mass on CT head. The patient underwent a suboccipital craniotomy for tumor resection and was diagnosed with a possible medulloblastoma, hemangioblastoma, or metastasis. At discharge, the patient was comfortable, oriented, and had normal neurological function. He was prescribed medications for pain control and was scheduled for follow-up appointments.

Discharge Instructions:
It has been a privilege to take care of you ___ 
___.
.
You were hospitalized because your heart was beating very slowly 
because of an abnormality in the electrical wiring system of 
your heart; you have a condition known as complete heart block.
.
You underwent an emergency procedure to implant a pacemaker into 
your chest that provides your heart with a regular electrical 
current to ensure that it beats at the correct rhythm. You 
tolerated the procedure well and the pacemaker is functioning 
correctly. This pacemaker will hopefully help to prevent 
recurrence of the fatigue that you have been experiencing.
.
You should avoid raising your arms above your head, and should 
also avoid heavy lifting, for the next several weeks.  Do not 
remove the steri-strips over the site where the pacemaker was 
placed.

Implantation of a pacemaker is surgical procedure, which is why 
you will require antibiotics to prevent infections. The 
following is your antibiotic regimen:
# START: Clindamycin 300 mg every 6h for 1 day
.

regimen is the following:

CP
**Take up to 3 tablets 5 minutes apart then call ___ if pain 
does not resolve.**
# CONTINUE: Cholestyramine 4 gram packet daily
# CONTINUE: Ezetimibe 10 mg daily
.
We decreased the dose of your Gabapentin to 300mg daily. This 
dose is based on your kidney function levels.  You can discuss 
the dosing with your primary care doctor next week.

Please continue to take all of your other medications as 
previously prescribed. 
.
Please attend the follow-up appointments detailed below.

___

discharge_summary: The patient is a 57-year-old female who presented to the emergency department with symptoms of syncope and was found to have a high-grade multi-level AV block with a heart rate of 40 beats per minute. She has a history of bradycardia, diastolic congestive heart failure, and chronic kidney disease. She was admitted to the hospital and underwent a pacemaker placement procedure, which was successful. At the time of discharge, she was hemodynamically stable with a heart rate of 40 beats per minute. She was prescribed several medications, including Torsemide, Lisinopril, Cholestyramine, Ezetimibe, ASA, Albuterol Sulfate Nebs, ADVAIR DISKUS, SINGULAIR, Fexofenadine, LORATADINE, and TRAZODON.

History of Present Illness:
___ G2P1 presents with one week of intermittent stabbing RLQ 
pain. She initially presented to ___ and was transferred 
here for GYN eval. Notably she lives in ___ and
has been in ___ visiting her boyfriend. Her pain started 
sometime around ___. Presented initially as intermittent stab 
"like a knife being twisted into my lower abdomen." Always on R. 
Lasts for several minutes, sometimes longer, then resolves. Has 
baseline aching in RLQ. Has not been bad enough or persistent 
enough that she needed to reduce her overall activity level. She 
does not associate it with specific movements or activities. She 
denies heavy lifting or strenuous activity. She denies nausea or 
vomiting. She says that sometimes the pain is increased when 
straining for bowel movements so she has been taking stool 
softeners that help. She was acutely in pain late last week in 
___ at the ___ game, so she drank heavily which 
helped with the pain. She says that over the last few days the 
pain has gotten worse and more frequent. She was initially 
concerned that her IUD had perforated. She has been having 
vaginal bleeding about 1 light tampon Q3-4 hours over the last 
week associated with all of this. Has been amenorrheic with the 
Mirena with only rare episodes of spotting. She denies abnormal 
vaginal discharge or odor and has
only been sexually active with her partner.

used

Pelvic U/S ___: Right-sided paraovarian mass; both the mass 
and ovary demonstrate normal blood flow; small amount of free 
fluid nearby. Intermittent torsion cannot be excluded. MR can be 
considered for further workup of the mass. 
F/U Pelvic U/S ___: Right adnexal mass and pathology of 
uncertain origin
MRI Pelvis ___: (wet read) No evidence of appendicitis. 
Enlarged ovary measuring 5.8 cm maximally. No dominant cyst. 
Significant edema within ovary, however right ovary enhances 
post contrast. No evidence of a tubo-ovarian abscess. Findings 
most in keeping with intermittant torsion or infective process 
involving right ovary. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the GYN service with concern for PID 
vs. tubo-ovarian abscess vs. chronic appendicitis based on 2 
pelvic ultrasounds and a pelvic MRI which was consistent with 
her presentation of intermittent RLQ pain and increased WBC 
count despite being afebrile.  The decision was then made to go 
to the operating room where a laparoscopic appendectomy was 
performed as well as lysis of adhesions.  Please see operative 
report for full details.  Post-operatively she was admitted to 
the GYN service.  Her post-operative course was uncomplicated.  
She was able to tolerate a regular diet, ambulate, void after 
her foley catheter was removed and control her pain with oral 
medications.  She received 36 hours of IV gentamicin and 
clindamycin and remained afebrile for her entire hospital stay.  
Her white blood cell count came down to 8.7 on post-op day 2.  
She was discharged on post-operative day 2 with two weeks of 
flagyl and doxycycline and told to follow-up with her primary 
gynecologist in ___ in 3 weeks for a post-operative check.

2. Lexapro 10mg daily, 
3. Xanax 1mg TID prn anxiety.

(Daily).

(Daily).

PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain: do not exceed 4g 
acetaminophen in 24 hours.
Disp:*15 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
6. ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*1*
7. doxycycline 100 mg PO BID for 14 days (faxed to ___ 
via ___)
8. flagyl 500 mg PO BID for 14 days (faxed to ___ via 
___)

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Abdominal pain concerning tubo-ovarian abscess, PID, chronic 
appendicitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Call your doctor for:  
* fever > 100.4  
* severe abdominal pain  
* difficulty urinating  
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr  
* abnormal vaginal discharge  
* redness or drainage from incision  
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication  

General instructions:  
* Take your medications as prescribed.  
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.  
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol  
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs  
* No strenuous activity, nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no 
douching, no sex), no heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for 6 
weeks.  
**if no cervix p LSC hyst, nothing in vagina for 3 months  
* You may eat a regular diet.  

Incision care:  
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.  
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.  
* If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
visit.
  
To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___
 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
discharge_summary: The patient is a 35-year-old female who presented with intermittent right lower quadrant pain. She had a history of abnormal pap smears and was s/p laser vaporization of dysplasia. She was admitted to the hospital with concern for PID, tubo-ovarian abscess, or chronic appendicitis. A laparoscopic appendectomy and lysis of adhesions were performed, and the patient's post-operative course was uncomplicated. She was discharged with medications for pain, constipation, and antibiotics, and was instructed to follow up with her primary gynecologist in three weeks. The patient's allergies and adverse reactions are listed as no known allergies or adverse drug reactions.

discharge_summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with dyspnea on exertion. She has a history of NSTEMI, cardiac catheterization, and COPD. She was transferred from another hospital for cardiac catheterization after presenting with chest pain and shortness of breath on exertion. The patient has allergies to penicillins and morphine.

The patient's diagnosis is 2-vessel coronary artery disease with thrombus in the ramus and occluded LCx with thrombus after DES. She underwent cardiac catheterization and PCI/DES to the LCx and POBA to the ramus.

The patient's past medical history includes diabetes, dyslipidemia, hypertension, NSTEMI, mild aortic stenosis, and chronic kidney disease. She also has a history of TIA, COPD, asthma, gout, and GERD.

The patient's physical examination revealed a well-appearing patient with a normal blood pressure and oxygen saturation. Her cardiac examination showed a regular rhythm with distant heart sounds and a soft systolic murmur.

The patient's discharge medications include amlodipine, atorvastatin, diltiazem, losartan, ASA, and lasix. She was also prescribed Plavix and heparin.

The patient's discharge summary notes that she is doing well with no symptoms of shortness of breath or chest pain. Her vital signs are stable, and she is able to ambulate without difficulty.

Discharge Instructions
Spine Surgery without Fusion

Surgery
Â Your dressing was removed the second day after surgery. 
Â Your incision is closed with staples. You will need staple 
removal. Please keep your incision dry until staple removal.
Â Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site. 
Â Please avoid swimming for two weeks after suture/staple 
removal.
Â Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
Â We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
Â You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
Â No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
Â No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 

Medications
Â ***Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
Â You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
Â It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation. 

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:

site.

Output:
discharge_summary:
Mrs. [Name], a 60-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital for lumbar stenosis. She had undergone an L3-L4 laminectomy for lumbar stenosis in the past and had developed pain down her right leg over the last year. She underwent an elective L2-3 and L4-5 laminectomies plus right L4-5 microdiscectomy, which was uneventful initially. However, she developed right lower extremity weakness and new radicular pain, and a small hematoma collection was found, which required re-exploration. She was discharged with paresthesias in her right lower extremity and weakness in her right hip flexor and knee flexors and extensors.

The patient has a history of diabetes, cutaneous candidiasis, hip pain, vitamin D deficiency, hepatic steatosis, hypothyroidism, sleep apnea, and hypertension. She has allergies to penicillins, cephalosporins, codeine, Lipitor, econazole, nitrate, peppers, Flagyl, ProAir HFA, sage, nystatin, and Victoza.

The patient's diagnosis is lumbar stenosis, and she underwent procedures including L2-3 and L4-5 laminectomies and right L4-5 microdiscectomy. She was prescribed medications including acetaminophen, bisacodyl, diazepam, docusate sodium, gabapentin, glucagon, heparin, insulin, milk of magnesia, oxyCODONE, polyethylene glycol, senna, artificial tears, atenolol, levothyroxine, pravastatin, and vitamin D.

The patient was discharged to extended care and was instructed to follow up with her neurosurgeon. She was advised to avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, or other strenuous exercise until her follow-up appointment and to take pain medications as directed.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ yo RHW with a history of a R temporal 
lobectomy and refractory epilepsy who presents as an LTM 
admission for characterization of events after ambulatory EEG 
revealed epileptiform activity over the left temporal lobe. 
She has been having events which she describes as dizzy spells 
with
some leg weakness. These were clustering in ___ and she has 
not had any events in the past several weeks. Given the concern 
that these represented a new seizure type, the patient was 
admitted for longterm continuous video EEG monitoring.

The patient was slowly tapered off of Lamictal. She had a few 
pushbuttons for body twitching that had no EEG correlate, 
however she did not have any of the typical dizzy spells. She 
also did not have any crying spells, which had been a prior 
seizure semiology for her. Her EEG showed rhythmic slowing with 
sharp features in the L hemisphere, but no frank epileptiform 
discharges or seizures. 
The patient was therefore restarted on her Lamictal at a reduced 
dose of 300mg BID. She was also started on Vimpat and titrated 
up to 100 mg BID by discharge. She will remain on his dose until 
follow up with Dr. ___ on ___. 

The patient was monitored on cardiac telemetry and remained in 
atrial fibrillation with no pauses, rapid rates, or other 
arrhythmias. She was continued on atenolol, digoxin and ASA.

discharge_summary: The patient is a 44-year-old female who presents to the neurology service with a chief complaint of dizzy spells. She has a history of refractory epilepsy and a prior right temporal lobectomy due to an oligodendroglioma. She has been experiencing episodes of dizziness, nausea, and vomiting, followed by bilateral leg weakness, which have been occurring for several months. Her past medical history includes epilepsy, atrial fibrillation, iron deficiency anemia, depression, GERD, and ADHD. She has been treated with multiple antiepileptic drugs, including Lamictal, which was tapered off during her hospital stay. The patient's physical examination is normal, with the exception of an irregular heart rhythm. Her neurologic examination reveals normal cognitive function, with no deficits in sensation, motor function, or coordination. The patient's EEG monitoring showed frequent bursts of left temporal theta slowing, but no electrographic seizures. She was admitted for long-term continuous video EEG monitoring to characterize her events and determine the cause of her symptoms.
