Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old man with history of hypertension, CAD s/p DES to LCx 
(___), dyslipidemia, osteoporosis, and chronic renal 
insufficiency who presented from home s/p fall with leukocytosis 
and multifocal infiltrates on CXR found to have aspiration 
pneumonia and severe dysphagia.  
.
#Fall: Patient fell without any prodromal symptoms and ___ 
post-ictal state.  History was most consistent with mechanical 
fall and patient with history of rare falls in past.  ___ 
evidence of ischemic changes or arrhythmia on EKG.  Last echo in 
___ with ___ systolic dysfunction or obstructive pathology.  He 
was not orthostatic on evaluation.   
.  
#Delirium: Patient presented from home after a fall and 
developed delirium while hospitalized.  His delirium was 
initially complicated by severe agitation requiring a 1:1 aide 
___, two point restraints, and occasional anti-psychotics to 
calm him when he became a safety threat. Delirium attributed to 
hospitalization, NSTEMI and pneumonia. Attempted to re-orient 
patient and normalize sleep wake cycle with good success.  His 
delirium was predominantly hypoactive during the last week of 
his admission.  
.
#Dysphagia:  His dysphagia was a chronic problem that was 
acutely worsened by his fall and subsequent delirium.  
Swallowing function extremely poor on video swallow, and he 
continued to aspirate daily.  He was kept NPO on aspiration 
precautions with nutrition via PPN in the hope that his delirium 
would clear and he would regain his strength to swallow back at 
baseline.  He had a repeat video swallow which revealed 
persistent poor swallowing function.  The family decided that 
regardless of the aspiration risk, Dr. ___ want to eat 
and would assume the risk.  They chose a modified diet in order 
to slightly lessen a large aspiration risk.
.
#Pneumonia: Patient with significant leukocytosis with 
neutrophilia and ___ localizing symptoms on admission. Initial 
CXR with multifocal opacities and left pleural effusion 
concerning for pneumonia but ___ new cough, SOB, or fevers at 
home. ___ recent hospitalizations. Received a dose of 
levofloxacin in the ED. Levofloxacin was discontinued as it was 
not felt that patient had a clinical pneumonia, but more likely 
an asiration pneumonitis (white count normalized overnight). 
However, when patient developed a new oxygen requirement in the 
setting of delirium concern for a developing infectious process 
increased and he was started on vanco/CTX/flagly to cover HCAP 
and aspiration pneumonia. Patient triggered several times for 
hypoxia which was felt secondary to poor clearance of secretions 
and mucus plugging. He received chest ___, mucomyst nebs, 
oropharynx suctioning, and humidified supplemental oxygen.  He 
continued to aspirate during his hospital course with transient 
desaturations.
.
#Pleural effusions: His course was also complicated by pleural 
effusions necessitating right thoracentesis of 900 cc on ___ and 
left thoracentesis of 1.4 L on ___.  Pleural fluid cytology was 
negative for malignant cells. 
.  
#NSTEMI: Patient with history of CAD s/p DES to left cx in ___ 
for 70% lesion. Reported a single episode of chest pain the 
night prior to admission which was short lived and self 
resolved. Reported that he typically gets it once a week. 
Troponins were initially checked and elevated - attributed to 
underlying chronic renal insufficiency. CK/MB flat. In the 
setting patient's acute change in mental status another set of 
enzymes were checked and these ended up initially peaking 
(troponin at 0.50, CKMB 25). Cardiology was consulted and felt 
patient's symptoms were most likely related to demand ischemia 
in the setting of underlying pulmonary pathology and agitation. 
He was given aspirin (PO or PR) but further anticoagulation was 
not started. Echocardiogram was of poor quality but show ___ 
major wall motion abnormalities.  Statin was transiently held 
given patient's aspiration risk and NPO status.  Troponin was 
found to continue to rise to 1.28 ___K-MB and CK 
confirming prior event.
.  
#Chronic renal insufficiency: Baseline creatinine of 1.7. 
Patient trended down to 1.4 during hospitalization as he was 
given PPN and IV fluids. 
.  
#Hypertension: Intermittently hypertensive when agitated.  He 
was continued on home lisinopril when taking POs. 
.
#Enterococcus in Urine: Bland UA but enterococcus (10K-100K) on 
culture. This was felt to be a sign of colonization rather than 
acute infection and thus patient was not treated for UTI. 
.  
#BPH: ___ active issues. Continued home finasteride.   
.  
#Anemia: Chronic in nature. Patient at baseline. ___ signs of 
active bleeding.   
.  
#Osteoporosis: He was followed by Dr. ___ was on 
Actonel as an outpatient. Next BMD scan was due on ___.  ___ 
fractures on CT head or spine, so he was continued outpatient 
calcium and vitamin D.
.
#Code Status: The patient was full code at the beginning of his 
admission, however, his HCP changed it to DNR/DNI prior to the 
end of his admission.  We had a series of family meetings during 
this admission.  This decision was made in accordance with what 
his wife deemed his goals of care: to be home and to avoid tubes 
and drains.  He was discharged home and the family chose to 
enroll him in hospice care.  He was discharged on a modified 
diet and his family understood that he had a 100% chance of 
repeat aspiration, and that it was impossible to predict when he 
would have a significant aspiration.  They signed the DNR/DNI 
forms, and will call the hospice nurse should he have a 
recurrent event.

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 91-year-old male who presented to the emergency department after falling at home. He reported a mild episode of chest tightness the previous night, which he attributed to gas pain. He has a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. On admission, his physical examination revealed a small abrasion on his head, poor inspiratory effort, and decreased breath sounds in his left lung base. Laboratory results showed leukocytosis, and a chest X-ray was concerning for multifocal pneumonia with bilateral pleural effusions.

The patient underwent thoracentesis on two occasions and was prescribed levofloxacin and tetanus vaccination. He was also given 1 liter of normal saline and had a CT scan of his spine, which showed moderate central spinal canal narrowing at C3-C4. He was discharged with a diagnosis of pneumonia and bilateral pleural effusions.

The patient's medications at discharge included levofloxacin, tetanus vaccination, and unspecified medications. He had a history of allergies to sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim.

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of abdominal bloating and weight loss. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes, and was previously diagnosed with high-grade B cell lymphoma and underwent 6 cycles of chemotherapy (EPOCH-R). He presents with diffuse gastric wall thickening around the gastroesophageal junction and an 11 mm bladder wall lesion, which is concerning for refractory high-grade lymphoma. He was transferred to the hospital for initiation of chemotherapy.

The patient's past medical history includes treatment with Cytoxan, Nitrogen Mustard, Rituximab, and other medications. He has a family history of CAD and CVA/HTN.

Upon admission, the patient's physical exam was normal, with no acute distress or abnormalities noted. His labs showed anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. He underwent imaging studies, including a TTE and CT neck without contrast, which showed normal biventricular cavity sizes with preserved regional and global systolic function, mild aortic regurgitation, and no lymphadenopathy.

At discharge, the patient's physical exam was again normal, with no acute distress or abnormalities noted. His labs showed improvement in his anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. He was prescribed medications, including mirilax and Colace, and was advised to follow up with his primary care physician.

The patient has allergies to Bactrim and has a history of anemia, gout, and hypertension. He is currently taking medications for his hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes.

discharge_summary: The patient is a 62-year-old male who was admitted with a chief complaint of fever, rinorrhea, and a non-productive cough. He has a history of refractory biphenotypic leukemia, disseminated fusarium infection, and multiple prior treatments, including hyperCVAD, decitabine, and MEC. He has also had admissions for pericardial effusions, pleural effusions, and VRE bacteremia. At the time of admission, his platelet count was 10K, and he was receiving transfusion support. He was treated with Bipap and antibiotics, and his empyema and effusions improved. He was discharged on 4 additional days of cefepime for a total of 5 days. The patient's medications at discharge included voriconazole, linezolid, and cefepime.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital after experiencing an asystolic arrest and complete heart block while participating in cardiac rehabilitation. He has a history of aortic stenosis, which was treated with aortic valve replacement, and conduction system disease with a combination of right bundle branch block, left anterior hemiblock, and first-degree heart block. He also has a history of mantle cell lymphoma, which is currently in remission and being treated with ibrutinib.

The patient's past medical history includes hypertension, dyslipidemia, and low testosterone, as well as a history of syncope and colon polyps. He has no history of premature coronary artery disease.

The patient's allergies include hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, lovastatin, and Arestin. He has no known adverse reactions to medications.

The patient's diagnosis is complete heart block, which was likely caused by increased vagal tone after exercise. He was treated with a pacemaker placement and was started on metoprolol XL 25mg to prevent further atrial tachycardia.

The patient's medications at discharge include metoprolol XL 25mg and antibiotics for one week. He will also require a D-stat for hemostasis and an antibiotic pouch due to his increased risk of infection.

The patient's physical exam was normal, with no acute distress, and his laboratory results were within normal limits.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions: Please call your surgeon or return to 
the emergency department if you develop a fever greater than 
101.5, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, 
pain unrelieved by your pain medication, severe nausea or 
vomiting, severe abdominal bloating, inability to eat or drink, 
foul smelling or colorful drainage from your incisions, redness 
or swelling around your incisions, or any other symptoms which 
are concerning to you. 
 
Diet: Stay on Stage III diet until your follow up appointment. 
Do not self advance diet, do not drink out of a straw or chew 
gum. 
 
Medication Instructions: 
Resume your home medications, CRUSH ALL PILLS. 
You will be starting some new medications: 
1.  You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain 
from your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and 
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications. 
2. You should begin taking a chewable complete multivitamin with 
minerals. No gummy vitamins. 
3. You will be taking Zantac liquid ___ mg twice daily for one 
month. This medicine prevents gastric reflux. 
4. You should take a stool softener, Colace, twice daily for 
constipation as needed, or until you resume a normal bowel 
pattern.
5. You must not use NSAIDS (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
drugs) Examples are Ibuprofen, Motrin, Aleve, Nuprin and 
Naproxen. These agents will cause bleeding and ulcers in your 
digestive system. 
 
Activity: 
No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may 
resume moderate exercise at your discretion, no abdominal 
exercises. 
 
Wound Care: 
You may shower, no tub baths or swimming. 

If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze.  
Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery. 
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.
 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 38-year-old male who was admitted for a revisional laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery due to morbid obesity. He has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus type 2, hyperlipidemia, and fatty liver. He also has a history of incisional hernia and has undergone previous surgeries, including laparoscopic adjustable gastric band and its removal. 

The patient's presenting symptoms were related to his morbid obesity, including concerns for his health, particularly diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He was initially managed with a morphine PCA and then transitioned to oral Percocet once tolerating a stage 2 diet. 

The patient underwent a successful revisional laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery and was discharged on a stage 3 diet. He was also prescribed medications to manage his pain, including OxycoDONE-Acetaminophen Elixir and Docusate Sodium. He was advised to avoid heavy lifting for 6 weeks and to resume moderate exercise at his discretion.

age: 43. gender: F.

History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ yo F with a history of triple negative BRCA1+ 
breast cancer diagnosed in ___. She underwent bilateral 
mastectomy and chemotherapy at that time. She has been generally 
lost to follow-up but was hospitalized recently for shortness of 
breath and found to have recurrence of her cancer.  
 Body imaging showed extensive probable metastases in the thorax 
with adenopathy and numerous pulmonary nodules as well as some 
left lung segment collapse. She did not have large pleural or 
pericardial effusions. The abdomen was benign including the 
liver. Bone scan, however, showed numerous abnormalities 
suggesting skeletal metastases. Widespread skeletal involvement 
is somewhat uncommon in triple-negative cancers, but the bone 
scan compared to prior scans does show a marked change. Her 
tumor marker is mildly elevated. She has some hoarseness, which 
likely reflects left recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement given 
the high concentration of disease in her left upper chest.  

 She now comes in because reports that she has had a severe 
headache and nausea for the past 48 hours. She reports that she 
has been waking up with a headaches every morning this week; 
however, this headache has persisted since yesterday and has not 
resolved. She reports she has been feeling nauseous and has not 
been able to each much. Reports that today she "vomited up 
bile." She denies dizziness, lightheadedness, or syncope. 
Reports that she has had difficulty seeing out of her L eye and 
"can only see half a word" when she reads.  

 In the ED, she had a head CT that showed:  
 There are multiple intracranial metastatic lesions. A lesion in 
the right occipital lobe best seen on series 602 B image 31 
measures approximately 3.1 x 3.1 cm and is complicated by a 
small amount of intralesional hemorrhage. There is associated 
vasogenic edema. Additional lesions are seen, for example and 
extra-axial lesion on series 2, image 23 abutting the inner 
table of the frontal bone in a left para falcine location. A 
small hyperdense lesion at the left parietal vertex is seen on 
series 2, image 25. A lesion abutting the  
 frontal lobe is seen on series 2, image 13 measuring 
approximately 1.4 x 3.7 cm. There is no midline shift or 
downward herniation though there is asymmetric effacement of 
right cerebral sulci compared to the left.  
 She was evaluated by neurosurgery who recommended Keppra, 
Dexamethasone, keeping SBP<140, and MRI scan.  
 
 On arrival to the floor, patient is tired, but otherwise well 
appearing.

otherwise negative.  
 
Past Medical History:
PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY  
She initially presented in early ___ with a multicentric 
high-grade triple-negative left breast cancer. The largest focus 
of invasive cancer was 5 cm. There was no lymphovascular 
invasion and her four sentinel lymph nodes sampled at the time 
of mastectomy in ___ were negative. The contralateral 
prophylactic right mastectomy was negative pathologically.  
 BRCA testing showed a BRCA1 mutation.  
 Thus, she had an advanced left breast cancer which was 
multifocal but no lymph node spread while the right breast was 
negative. Following recovery from her mastectomy and her 
bilateral ___ flap reconstructions, a port was inserted and she 
began dose-dense cyclophosphamide and doxorubicin in early ___. She received four doses of dose-dense cyclophosphamide and 
doxorubicin followed by weekly paclitaxel. Dr. ___ was 
consulted, but did not feel that she required post mastectomy 
radiation therapy based on free margins, the absence of 
lymphovascular invasion and the absence of nodal involvement.  
 Following her chemotherapy there was no additional systemic 
therapy given because of her triple-negative status. We did 
strongly encourage her to have a prophylactic bilateral BSO, but 
she opted to defer that following completion of her other 
therapy. In fact, this was never done and she had a long 
interval where she did not ___ for routine followup here.  
 She was recently seen for shortness of breath. Re-staging 
showed recurrent disease.

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 43-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a severe headache and nausea. She has a history of triple-negative breast cancer diagnosed in the past, which has recurred. She underwent bilateral mastectomy and chemotherapy, but did not receive post-mastectomy radiation therapy. She was recently seen for shortness of breath and was found to have extensive metastatic disease in her thorax, abdomen, and bones. 

The patient's past medical history includes HCV, liver failure due to Acetaminophen toxicity, and an eating disorder. She has a family history of colon cancer and dementia. 

On admission, the patient's physical examination was normal, except for bronchial breath sounds on the left and mild tenderness in the left upper quadrant of her abdomen. 

The patient's laboratory results showed mild elevation of her tumor marker, and her imaging studies showed multiple intracranial metastatic lesions with hemorrhage. 

The patient was treated with Keppra, Dexamethasone, and was recommended to have an MRI scan. She was also advised to keep her blood pressure below 140 mmHg. 

At discharge, the patient's vital signs were stable, and her physical examination was normal, except for a left-sided peripheral vision defect and weakness in her upper extremities.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o F with a h/o cholelithiasis, HTN, ___ 
___ tear, C-section, hysterectomy and suicidal ideation who 
initially presented to ___ for RUQ pain with US 
and MRCP findings of CBD dilation of ~8mm, transferred to ___ 
for potential EUS vs ERCP. The patient was admitted to the Acute 
Care Surgery service for further medical care.  

On HD1, Psychiatry was consulted for evaluation and management 
of SI while inpatient.  The patient was placed under ___, 
and 1:1 observation was provided given recent SI and possibility 
for exacerbation of mood with ongoing stressors and 
hospitalization. 

On HD1, the patient was taken to the operating room and 
underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy.  The patient tolerated 
this procedure well (reader, please refer to Operative Notes for 
further details).  After remaining hemodynamically stable in the 
PACU, the patient was transferred to the surgical floor. 

On POD1, the patient was written for a regular diet, her IV 
fluid were discontinued and she was started on oral pain 
medication.  Her foley catheter was removed and she voided 
without issue. On POD 2, psychiatry revisit the patient and were 
okay with discontinuing 1:1 and recommended continuing all her 
home psych medications,

During this hospitalization, the patient ambulated early and 
frequently, was adherent with respiratory toilet and incentive 
spirometry, and actively participated in the plan of care. The 
patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were 
used during this stay. 

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient was discharged to an inpatient

Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute cholecystitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure caring for you at the ___ 
___.  You were admitted to the Acute Care Surgery 
service with acute cholecystitis (gallbladder inflammation) and 
were taken to the operating room and had your gallbladder 
removed laparoscopically.  This procedure went well.  Your pain 
is better controlled and you are now tolerating a regular diet. 

The Psychiatry service met with you given your thoughts of 
self-harm, and have recommended that you be discharged to a 
Psychiatric facility for further mental health care.  

You are now medically cleared to be discharged from the 
hospital. Please note the following discharge instructions:

Please follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic at the 
appointment listed below.
 
ACTIVITY:
 
o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
o You may climb stairs. 
o  You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit.
o  Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about 
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies 
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
o  You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You 
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
o  You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
o  You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
You might feel somewhat depressed.
o  You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
o  All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
o Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages 
called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay).
o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This 
is normal.
o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid 
staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, 
please call your surgeon.
o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do 
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed.
o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you 
cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of RUQ pain. She has a history of cholelithiasis, hypertension, and a tear, as well as a C-section and hysterectomy. She also has a history of suicidal ideation and has previously been in therapy for PTSD, anxiety, and suicidal ideation following her mother's death. 

The patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was started on oral pain medication. She was also prescribed risperidone to manage her auditory hallucinations. At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs, and was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  During your hospitalization, you had surgery to 
remove unhealthy tissue on your lower extremity.  You tolerated 
the procedure well and are now ready to be discharged from the 
hospital.   Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a 
speedy and uneventful recovery.

LOWER  EXTREMITY AMPUTATION DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS

ACTIVITY 
ÂYou should keep your amputation site elevated and straight 
whenever possible.  This will prevent swelling of the stump and 
maintain flexibility in your joint.  
ÂIt is very important that you put no weight or pressure on 
your stump with activity or at rest to allow the wound to heal 
properly. 
ÂYou may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots, if 
applicable.  It will take time to learn to use a walker and 
learn to transfer into and out of a wheelchair.  

MEDICATION
ÂBefore you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
the medicine you should take at home.  If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  

ÂYou will likely be prescribed narcotic pain medication on 
discharge which  can be very constipating.  If you take 
narcotics,  please also take a stool softener such as Colace.   
If constipation becomes a problem, your pharmacist can suggest 
an additional over the counter laxative. 

ÂYou should take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours, as needed for 
pain.  If this is not enough, take your prescription narcotic 
pain medication.  You should require less pain medication each 
day.  Do not take more than a daily total of 3000mg of Tylenol.  
Tylenol is used as an ingredient in some other over-the-counter 
and prescription medications.  Be aware of how much Tylenol you 
are taking in a day.

BATHING/SHOWERING: 
ÂYou may shower when you feel strong enough but no tub baths or 
pools until you have permission from your surgeon and the 
incision is fully healed.
ÂAfter your shower, gently dry the incision well.   Do not rub 
the area. 

WOUND CARE:
ÂPlease keep the wound clean and dry. It is very important that 
there is no pressure on the stump.    If there is no drainage, 
you may leave the incision open to air.  
ÂYour staples/sutures will remain in for at least 4 weeks.  At 
your followup appointment, we will see if the incision has 
healed enough to remove the staples. 
ÂBefore you can be fitted for prosthesis (a man-made limb to 
replace the limb that was removed) your incision needs to be 
fully healed. 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
ÂOpening, bleeding or drainage or odor from your stump incision 

ÂRedness, swelling or warmth in your stump.
ÂFever greater than 101 degrees, chills, or worsening 
incisional/stump pain  

NO OTHER PROVIDER, EXCEPT YOUR VASCULAR SURGEON, SHOULD 
DETERMINE IF YOUR STAPLES ARE READY TO BE REMOVED FROM YOUR 
STUMP! 
  
IF THERE ARE ANY QUESTIONS, THE PROVIDER SHOULD CALL THE 
VASCULAR SURGERY OFFICE AT ___ TO DISCUSS.   THE 
STAPLES WILL BE REMOVED IN THE OFFICE AT YOUR FOLLOWUP 
APPOINTMENT WHEN IT IS DETERMINED BY THE VASCULAR SURGEON THAT 
THE WOUND HAS SUFFICIENTLY HEALED.

___
 

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 41-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital for right forefoot and ascending cellulitis. He has a history of multiple percutaneous interventions for bilateral lower extremity peripheral arterial disease, including a left below-knee amputation (BKA) in the past. He was informed that he would likely need a BKA on his right leg due to non-healing ulcers and was admitted for possible one or two staged amputation.

The patient's past medical history includes diabetes mellitus type 2, end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis, hypertension, dyslipidemia, obesity, asthma, sleep apnea, cocaine dependence, peripheral arterial disease, depression, HIV, and a history of HD line sepsis and PEA arrest.

The patient's allergies include erythromycin base. He was diagnosed with right BKA and underwent the procedure without complications. He was also prescribed vancomycin with hemodialysis for his infected right foot ulcers and cellulitis.

The patient's medications on admission included a preadmission medication list, which was accurate and complete. His discharge medications included sertraline, abacavir sulfate, albuterol inhaler, alprazolam, amlodipine, aspirin, atorvastatin, calcitriol, calcium acetate, clonazepam, docusate sodium, doxepin HCl, gabapentin, glargine, labetalol, lopinavir-ritonavir, loratadine, nephrocaps, polyethylene glycol, senna, and sevelamer hydrochloride.

The patient's physical examination revealed a well-healed left BKA and a right foot with gangrene, bogginess to the bottom of the first toe, and cellulitis along the plantar surface and lateral aspect of the foot up to the level of the ankle. His wound was described as very tender.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions: Please call your surgeon or return to 
the emergency department if you develop a fever greater than 
101.5, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, 
pain unrelieved by your pain medication, severe nausea or 
vomiting, severe abdominal bloating, inability to eat or drink, 
foul smelling or colorful drainage from your incisions, redness 
or swelling around your incisions, or any other symptoms which 
are concerning to you.

Diet: Stay on Stage III diet until your follow up appointment. 
Do not self advance
diet, do not drink out of a straw or chew gum.

Medication Instructions:
Resume your home medications, CRUSH ALL PILLS.
You will be starting some new medications:
1.  You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain 
from your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and 
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications.
2. You should begin taking a chewable complete multivitamin with 
minerals twice a day. No gummy vitamins.
3. You will be taking Zantac liquid ___ mg twice daily for one 
month. This medicine prevents gastric reflux.
4. You will be taking Actigall 300 mg twice daily for 6 months. 
This medicine prevents you from having problems with your 
gallbladder.
5. You should take a stool softener, Colace, twice daily for 
constipation as needed, or until you resume a normal bowel 
pattern.
6. You must not use NSAIDS (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
drugs) Examples are Ibuprofen, Motrin, Aleve, Nuprin and 
Naproxen. These agents will cause bleeding and ulcers in your 
digestive system.

Activity:
No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may 
resume moderate
exercise at your discretion, no abdominal exercises.

Wound Care:
You may shower, no tub baths or swimming. 
If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze. 
Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 29-year-old female who was admitted for weight reduction surgery. She has a history of morbid obesity, with a weight of 249.1 pounds and a body mass index (BMI) of 42.8. She has tried various diets and medications in the past, including Topiramate, but has not had significant weight loss. She has a family history of heart disease, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia.

The patient underwent a laparoscopic gastric bypass procedure without event and was discharged on postoperative day two. She was prescribed several medications, including Actigall, Zantac, Roxicet, Colace, Fluoxetine, Lorazepam, Levothyroxine, and Topiramate. She was also advised to follow a Stage III diet and to crush all pills.

The patient was instructed to resume her home medications, including CRUSH ALL PILLS, and to start taking new medications to treat pain, prevent gastric reflux, and prevent gallbladder problems. She was also advised to take a stool softener and to avoid using NSAIDS. She was instructed to avoid heavy lifting for six weeks and to resume moderate exercise at her discretion.

The patient is a 71-year-old female who was admitted for removal of her peritoneal dialysis catheter due to recurrent infections. She has a history of end-stage renal disease, hypertension, dyslipidemia, COPD, MGUS, anemia, obesity, and GERD. During her hospital stay, she underwent removal of her peritoneal dialysis catheter and placement of a tunneled hemodialysis line. discharge_summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male who was admitted for new onset atrial fibrillation and exertional dyspnea. He has a history of mitral valve prolapse, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, hypothyroidism, osteopenia, and lichen planus. He underwent a mitral valve replacement with a 31 mm Epic tissue valve and a modified left-sided maze procedure and left atrial appendage ligation. The patient's past medical history includes mitral regurgitation, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, hypothyroidism, osteopenia, and lichen planus. He has no known allergies or adverse drug reactions.

The patient's diagnosis is severe mitral regurgitation, which was treated with a mitral valve replacement. He underwent cardiac catheterization and was admitted for MV repair vs. replacement. The patient's medications at discharge include warfarin, levothyroxine, metoprolol, lisinopril, clobetasol, fluocinonide, lorazepam, acetaminophen, amiodarone, aspirin, docusate, furosemide, metoprolol tartrate, oxydone, polyethylene glycol, and potassium chloride.

The patient's physical examination revealed an irregular heart rate and rhythm, II/VI systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border, and apical higher pitched III/VI systolic murmur. His blood work showed a white blood cell count of 12.9, hemoglobin of 9.0, and platelet count of 2.84. His electrolyte levels were within normal limits.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted this hospitalization following a cardiac 
arrest. You underwent a cooling of your body temperature to help 
decrease any negative effects on the brain following cardiac 
arrest. The likely cause of your arrest is an arrythmia as a 
result of scarring from coronary artery disease. 

In order to assess the perfusion of the heart by the coronary 
arteries you underwent a cardiac catheterization which revealed 
multiple blockages in the conroary arteries. We were able to 
place a stent in one of the arteries; the obtuse marginal branch 
of the left circumflex artery that feeds the side portion of the 
heart muscle.

At the time of your cardiac arrest your heart pupming function 
was depressed. A most recent echocardiogram revealed that the 
pumping function has greatly improved since the time of your 
arrest.

You have been started on the following new medications:
Aspirin 81 mg daily: this is taken to decrease clot in the 
coronary arteries

Atorvastatin 80mg daily: this is a cholesterol medication taken 
to decrease worsening of plaque formation.

Lisinopril 5mg daily: this decreases the resistance the heart 
has to pump against and thereby decreased the blood pressure

Metoprolol XL 100mg daily: this medication decresases the 
workload of the heart by decreasing the heart rate and thereby 
the blood pressure

Ticagelor 90mg two times a day: This medication decreases the 
risk of clot formation where the stent was placed. 

KCL 20meq daily: you have required Potaassium daily since your 
admission. You should take this daily and then have labs checked 
on ___ by visiting nursing to assess your response. 

PLEASE CONTINUE:
Metformin 100mg XL twice a day for your diabetes
Sertraline 200mg daily for depression
Levothyroxeine 50mcg daily
 
PLEASE HOLD until seen by your PCP/Cardiologist:
Wellbutrin
Mirtazapine

****Failure to take the Ticagelor and the aspirin could result 
in a lifethreatening heart attack**** 

You have been set up with a Lifevest. The details of this device 
have been discussed with you. If you go into a lifethreatening 
arrythmia again, this device will detect that arrythmia and 
deliver an electric shock to return you to a normal sinus 
rythym. The plan is for you to eventually receieve an internal 
cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) in the future once your heart 
has been given time to recover from your recent cardiac arrest. 
This will be discussed in follow up with the electrophysiology 
team as an outpatient.

You should avoid stressful situations and exercise while you are 
wearing the lifevest. You also CANNOT drive with the lifevest. 
You may participate in your reguilar activities including 
walking as long as this does not cause you physical strain.  
  
You will need a variety of follow up appointments as detailed 
below.

You will need labs in 6 weeks to assess your liver function and 
cholesterol panel since we increased your statin or cholesterol 
medication.  You will also need your electrolytes and your 
kidney function checked on ___ as we have started 
you on a medication called Lisinopril and a potassium 
supplement. 

Today we discussed heart failure and the need to weigh yourself 
every day before breakfast as well as the improtance of 
following a low salt diet. If your weight goes up by more than 3 
lbs in 2 days you should call Dr. ___ cardiologist). 

If you have any questions or concerns related to your symptoms 
or your hospitalization you can call the heartline which has 
been given to you with your discharge paperwork. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 47-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a cardiac arrest. He was found to have severe 2-vessel coronary artery disease, with chronic total occlusion of the left circumflex artery and occlusion of the OM1 branch. He underwent a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with a drug-eluting stent (DES) in the OM1 branch. His past medical history includes diabetes, dyslipidemia, hypertension, depression, sleep apnea, and hypothyroidism. He has no known allergies or adverse reactions.

The patient's diagnosis includes moderate-severe regional and global systolic dysfunction due to coronary artery disease, mild global right ventricular systolic dysfunction, and mild mitral regurgitation. He was treated with aspirin, ticagrelor, and atorvastatin, and was also prescribed metoprolol and lisinopril.

The patient's medications at discharge include levothyroxine, sertraline, aspirin, atorvastatin, and metoprolol.

discharge_summary: The patient is a 51-year-old female who was admitted with chest pain and a history of CAD with prior MI. She presented with 3 days of persistent chest tightness and was found to have a posterior STEMI with occlusion of the distal circumflex artery. She underwent a left heart catheterization and was treated with a DES to the culprit vessel. She also had a non-culprit RCA lesion with diffuse irregularities. The patient's past medical history includes CAD, hypertension, CKD, hyperlipidemia, TIA, CVA, antiphospholipid syndrome, OSA, and fibromyalgia. She has allergies to morphine and fish oil. At discharge, the patient was prescribed medications including ticagrelor, aspirin, plavix, atorvastatin, metoprolol, and warfarin. She was also advised to continue using her CPAP machine for OSA. The patient developed several small hematomas during her hospital stay, but her CBC remained stable and she did not have evidence of internal bleeding. She was discharged with close cardiology follow-up.

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a left heel ulcer and cellulitis. She has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and depression, and has had multiple ulcerations and debridements in the past. She presented to the emergency department with a one-week history of increasing redness and pain in her left heel, which had worsened the day before her admission. She was treated with IV antibiotics and a culture of the wound was taken. The culture grew coagulase-negative Staphylococcus aureus and diptheroids, and she was started on Vancomycin and PO cipro and flagyl pending culture data. She was also treated with wet-to-dry dressing changes and remained afebrile with stable vital signs throughout her admission. She was discharged home on PO Bactrim and instructed to perform daily wet-to-dry dressing changes and follow up with her doctor in a week.

The patient's medications on admission included Lisinopril, Metformin, Oxybutynin Chloride, Percocet, Simvastatin, Spironolactone, Trazodone, and Multivitamin. Her discharge medications included Sulfamethoxazole-Trimethoprim, Budesonide-Formoterol, Lisinopril, Metformin, Simvastatin, Spironolactone, Trazodone, Fexofenadine, Multivitamin, Vitamin E, Ferrous Sulfate, and Oxybutynin Chloride.

The patient's discharge diagnosis was left heel ulcer and cellulitis, and her discharge condition was clear and coherent mental status, alert and interactive level of consciousness, and ambulatory-independent activity status.

Dear Ms ___, 

You were admitted to the ___ for the evaluation of your 
shortness of breath.  We performed many studies including a

arteries was causing your shortness of breath.  You underwent a

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with complaints of dyspnea on exertion and chest discomfort. She has a past medical history of CAD, DM with CKD, Afib, and HLP. She was recently hospitalized for volume overload and underwent ultrafiltration and diuresis. On admission, her troponin level was 0.08, and a d-dimer was positive. She underwent cardiac catheterization, which showed significant atherosclerotic disease in the left main coronary artery and left anterior descending artery. She was diagnosed with mitral regurgitation and had a left ventricular ejection fraction of unknown percentage.

The patient's medications at discharge include ASA 325 and SL nitroglycerin. She has a history of allergies to Motrin. Her physical examination was notable for a palpable pulse in the right and left carotid, femoral, popliteal, and dorsal pedal arteries. Her skin examination showed multiple areas of shallow ulceration and apparent desquamation on the dorsum of her right hand.

The patient's review of systems was negative for prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. She denied recent fevers, chills, or rigors.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the Thoracic Surgery service due 
to inability to tolerate POs. He was tachycardic at initial 
presentation thought to be due to dehydration as well as the 
pain and discomfort of his obstruction. This tachycardia had 
resolved prior to discharge with fluid resuscitation as well as 
Roxicet medication. 

On HD 2, the patient underwent EGD which showed a large gastric 
mass circumferentially at the GE junction across which an 
esophageal stent was successfully deployed. Biopsies were also 
taken as the biopsies from the OSH, although showing malignancy, 
were still undeterminate as to of which origin. 

He did well post-procedure and was able to tolerate a full 
liquid diet after the stent placement. Pain control also 
improved with liquid oxycodone-acetaminophen. 

At discharge, he was tolerating a full liquid diet including 
Ensure for nutritional support and was no longer tachycardic. He 
was much more comfortable with pain well controlled on Roxicet. 
He will follow up with Dr. ___ Dr. ___ oncology and 
appointments have already been made.

or solids. An EGD was performed and an esophageal stent was

Please call your doctor or return to the Emergency Department 
for the following:

food/Ensure drinks to maintain good nutritional input

discharge_summary: The patient is a 51-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital due to intolerance to solid foods and a gastric mass at the gastroesophageal junction. He had a history of dysphagia, regurgitation, and epigastric pain, which persisted despite self-resolved episodes. A CT scan showed a large gastric tumor extending to the esophagus with hepatic metastasis. He underwent an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with esophageal stent placement and biopsies were taken. The patient was tolerating a full liquid diet at discharge and was no longer tachycardic. He was prescribed oxycodone-acetaminophen for pain, pantoprazole for stomach acid reduction, and docusate sodium for bowel regularity. The patient was discharged home with instructions to follow up with his doctor and oncologist.

discharge_summary:
The patient is an 86-year-old female who was admitted with rectal bleeding from hemorrhoids. She has a history of atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, and congestive heart failure. She was previously taking coumadin, but it was stopped due to recurrent rectal bleeding. The patient underwent a hemorrhoidectomy and was found to have internal hemorrhoids. She was also diagnosed with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, severe aortic stenosis, mitral regurgitation, obstructive sleep apnea, and congestive heart failure.

The patient's medications at discharge include amiodarone, allopurinol, simvastatin, vitamin D3, nitroglycerin, docusate sodium, calcium carbonate, metoprolol succinate, valsartan, and furosemide. She was instructed to restart coumadin once spotting resolves and to follow up with her doctor and cardiologist as an outpatient.

The patient was discharged home with stable vital signs, controlled pain, and tolerating a diet. She was advised to take all of her medications as usual and to not restart coumadin or aspirin until she sees her doctor in clinic next week.

#s/p Fall:  
Presented after a fall from standing height and found to have a 
right intertrochanteric hip fracture with varus angulation. CT 
head with subgaleal hematoma but no intracranial hemorrhage, and 
CT C spine negative for traumatic injury. Fall appears to be 
purely mechanical secondary to underlying neuropathy and 
progressive weakness with possible acute decompensation in the 
setting of pneumonia. She had no LOC, but may have an 
orthostatic component as well contributing to lightheadedness 
given poor PO intake. Troponins obtained for pre-op workup were 
slightly elevated x3 (max 0.03). Likely ___ slight ___, EKGs w/o 
e/o MI. 

The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service with 
a right hip fracture. The patient was taken to the operating 
room on ___ for right hip ORIF, which the patient tolerated 
well. For full details of the procedure please see the 
separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from 
the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory 
recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The 
patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, 
and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. 
The patient was given ___ antibiotics and 
anticoagulation per routine. The patient worked with ___ who 
determined that discharge to rehab was appropriate.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
weight-bearing as tolerated in the right lower extremity, and 
will be discharged on ___ for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will 
follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough discussion was 
had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected 
post-discharge course including reasons to call the office or 
return to the hospital, and all questions were answered. The 
patient was also given written instructions concerning 
precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care. 
The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

 
#LLL pneumonia: CXR obtained on pre-op workup showed LLL 
opacity. Unclear if she had a true clinical pneumonia given she 
so did not have symptoms of pneumonia, but fall could be due to 
weakness in the setting of infection. Did not meet criteria for 
HAP. Treated with five day course of ceftriaxone and 
azithromycin.

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- weight bearing as tolerated on right lower extremity

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take subcutaneous heparin daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

FOLLOW UP:
Please follow up with Dr. ___ in the ___ Trauma 
Clinic ___ days post-operation for evaluation. Please call 
___ to schedule appointment.

Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission within ___ weeks and for and any new 
medications/refills.

Please follow up with your oncologist at your earliest 
convenience.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

discharge_summary:
The patient is an 88-year-old female who was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service with a right hip fracture after a fall from standing height. She has a history of gastric carcinoma, currently undergoing chemotherapy, and has undergone left ORIF of the hip. She presents with right hip pain and right intra-trochanteric fracture. The patient's past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy, rheumatoid arthritis, osteoporosis, vertigo, arthritis, coronary artery disease, and syncope. She has no known allergies or adverse drug reactions.

The patient underwent a right hip open reduction and internal fixation procedure, which she tolerated well. She was given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was discharged on oral medications, including antibiotics and anticoagulation, and was advised to follow up with her doctor routine. She was also given written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care.

The patient's diagnosis is a right hip fracture, and she will require ongoing management and follow-up care to ensure proper healing and recovery.

positive for gram-positive cocci in clusters, but this was 
speciated to coag negative staph and was likely a contaminant. 

#Leukocytosis: Initially elevated to ___ iso bacteremia as well 
chronic elevation from steroid use. Downtrending on discharge to 
baseline with treatment of bacteremia as above. Discharge WBC: 
16.8. 

#Septic Joint
Initially concerning for septic arthritis vs. trochanteric 
bursitis.
Atraumatic hip pain. Joint aspirate with 22K WBCs and Hct 22,
negative culture. However she had already received two days of 
antibiotics at the time of aspiration. She was seen by ortho, 
who thought her pain was likely trochanteric bursitis. GNRs 
would also be an atypical cause of septic arthritis, but the hip 
could have been seeded during her recent bacteremia. Rheum and 
ID both agreed with the diagnosis of a likely septic joint and 
recommend wash out, which was deferred by orthopedics. An MRI R 
hip was obtained notable for small effusion with no evidence of 
a septic joint. Rheumatology was concerned that she may not 
improve with antibiotics alone given the severity of her RA, 
however, the decision was made to treat the patient 
conservatively with IV antibiotics. Patient seemed to improve 
clinically with antibiotics with improved mobility at the joint 
so a wash-out was deferred in agreeance with all consulting 
services. She had a PICC line placed on ___ for continued 
antibiotics. 

#Incidental Uterine Mass
#Cervical stenosis
Incidentally found mass seen on her MRI of her R hip. She had a 
follow up pelvic US which showed a likely fibroid vs. polyp. The 
ultrasound also revealed a fluid filled uterine cavity 
concerning for cervical stenosis. The patient was asymptomatic. 
She will need outpatient gynecology follow-up. 

#ESRD on HD 
#Hyperkalemia
Initially became fluid overloaded and hyperkalemic in the 
setting of missing HD. Transferred to the ICU for 2 days until 
stabilized with emergent HD and returned to the floor. Her 
hyperkalemia was treated with insulin/Calcium. Discharge K 5.8 
after which she received HD. On MWF HD. Access: LUE AVF. 

#Macrocytic Anemia
Most likely secondary to ESRD. MCV 101-102. Folate normal. B12
low-normal 389. Recommend serum or urine MMA as outpatient to 
assess for B12 deficiency as a low normal B12 may still be 
deficient at the tissue level.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
===============
#Hypertension. Remained hypertensive to 180s, but asymptomatic.
Her home regimen was continued as below: 
On HD days: Hydral 25 BID, labetalol 300 BID
On non-HD days: Hydral 25 TID, labetalol 300 TID, amlodipine 10
On all days: Lisinopril 10
Her lisinopril was increased to 20 mg po daily in light of 
continued high blood pressures. 

#Rheumatoid arthritis 
Initially give 10 mg prednisone po daily and titrated down to 
7.5 mg as per rheumatology recs. 

#COPD on 2L home O2 
There is some concern that her respiratory disease is actually
due to ILD in the setting of her RA. Could consider PFTs as an
outpatient. She received O2 and her home nebulizers

#Hypothyroidism 
She was continued on levothyroxine 125 mcg daily. 

#Anxiety/depression 
She was continued on her home pregabalin, clonazepam, sertraline 
and trazodone.

admission. Consider up titration of her lisinopril as needed.

check for hyperkalemia

borderline low Vitamin B12 (389), which may contribute to 
patient's microcytic anemia

lung disease is due to her COPD or ILD secondary to RA, or a 
mixed picture. Also consider a sleep study to r/o OSA.

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 78-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of hip pain. She has a past medical history of rheumatoid arthritis, chronic heart failure, COPD, and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD). She also has a history of ESBL E. Coli bacteremia and has undergone two knee replacements. 

The patient was initially transferred to the floor, but was later transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to worsening respiratory distress and hypoxia. She was diagnosed with septic arthritis of the right hip and underwent arthrocentesis. 

The patient's medications at discharge include vancomycin, zosyn, and prednisone. She was also prescribed calcium gluconate and insulin/dextrose. 

The patient's physical examination revealed a tender right hip with pain on movement and limited range of motion. Her laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and pro-B-type natriuretic peptide. Her chest X-ray revealed diffuse interstitial opacities and irregularity of the left second and third lateral ribs, suggestive of fractures.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ presented to the Emergency Department on ___ with acute onset periumbilical pain.  An abdominal 
ultrasound was suggestive of a 
'moderately distended gallbladder with mural edema and dependent 
stones; early acute cholecystitis should be considered' and 
cholelithiasis; LFTs were also elevated upon admission (T. bili. 
2.9)  While in the ED, intravenous fluids, pain/ nausea 
medication and intravenous antibiotics were administered.  He 
was subsequently admitted to the Acute Care Surgical service for 
ongoing management.  

Upon admission, the patient underwent an MRCP for evaluation of 
possible choledocholithiasis given elevated LFTs.  The MRCP was 
notable for 'appearance consistent with hepatic edema, likely 
hepatitis, abnormal gallbladder with marked gallbladder wall 
edema and gallstones' without evidence of common bile duct 
stones.  Additionally, a minimally complex cyst in the lower 
pole of the left kidney was noted with follow recommended in 6 
months. 

On HD2, an ERCP was attempted, but unsuccesssful due to 
Roux-en-Y anatomy.  Post-procedure, the patient's abdominal pain 
improved and LFTs trended downward suggesting passage of stones. 
 He was subsequently taken to the operating room on HD3 where he 
underwent a laparascopic cholecytectomy; see operative note for 
details.  Post-operatively, the patient remained afebrile with 
stable vital signs; intravenous antibiotics were not resumed.  
His diet was advanced to regular and well tolerated.  
Additionally, he was voiding adequately and ambulating 
independently.  He was subsequently discharged to home on POD1 
and will follow-up in ___ clinic in 2 weeks. Of note, while in 
the PACU, a pilonidal cyst without erythema was noted, which per 
patient, is chronic.  The patient was instructed to continue 
current management of dry dressings prn with regular inspection 
of site.  Warning signs were reviewed with patient with 
perceived good understanding. He will follow-up with his primary 
care provider for ongoing management.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain due to 
inflammation of your gallbladder and elevated laboratory values 
caused by gallstones.  After likely passage of the stone/s, your 
pain improved and your laboratory values began normalizing.  You 
subsequently underwent a laparascopic cholecystectomy and 
recovered in the hospital.  You are now preparing for discharge 
to home with the following instructions:

 Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.
Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. 
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.

Additionally, please continue to apply a dry dressing to the 
cyst on your back.  Please inspect this site regularly and 
report any chills, fever, redness, increase and/ or change in 
drainage to your physician ___.  Also, please follow-up 
with your primary care provider for ongoing management.
 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
discharge_summary:
The patient is a 49-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with sudden onset sharp, constant periumbilical pain. He has a history of gastric bypass surgery and has experienced similar pain in the past. His past medical history includes IDDM, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hyperthyroidism, stiff man syndrome, and kidney stones. He also has a family history of diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and T-cell lymphoma.

The patient was diagnosed with acute cholecystitis and underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He was also found to have cholelithiasis and a minimally complex cyst in the lower pole of the left kidney. His laboratory results showed elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels.

The patient was treated with intravenous fluids, pain medication, and antibiotics, and was subsequently discharged home with a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. His medications at discharge included oxycodone for pain, docusate sodium for constipation, rosuvastatin for hyperlipidemia, lisinopril for hypertension, tamsulosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia, levothyroxine for hypothyroidism, latanoprost and levobunolol for glaucoma, magnesium gluconate for constipation, vitamin B-12 for deficiency, and insulin aspart for diabetes.

The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care provider for ongoing management and to continue his current management of dry dressings for a pilonidal cyst.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old female who presented with chest pain, dyspnea, and nausea. She was diagnosed with Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI) and underwent a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) procedure to treat a 90% stenosis in the proximal right coronary artery. The patient also had a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, vitamin D deficiency, esophagus, kidney stones, medullary sponge disease, and rheumatoid arthritis. She had a family history of coronary artery disease (CAD) in her mother, father, and sister.

The patient's allergies include erythromycin base, iodine, latex, sulfa, and clindamycin. She was prescribed aspirin 81mg daily, Plavix 75mg daily, pantoprazole, losartan 50mg daily, and metoprolol succinate 25mg daily at discharge.

The patient's physical examination revealed a well-developed and well-nourished female with no significant skin lesions or rashes. Her vital signs were stable, and her lungs were clear bilaterally. The patient's electrocardiogram (EKG) showed normal sinus rhythm with no acute ST changes.

The patient's pertinent results included a coronary angiogram that showed ostial stenosis in the left main coronary artery and a 90% stenosis in the proximal right coronary artery. The PCI procedure was successful in treating the stenosis, and the patient was discharged with a plan for staged PCI in the future.

-refrain from sitting longer than 15minutes spaced at least 4 
hours apart.
-Use cusions and comforters to pad your surgical site as 
possible to avoid undue pressure to that area.

Colorectal Surgery Discharge Instructions
You were admitted to the hospital after a transperineal 
completion proctectomy and gracilis flap reconstruction for 
surgical management of your recurrent pelvic abscess, retained 
anal sphincter, and J-pouch anastomosis. You have recovered from 
this procedure well and you are now ready to go to a 
rehabilitation facility. You have tolerated a regular diet, have 
good ostomy output and your pain is controlled with pain 
medications by mouth. You may go to a rehabilitation facility 
and then home to finish your recovery.

Please monitor the appearance of the ostomy and stoma and care 
for it as instructed by the wound/ostomy nurses. ___ stoma 
(intestine that protrudes outside of your abdomen) should be 
beefy red or pink, it may ooze small amounts of blood at times 
when touched and this should subside with time. The skin around 
the ostomy site should be kept clean and intact. Monitor the 
skin around the stoma for bulging or signs of infection listed 
above. Please care for the ostomy as you have been instructed by 
the wound/ostomy nurses. 

If you have any of the following symptoms please call the office 
for advice or go to the emergency room if severe: increasing 
abdominal distension, increasing abdominal pain, nausea, 
vomiting, inability to tolerate food or liquids, prolonged loose 
stool, or extended constipation.

You have an incision along your perineum which is closed with 
sutures. This incision can be left open to air or covered with a 
dry sterile gauze dressing.  Additionally you have a long 
incision on your medial thigh from the gracilis flap by the 
plastic surgery team.  This can be left open to air. Please 
monitor the incision for signs and symptoms of infection 
including: increasing redness at the incision, opening of the 
incision, increased pain at the incision line, draining of 
white/green/yellow/foul smelling drainage, or if you develop a 
fever. Please call the office if you develop these symptoms or 
go to the emergency room if the symptoms are severe. You may 
shower, let the warm water run over the incision line and pat 
the area dry with a towel, do not rub.
No heavy lifting for at least 6 weeks after surgery unless 
instructed otherwise by Dr. ___ Dr. ___. You may 
gradually increase your activity as tolerated but avoid heavy 
exercise.  You will be prescribed a small amount of the pain 
medication oxycodone and oxycontin. Please take this medication 
exactly as prescribed. You may take Tylenol as recommended for 
pain. Please do not take more than 4000mg of Tylenol daily. Do 
not drink alcohol while taking narcotic pain medication or 
Tylenol. Please do not drive a car while taking narcotic pain 
medication.

You are being discharged on the antibiotic linezolid, which you 
will take until ___.  Please take this by mouth as 
directed on your prescription.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope 
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities. Good luck!
 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
discharge_summary: The patient is a 41-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for a pelvic abscess. She has a history of familial polyposis, hypothyroidism, and other medical conditions. She underwent a transperineal completion proctectomy and gracilis flap reconstruction to manage her recurrent pelvic abscess. The patient has allergies to lanolin, egg, and vancomycin. She was prescribed several medications at discharge, including Levothyroxine, Ranitidine, Linezolid, Gabapentin, OxycoDONE, OxyCODONE SR, and Acetaminophen. The patient was discharged to a rehabilitation facility for continued monitoring of her surgical wounds and physical therapy.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ presented to ___ and Delivery on ___ with loss of 
fluids and breech presentation. Decision made at that time to 
proceed with primary low transverse cesarean delivery. 

Postpartum, her course was complicated by preeclampsia, severe 
by blood pressures. Her serum labs were normal and P:C was 0.28 
on ___. On the evening of ___, she had a sustained severe 
blood pressure requiring one dose of fast-acting nifedipine. She 
was started on nifedipine 30mg daily that day, and after 3 days, 
was transitioned to labetalol 200mg q8h and uptitrated to 
labetalol 400mg po q8h starting ___. She remained asymptomatic 
and well throughout this time.

In addition, she had an episode of non-sustained tachycardia 
over the course of ___, for which complete workup, including 
EKG, repeat labs, and CTA were all reassuring. Etiology was 
thought to most likely be reflex tachycardia from nifedipine 
administration or insufficient oral intake.

Her postpartum course was otherwise uncomplicated. Her pain was 
treated with oral pain medications. She was continued on her 
home levothyroxine. She ambulated and her foley was discontinued 
and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was advanced without 
incident. 

By postpartum day 6, her blood pressures were stabilized in the 
normal to mild-range on an oral antihypertensive regimen. In 
addition, she was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating 
independently, and pain was controlled with oral medications. 
She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was then 
discharged home in stable condition with postpartum outpatient 
follow-up scheduled.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 38-year-old female who presented to the hospital with a chief complaint of loss of fluids and breech presentation. She is a G1P0 at 38 weeks and 1 day gestation. Her past medical history includes hypothyroidism, prolactinoma, pituitary microadenoma, nephrolithiasis, and abnormal pap smear with +HPV. She has a history of allergies to aspirin.

The patient underwent a primary low transverse cesarean delivery due to breech presentation. Her postpartum course was complicated by preeclampsia, which was managed with nifedipine and labetalol. She also experienced an episode of non-sustained tachycardia, which was thought to be related to reflex tachycardia from nifedipine administration or insufficient oral intake.

The patient was discharged home on postpartum day 6 with a stable condition, tolerating a regular diet, ambulating independently, and pain controlled with oral medications. Her medications at discharge include docusate sodium, ibuprofen, and labetalol.

His past medical history includes hyperlipidemia, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, gout, and obesity. He also has a history of cholecystectomy, bilateral hip replacement, and fractured skull. The patient has allergies to Celebrex and has a family history of lung cancer and CAD.

The patient underwent a left VATS and wedge resection of the left lower lobe lung nodule and mediastinal lymph node sampling. He tolerated the procedure well and was discharged to home with a diagnosis of left lower lobe lung nodule. His medications at discharge include acetaminophen, docusate sodium, milk of magnesia, oxyCODONE, levemir, novolog, allopurinol, aspirin, atorvastatin, benazepril, dorzolamide, gemfibrozil, hydrochlorothiazide, ibuprofen, latanoprost, metFORMIN, and tamsulosin.

The patient was advised to continue using his incentive spirometer, check his incisions daily, and report any increased redness or drainage. He was also instructed to remove his chest tube dressing in 48 hours and to wean his pain medication over the next week as the discomfort resolves.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 69-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital for a planned radical pancreatoduodenectomy to clear biopsy-proven adenocarcinoma of the uncinate process of the pancreas. He presented with obstructive jaundice and weight loss. The patient has a history of myocardial infarction, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and spinal stenosis. He also has a history of coronary artery disease and has undergone percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty. The patient's past medical history is significant for a tonsillectomy as a child and a history of cancer in his mother and father.

The patient underwent exploratory laparoscopy and laparoscopic liver biopsy, which revealed metastatic disease to his liver. He was then taken to the operating room for an elective Whipple procedure, but it was aborted due to the discovery of metastatic disease. Instead, the patient underwent ERCP and a metal biliary stent was placed in his common bile duct.

The patient was discharged home in stable condition, with a diagnosis of metastatic pancreatic carcinoma and a common bile duct stricture. He was prescribed several medications, including aspirin, atenolol, docusate sodium, enalapril, furosemide, gabapentin, glargine, metformin, omeprazole, oxycoDONE, senna, and simvastatin. He was also advised to follow up with his surgeon and primary care provider as advised, and to resume all regular home medications unless specifically advised not to take a particular medication.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old male who presented with a severe headache and nausea/vomiting after fixing his window at home. He was diagnosed with a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and underwent a cerebral angiogram, which did not reveal any evidence of an aneurysm. The patient was treated with dilantin, but due to low serum levels and a rash, he was switched to Keppra. He also developed a left basilic vein thrombosis and had episodes of intermittent hyponatremia, which were treated with salt tablets.

The patient's past medical history includes diabetes, hypercholesterolemia, cataract surgery, and a non-traumatic retinal detachment. He has allergies to penicillins and Vicodin.

The patient's diagnosis is a subarachnoid hemorrhage, and he underwent a cerebral angiogram to rule out an aneurysm. He was treated with dilantin and later switched to Keppra due to side effects.

The patient underwent a brief hospital course, during which he was monitored for any complications. He was started on a course of dilantin, but due to side effects, he was switched to Keppra. He also developed a left basilic vein thrombosis and had episodes of intermittent hyponatremia, which were treated with salt tablets.

The patient's medications at discharge include nimodipine, docusate sodium, senna, oxycodone-acetaminophen, levetiracetam, and simvastatin.

discharge_summary: The patient is a 35-year-old female who was admitted with abdominal pain, which was diagnosed as gallstone pancreatitis. She had a history of gestational diabetes, Caesarean section, and GERD. She was also experiencing pruritus, dark urine, yellowing of her eyes, and fatigue. Her laboratory results showed elevated LFTs and lipase levels. She underwent ERCP with sphincterotomy and biopsy of the ampulla, which was negative for malignancy. Her LFTs were slow to resolve, but she remained pain-free and was tolerating a low-fat diet. She was discharged with instructions to follow up with her primary care physician and to schedule an outpatient cholecystectomy. Her medications at discharge included diphenhydrAMINE for pruritus and outpatient lab work to monitor her LFTs.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ male with history of renal transplant in ___ who 
presents with subacute kidney injury.
.
# Acute on chronic kidney injury - 
The patient was admitted with a Cr of 5.3. Renal U/S showed 
moderate-to-severe hydronephrosis, which had worsened over the 
past year. FeNa was 5.5%. Urine culture negative on two 
occasions. The patient had good urine output. A Cudet foley 
catheter was placed with good return. Both Urology and 
transplant nephrology were involved in the case. The etiology of 
the renal failure was thought to be multifactorial: ATN ___ 
recent illness with significant nausea/vomiting during which 
time he continued to take Lasix and losartan with obstructive 
component because the patient had stopped taking terazosin. The 
patient's Cr did not improve during ___ hospitalization. His K, 
which was intially 5.2 responded to Kayexelate and his potassium 
was stable throughout the admission. A repeat renal ultrasound 
showed progression of the hydronephrosis despite a foley 
catheter in place with good return. Cystogram showed a dilated 
collecting system but no ureteral stricture. The patient was 
discharged with a foley in place and urology follow-up the 
following week. He was also discharged to have his renal lytes 
rechecked and with close nephrology follow-up. Terazosin was 
restarted. Lasix and losartan were stopped with the patient to 
take lasix only every ___ day. 
.
# Hypertension- The patient had persistent hypertension during 
this admission. Losartan was held given acute kidney injury. The 
patient was continued on his home diltiazem and nadolol. 
Hydralazine 25 mg tid was started with good response. 
.
# S/p renal transplant- The patient's immunosuppressive regimen 
with prednisone 4 mg qday and imuran 50 mg qday was contiued as 
was calcitriol.
.
# Hyperlipidemia: Continued home statin. 
.
# GERD
- continude PPI
.
# BPH- Thought to have contributed to acute kidney injury. 
Terazosin 3 mg bid was started to be uptitrated as an 
outpatient. The patient was discharged with a foley in place and 
urology follow-up. 
.
# ___- patient has had over 4000 lesions removed. Outpatient 
follow-up with dermatology
.
# DVT prophylaxis with subQ heparin. The patient remained full 
code throughout this admission. Contact was with the patient's 
wife, ___ ___.

Output:
discharge_summary: The patient is a 53-year-old male who was admitted with acute kidney injury on chronic kidney disease. He has a history of renal transplant in 2007 for IgA nephropathy and has been non-adherent to his terazosin medication for the past three months. He presented with a two-week history of severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which resolved before admission. His creatinine level was elevated at 4.7, and he was found to have a potassium level of 5.2. He was given kayexelate and maintained a good urine output. The patient's past medical history includes IgA nephropathy, chronic MRSA osteomyelitis, multiple skin cancers, hypertension, enlarged prostate, restless leg syndrome, GERD, gout, hypertriglyceridemia, and anxiety. He was diagnosed with interval progression of severe hydronephrosis of the transplant kidney and cortical thinning. He was treated with a Cudet foley catheter, kayexelate, and hydralazine, and was discharged with a foley in place and urology follow-up. He was also restarted on terazosin and lasix was stopped.
